A Year in Review . . . Seeing as yet another half-day (more on that later) is going by so slowly, I think I can afford a little time to look back on 2002 . . . The first part of 2002 was fraught with personal problems. I was definitely not getting along with my brother as a roommate, and I take part of the blame for that. Still, it was not an ideal living arrangement, and we fought constantly during the little time I was actually home. I spent most of my time over at my boyfriend's, which wasn't the greatest thing for us at the time, either. He was sympathetic and very accomodating, but a new relationship needs time to grow without that kind of pressure. We had our problems over the summer, but eventually started seeing each other again, for which I am glad. I am very happy at the moment. =) Thanks to long distance and sporadic communication, my father stopped talking to me when I moved out of the apartment I shared with my brother. Although he was covering my share of the rent (long story - I was still in school), it was apparently still a huge deal for me to be leaving 8 months into a year-long lease. It wasn't as if I was forcing my brother to leave as well . . . but the end result of the matter is that my father no longer speaks to me. Oddly enough, the harshest words were exchanged between my brother and I, and we are now back on pretty good terms. One family member down . . . one gained. My grandpa moved to the city from Sherwood Park (Edmonton area) in October. Though I have yet to see his place, it's nice to know he's in the city with the rest of his family. He suffered some very difficult times health-wise, and I'm glad he's closer now, and I'm hoping he's got many more good years to go before his time is up. I graduated from school . . . this is an accomplishment that has been 5 years in the making. It's too bad I don't have a bachelor degree to show for those 4 years (I only have a diploma, and I took a year off after 2 years at university), but at least I have something. I love learning, but I definitely don't miss the homework, or the exams, or the late nights stressing over whether or not everything would get done in time. I miss the comraderie of seeing the same 20-odd people 5 days a week. The shared commiserating over beers after a particularly grueling day. And strangely enough, I sometimes miss the craziness that was my last 2 months. I had just moved out on my own, I was trying desperately to maintain the 20 hours a week required at work in order to qualify for a scholarship (not to mention, making enough to cover rent), and at school we had 16 weeks' worth of material in 3 classes crammed into 6 weeks. For the most part, I'd wake up Monday morning and go to school from 8-3. From 3-5 I'd be downtown working on a project, then I would go home and sleep until 11pm. Then I'd work 12am-7am, and head back to school for 8am. I'd sleep when I got home in the afternoon sometime between 4 and 6pm, and this would continue until Friday morning. Then I would have 3 semi-normal days. But I'd still be at school for most of Friday and Saturday, since I needed use of a computer for homework and didn't have one at home. And the schedule was further complicated by being quite sick once or twice, sleeping at night, then switching back to sleeping in the afternoons but not being sleepy. I'm sure this makes absolutely no sense. =) But sometimes I miss that craziness. Only cuz it gave me an excuse for doing a half-assed job of stuff. *L* I got my first apartment . . . though it was tough at first, because I was still in school, I managed. I learned that, much as I always wanted my own place, I really miss having company. In the 8 months I've been on my own, I just do not enjoy spending more than a few hours at a time at home alone. Growing up, I had 3 brothers and plenty of (sometimes unwanted! *s*) company. I like my own space - and I LOVE being able to walk around in the buff - but I get lonely easily. =)
HAPPY NEW YEAR TO EVERYONE! =) I wish everyone the best in health, love, family, career, and life in general! =)

Dealing with Family Families can be tough to deal with. Especially when children grow up. We develop our own set of values, because no matter how much our parents would like to think differently, we are all individuals. We develop an identity separate from our parents and our family, but we are still connected. When disagreements occur, it is a touchy issue. With most other people (friends, boyfriends, etc), there's always the thought in the back of our heads that "There are tonnes more people out there". But family is family. They're yours and you're theirs as long as you live. I've mentioned before that my father and I don't speak anymore. He's moved away to be with his wife, and it's easy to forget about him. It sounds callous, but it's a reality. He was there for me once when I really needed someone, and for that I'm grateful. But the odd little reminder still hurts - that he could have regular contact with one of his four children, less regular contact with two more, and virtually none with the fourth. I suppose with four kids, it can be easy to play favorites. I always feared disappointing him. Perhaps I still do, but without him around, it's not something I think about. And more recently, I fear disappointing my grandpa greatly. My grandpa is very special to me. I know I don't show it anywhere near often enough, but he is. He is the best grandpa ever. Even in the bad times when I was younger, he was never stingy with compliments. He made me feel like a bit like a princess, and in a house full of boys and with a father that was obvious about his favorites, that was a feeling to be treasured. When I was six, he made - by hand - this huge doll house for me. For me. Complete with tiny furniture and the sides of the house swung open so I could play inside. My favorite part was the bathroom on the second floor at the front of the house. Even for a child's hands, it was difficult to get into that bathroom. But the toilet had a pull-chain to flush it. Of course it didn't really flush, but to a child with an imagination, it was heaven. Whenever I see him (which is far too little), he always compliments my hair, and makes a big deal of how gorgeous it is. I know I'm not the prettiest thing on the block, but my hair has always been my one vain spot. You can see why I love my grandpa. =) He's old-fashioned, my grandpa. I want so badly to go and see him, but I worry that news about my life would disappoint him. While I am very happy with recent developments, I'm not sure how he would take it. When my grandpa was young, people got married, then lived together, then had kids, and then they died. He worships my grandma and her memory. I don't know if he'd understand how things are different for me. Sometimes I feel like even my mum doesn't. She has been very good about keeping lectures and disapproving looks to a minimum, but I know how she feels. People shouldn't live together before they get married. And I don't blame her much - after my last break up, I even declared myself that I wouldn't live with another man unless marriage was a very near reality. But since then, my views have changed. So long as my boyfriend and I are on the same level and still agree on important issues, I don't see a problem with moving ahead with our lives sans a ring and a proposal. But I worry that my grandpa won't agree with me. That he'll think I'm an irresponsible girl who just follows what everyone else is doing. And that would tear me apart. I don't want to lose my princess status with my grandpa. Because one day, when I do decide that I'm good and ready for marriage, I want him to be the one who offers me to my husband-to-be. Sorry, dad, but it's how I feel. I've been reluctant to share my happy news with most of my family. I worry that they'll all feel the same way, and then I will always have to face the veiled disappointment in their eyes. Why do the opinions of our family matter so much to us? Because no matter what, we love them and no matter what, we're stuck with them.

My bf and I went to the carpet/flooring store yesterday and spent over an hour deciding what the rest of the house would look like. Now, this had plenty of potential for some nasty results. This being our first house, and really, the first real "our" place at all, we have never decorated together. I moved into his apartment, and seeing as he was already set up, I can't be bothered to try changing anything. So now we have the task of deciding together how we want this house to look. Exterior colours was a tad painful. My imagination has been in hibernation mode for a long time, and tiny little colour cards did not help much when it came to picturing what the house would look like. So we drove around to the houses that were finished and decided on something we could live with. Appliances were a lot easier. It's either black or white. And we'd both agreed that white cupboards and black appliances would look really sharp. But yesterday was the toughest of all. There was carpet. Not only colour, but texture, pile height, and material. Polyester tends to be stain-resistent; nylon wears forever. One type of texture shows a change in colour when the nap changes (you know, the light and dark streaks when you vacuum?) . . . the others aren't quite as soft. My bf wanted a lighter colour, something neutral. I love darker colours, especially green and blue. Since we're also keeping resale in mind with all these decisions, we compromised with gray. Sounds pretty boring, but it's actually a really warm colour. It has more character to it than beige or tan, but is more neutral than green or blue. But that wasn't it. Oh no, far from it. Then there was lino. That was very simple. There was a sample sitting out on the floor, the saleslady asked if we liked, and we both agreed right away. It had the nice large squares, which make the room seem bigger. That was quick. Then countertops. Complicating matters was the fact that I had this showhome kitchen in my head that I was trying to recreate. Well, I don't have a perfect memory, and in the face of thousands of different designs and colours, it's easy to lose sight of how everything will look when it's all done. But we settled on that fairly quickly, too. A medium charcoal speckled pattern that went well with all the colours picked so far. Next was kitchen tiles. Oh man, that was the worst. The saleslady pointed out their wall with the tiles that came standard. Within one second flat, I said "nope". None of them would do. They all looked like bathroom tiles. I didn't want my kitchen looking like a bathroom. I must have looked through all the samples, and tried to explain to her what was in my head, before realizing that what I wanted was just not there. Or if it was, it was going to cost too much. After much deliberation, we finally went with another dark colour in a large tile. Messes will be easy to camouflage in our kitchen. =) Don't worry, when it's all done, I will see what I can do about putting pictures up so this all makes sense. You'd think we were done, but the bathroom tiles were separate (obviously). Those got picked out fairly quickly. A creamy matte tile with an etched one randomly inserted every 10 tiles. Ohhh, boy. And then grouting colour for each tile pattern, edging for carpet-to-lino transitions, and lino-to-lino where the back steps meet the kitchen. All in all, I think it's going to look very nice. It's going to be so hard waiting for it to be done!

Come to think of it . . . is anything ever truly original? Ideas are always built on something . . . theories are based on disproving an established idea . . . it all has to start from something. If it's derived from something else, it's just a twist, an expansion, a deviation. It's not truly original. So where did the first human being get his/her ideas from? Do I think too much? Yes, methinks so. It's my curse in life. Do I ever think about anything useful or practical? No, not really. I need inspiration in order to keep these deranged thoughts at bay . . . woohoo! Dreams I had a very weird dream last night. I don't usually remember my dreams, but if I do, they often don't make any sense when I recount them after waking. I dreamt last night that I went to the movies with my bf. Nothing unusual there. But we had a dog with us (in real life, we only have two cats). Apparently they had special showings in which dogs were allowed, but the one we wanted to see wasn't one of them. No biggie - we sweet-talked out way into the movie, and found that a few other lucky people had done the same. There were a couple of other dogs in the theatre. I told you my dreams were always weird . =) Anyways, the dog was behaving itself for the most part, but my bf started getting bored with the movie. He started barking. *L* So of course, our dog joined in, and so did the others, much to the dismay of the other movie-goers. I can't remember if we got kicked out, but I'm sure we must have. I must have been rich in this dream, cuz later that same day, I went to the movies again. This time it was with my mum. No dogs this time. None in the theatre either, so it must have been a no-dog showing. =) Except this time, we sat beside two women who were holding hands. The larger one of the two took an immediate interest in my mum and kept asking her questions and trying to steal her away from me. So we eventually moved a few rows down. I don't remember how it ended. I've given up trying to figure out if my dreams mean anything . The odd time there's been an obvious meaning - like the dream where I was in a car driven by an ex and it kept getting smaller until I fell out - but most of the time, I believe it's just my brain getting rid of garbage. And since I'm not terribly creative in waking life, I figure that's why they're extra weird. =) I'm very tired this week. I hope I'm not getting sick. My 'sick' dream always freaks me out. It's always the same one - I'm in a huge, blindingly-white room with no real boundaries or walls, and there are hoards of little creatures chasing me from one end to the other. I can never see them, but I'm terrified in the dream and when I wake up.

Thought for the day: Hypocrits don't make good friends.

Hmmm . . . upon reviewing that last post, it occurred to me . . . What's happened to the imaginations of kids these days? I have many friends who agree - when we were young, the only TV we watched was Saturday morning cartoons (and they were GOOD cartoons, not the crazy nonsense on YTV these days) so our parents could sleep in, and maybe the odd show or two after school. But we didn't have Nintendos or PS or X-box or internet for the longest time . . . so we had to amuse ourselves. We'd complain of being bored to our parents, and they'd simply say "well, find something to do then." And then we came up with games or crafts or projects by ourselves. Refrigerator boxes were the ultimate, empty toilet rolls and paper bags had endless possibilities . . . I don't know many primary-school-aged children who play like this anymore. Granted, I don't know all that many children in that age range, but still. Are they losing something in having their entertainment provided for them? It makes me wonder . . . Perhaps I'm naive, but if I ever have children, I'd like them to be able to see the potential in every day house-hold items. It's gotta be expensive having kids even without all the gadgets and new-fangled electronic toys . . . Yeesh, I sound like a grandparent or something . . . "Well, in MY day we had to walk blah blah blah blah . . . " *L*

I used to be creative . . . I'm just not quite sure what happened. =) When I was young, it was great having four kids in the family. Well, OK, it was great when my younger brothers got old enough to play with. The youngest is almost 7 years younger than me, so it was a while before we all played together. We used to put on plays for my parents and any unsuspecting guests who might happen to be over at the time. I was director, producer, and often the star as well. But of course my brothers were involved - no fun being a director if there's no one to direct! =) We made sure my mum got the big brown paper bags when she shopped, since we were the perfect size for using those as costumes. We'd cut out a hole for our head (usually the whole bottom flap) and holes for our arms. Most often, we were Carebears . . . but not always. And we would do skits. Based on this apparently outgoing and show-offey nature , I don't understand why I had performance anxiety at piano recitals just a few years later. I guess I probably was (am? *s*) a bossy older sister . . . during long-past summers, my brothers and I would keep ourselves amused by playing school. It wasn't enough that we were in school for real the rest of the time . . . play school was fun, because I was in control. =) It goes without saying that I was always the teacher, and my brothers were always the students. I could be wrong, but I don't recall any strong objections on their part. I loved being in charge, and giving them assignments (yes, they actually got homework, and they actually did it!) and then marking them. You'd think I would have felt a stronger calling as a teacher, but it's one profession I've never even bothered considering. And yet, many years later when I was to teach piano lessons to a handful of children, it was something I almost dreaded at times. I wasn't strict at all, and as such, not many of my students progressed as far or as fast as they could have or should have. After 3 years, I decided that I was not doing these children any favors, and got out of it (it also helped that that was the same time I moved into an apartment where I couldn't keep a piano any longer). Should I ever have children of my own, I think it's something I might go back to (teaching piano), albeit with a different attitude. It's an ideal parttime job for a stay-at-home mom. I remember when I first started playing the piano. Boy, is this entry ever wandering! =) Oh well, I'm rolling with it . . . I actually started out in singing lessons. Obviously, my singing teacher had a piano that she used regularly during our lessons. It wasn't long before curiosity got the better of me and I asked her to show me how to play the piano as well. It was only a matter of months before she'd taught me all she felt comfortable with, and had to suggest another teacher to my parents. I wish I'd been able to do both - singing and piano - but my parents couldn't afford both. But I went far with the piano . . . for anyone who's familiar with classical music training (RCM) , I completed Grade 10 before I finished high school, and attempted to begin my teaching degree/diploma (performance - the other option - definitely wasn't my cuppa tea) when I started university, but it proved to be too much. One day, I'll complete it . . . Well, I could keep going on this memory lane , but at nearly 24 years, it could be a while before it runs out . . . =) So I'll leave it at that for now. I like reminiscing. I have lots of good memories up to about 14/15 years of age.

A Cursed Office At first, I chuckled to myself when someone mentioned that our new (well, 6 months old now) office building was cursed. Then came our first accident less than 3 months after we moved in. A man was killed when a forklift crushed him. I don't know all the details, nor do I care to. Although it happened in the back shop, and I was oblivious until I saw all the somber faces around the office nearly two hours after the fact, it's been my nearest exposure to such a situation. Then today, a second "incident", just over 3 months after the first. Thankfully, as far as I know, it wasn't fatal. But someone had a heart attack - and nobody nearby knew CPR! I find that absolutely incredible, given that most of the employees work in the shop out back. To me, it would be common sense that the employer would run a First Aid/CPR course at least once a year. And especially after the first accident. Oh well, I'm not the employer, so who am I to say anything? I just get interrogated about why I'm using a courier at $5/destination instead of regular post. Ohhhhh, I sense a rant coming on . . . One word - management. You know what I'm talking about (unless you're in the upper management yourself . . . in which case, I would highly suggest you stop reading now) . . . bosses. I just have to shake my head sometimes. Perhaps I'll understand someday if I ever become one myself, but until then, I will remain baffled. For example . . . from what I understand, our main boss is more of a people person than a computer person. To put it politely. Email is a challenge. Meanwhile, most of the office staff uses computers all day long, and a few of us run several large and complex programs. To me, the sensible thing would be to spend a little extra for a computer with a faster processor, etc for the people using computers all the time. Save a few bucks on a slightly less fancy though entirely adequate one for those only needing it for email. Sensible, yes? Apparently not. The boss has not one, but two very fancy and expensive-looking computers at his disposal. I have yet to see him use either. Meanwhile, the office manager was running something equivalent to a 386 up until she moved to the reception desk, where it was determined that we couldn't have clients seeing that piece of junk as soon as they walk in. Three people in our little corner of 4 offices got their computers stolen recently. The thieves completely by-passed my office in favour of kicking in a door down the hall. I'm very upset . . . those who lost their computers got fancy new Dell ones with the flat screen monitors, and I'm stuck with my old HP. Boohoo for me . . . I'm hoping they come back and take mine. *L* As I mentioned before, I get asked why I'm using a courier instead of the regular post. Apparently my boss has absolutely no idea what I do. In fact, I know he doesn't. I make reports, and often clients want 4 or even 5 copies. When the report is up to 60 pages long, with dividers and a data CD, I figured $5 per destination regardless of weight (within reason) was pretty darn reasonable. I'm sure the same package would be at least $10 by regular post, and would take up to 3 days to be delivered, as opposed to a coupla hours. And it's not as if I'm careless - I'll only call once a day, so if there are multiple reports going to the same destination, they all go out at once. Unless, of course, the client is in a huge hurry for the data. And the latest - I've been asked to cross-check all our field technicians' time sheets with jobs and invoices to see what we're charging out vs what we're paying them. I thought that's what his cracker-jack CA was for. I tried to explain to him that not all jobs are billed out by the hour - quite a few are flat job rates, and all-inclusive. I have a sneaky feeling that if I do exactly what he asked me, and simply look up hours billed, he will come back with a million questions, and it will have to be done all over again. And if I do read between the lines and provide him with what he really wants - easily a few days' worth of work, and we're in busy season - he will still have questions. I don't think I like being a subsidiary company working in the same building as the parent company. Ohhhh, there's more. Would it not be logical to have a team working in the same area, physically? Our little subsidiary company of 3 office and 4 field staff shares the same office building as the parent company. Two of my co-workers are up on the second level at the back of the building. I'm on the main floor at the front. When we first moved in, there was an empty office right across the hall from my co-workers. Two, in fact. But one quickly turned into a sadly disorganized storage room, and the other for salesmen that are constantly consulting the woman in the office next to mine. Would it not make more sense to have us switch? I would be more than willing to spend a few hours on a Saturday to move stuff so that it didn't disrupt a regular work day. But no - that's entirely out of the question! I need to be downstairs with all the other women in some sort of harem or something. So I can be at the boss's beck and call. Phew, I'd better stop soon . . . work is over for the day, and I'll end up going in tomorrow morning very bitter! There are a few perks that make my job worth staying at . . . I just felt like ranting about all the bad stuff today. =)

The Continuing Saga That Is My Dodge . . . Ah yes . . . the infamous Dodge Spirit. Thought maybe I'd gotten rid of it, because I hadn't posted anything in a long time? I wish!! No, no . . . I've just successfully tried not to think about it for a long time. Well, a few weeks anyways. It's an entirely unpleasant situation that I would just rather not pollute my mind with. But it's always there, and it pops up at random times. Like yesterday. A few weeks back, I attempt to placate the shop manager and myself by saying that I would put the car up for sale again, but leave it on his lot until it was sold. Then he'd get paid as soon as it was, and he could be happy. And then, should I choose to, I could take action to get my money back. Or some of it. But I didn't tell him that last part, of course. About a week ago, I finally forked over a dozen dollars or so to have the ad in the Bargain Finder enhanced and run for 3 weeks - I'm horrible at remembering to call in each week to renew it. No biters the first week. A few missed calls on my cell where I didn't recognize the number, but nobody left a message. Oh well, whatever. Then yesterday - at home (I advertised my cell number) - I got a call. At first, I couldn't figure out how on earth he got this number - and my name, to boot. Then he explained that he saw the car at the garage, but the number on it didn't work (obviously - I moved and hadn't changed the sign). He talked to the manager - AND THE MANAGER GAVE HIM ALL THESE DETAILS! Gave him my home phone number, my name, and even went so far as to tell him what exactly had been done to the car and the fact (and the exact amount) that I still owed the shop money. I was livid! Since when can a stranger walk off the street and get all this information?? My anger bordered on feeling violated. So, either one of two things is going to happen this weekend . . . the guy is going to call on Saturday to test drive it. Obviously I can't let him drive it off the lot, since it's neither insured nor registered. I will be tickled pink if he buys it. That's the ideal option. But if he doesn't, the car is leaving that lot, with or without the manager's consent. I still have AMA coverage, and I'll get it towed to the bf's dad's acreage outside the city. I went out at lunch today and got a spare key cut from the dealership, and I'll find some way of getting the club taken off. Oh yeah - and the shop has also put a club on my steering wheel. Once again - if you don't want to get ripped off or screwed around - DO NOT TAKE YOUR VEHICLE TO SOUTH TRAIL CERTIGARD. Hehehe - can I get in trouble for un- advertising for a place? I don't care at this point. So - we'll see what happens. As I said, ideally the guy figures the car is worth it and buys it.

Good Days Yesterday was a good day for many reasons, despite starting it with two flat tires. To begin with, I got invited along for a lunch meeting. We were supposed to be meeting with 2 guys from another company to discuss some potential work, but when we got there, it was only one, and he was young. You just can't turn down company lunches, because it's free, and it's often ritzier places than I would regularly visit. And it means I get to go downtown - I really miss the whole downtown atmosphere and culture lately. So, just three of us for lunch, all within a few years' range of each other. Which meant the conversation had no trouble flowing after the business part of it was taken care of. Indeed, although it's a little taboo, I daresay there was just a hint of flirting going on, although innocent enough. It was fun. No matter whether the company was lively or not, I usually come back from lunch meetings just a little hyper and definitely refreshed. It's nice to eat a decent meal midday, and coming back around 1:30 or 2pm certainly helps the day go by faster. *L* I was a little sad though - my bf was unusually slow at work, so I'd hoped to have lunch with him and maybe drive by the lot to check on any progress. I called him when I got back from lunch, but he'd found something to do. Around 3:30 I get a call from him. Wants to know when I think I'll be done at work. Knowing there's got to be a reason for this (he knows my hours are fairly flexible unless I've got something urgent on the go), I ask what he's got in mind. We've been meaning to go see the house (or it's beginnings) all week. He really wanted to go see it, and wanted to know if I'd be done work soon so we could go together. Awwwww . . . I was so touched that he would call me first. So of course I snuck out of work early. No big deal - our office manager knew where I was going, and she knows how excited I am about this whole thing. And there's a big concrete foundation now! From nothing but a hole to a big, open concrete box in 4 days! Probably less, because it looked like it was already drying. I've been told that the actual structure goes up quite quickly, that it's the inside that takes the most time. That's OK with me . . . we'll be able to occupy ourselves better in the summer, when progress will be slower. We get a possession date when we do the framing walk-through in mid-June. It'll likely be September, as they've been consistently a month behind on most houses lately. I don't mind, because it gives us an extra month to save and get ready to move. Just so long as it's still nice enough to have a great big BBQ party when we move in! Exciting times, exciting times . . .

Rotten Luck Road hazards - they really suck. Yesterday, on my drive in to work, I was merely blocks away when my car started pulling really hard to the right. My first thought was "great, now I'm going to have to book it in for a wheel alignment or something." But because it came on so suddenly, I feared it was something worse. It was, and it wasn't. I got out at work, and I decided that before I inspected the car, I'd fill up the windshield washer fluid, since the warning light had been bugging me for nearly a week. It's one of those things I only think of doing while I'm driving - once I park, I'm so focused on what comes next that I've completely forgotten. On my way from the trunk to the hood, I noticed the very flat tire on the front passenger side. Groan. One of only two day I decide to dress up for work, and I'm going to have to figure out how to change a tire. Then, someone else is on their way in, when they look at my car and say "Wow, what happened there?" I explained I must have run over something. He said, "No kidding - you got the front AND the back!" Sure enough, when I walk around again, both tires are flat right down to the rims. Luckily, flat tires aren't major damage, so long as I haven't been driving long enough to warp the rims. I don't think I did. But silly me, I don't think terribly clearly under stress. I had no idea how far I could safely drive once they were pumped up (thank goodness I work at an office with a shop in the back - two guys helped me pump them up so I could drive somewhere to get them fixed). I took their suggestion of a nearby Husky station . . . there was no way I'd make it as far as the Honda dealership. I didn't think of it until later, but I have a friend who works at a tire shop only a 5-min drive away. I probably would have made it, but oh well. Turns out I managed to hit the exact same nail twice in the exact same spot on both tires. I have no idea where it happened, and can't believe I didn't notice. Mind you, I've never driven on a flat tire before, so you can't really blame me for not noticing sooner. So - I've officially broken in my car, literally. Unless you count my little encounter with the garbage crate in the alley. Sheesh, maybe I shouldn't be driving . . . at least not driving a new car! *L*

The Evil Addictiveness That Is The Sims Has anyone else come across this highly addictive game? It's kinda of old by now, but they keep coming up with expansion packs - Hot Date, Livin' Large, a pets one . . . Whosever brainchild this was knew what they were doing! I can play that game for hours and not know how much time has gone by (except Sims' time, that is!). You control these little people, how happy they are, or even how miserable they are. You can make them marry, have kids, renovate their home while their at work, or sleeping, or heck, even under their noses! Anyone who denies that people are control freaks on some level is indeed in denial. *L* I only have the basic version, none of the expansion packs yet. This weekend I was introduced to the Hot Date version. Now I want more! The characters are no longer confined to their homes and the lot surrounding them . . . they can venture "downtown", and return home as if time had never passed! If only real life was like this . . . get up an hour early for work, take a 2-day jaunt for entertainment and shopping, and still return in time to leave for work as if nothing had happened. Can you imagine how different life would be? I have one family that I mainly play with. It started out with one girl . . . she was a career girl, in the police force, and I was beginning to suspect she was more attracted to females. Yes, despite all the control you have, they will still develop their own personality with likes and dislikes. She got along so much better with the women that came by to visit than the men. She would interact with both, but develop a 'heart' for the women much quicker than the men. I was getting concerned . . . I wanted her to marry so there'd be two incomes and I could make a huge house with all the fancy accoutrement. (No, I'm not materialistic *L*). So I created a 'family' of three men, figuring at least one of them had to spark her interest! After a frustrating few 'days' - in which they would come calling and she would stubbornly stand and twiddle her thumbs instead of greeting them as I told her to do - she finally started getting to know them all. It quickly became apparently that one stood out, and after 4 separate rejections (she proposed), she finally lucked out. I since made them have a kid, and I'm curious to see if he ever grows to be an adult. Anyways, it's all pointless nonsense, but I felt like blogging about it this morning.

Once Again, I'm Proven Wrong Last night, I gathered together a set of tax forms and sprawled out on the floor with all my slips of paper. I went through them manually and carefully, and it turns out it was my mistake after all. It's rather sneaky, actually. Last time I did taxes, there wasn't a distinction between Alberta tuition and federal tuition carryovers. Or maybe I just never noticed. But I'd sure like to know how they differentiate the two. My carryover was Alberta tuition, not federal. I'd filled out my taxes with both, not knowing there was a difference. And it's a huge difference. Even if it was a federal carryover, my refund would have been much more. Oh well, I still got a sizeable one, so I won't complain. I think I'm going to make a habit of doing my taxes manually from now on, just to make sure the computer spits out a number I agree with. If I'd been expecting less, and received the same amount that I did, I would have been ecstatic. But being that I expected more, it was a little disappointing. Funny how that works, huh? But as I mentioned - it's all extra money. So it's all good. :) Before next tax season, it's my goal to have an RRSP started . . . I feel I'm getting kind of old not to have started one already.

And on to the subject of strip clubs Now, I don't want to offend any of my friends who think differently, cuz I know there are some. But I don't see anything wrong with strip clubs. To be honest, I think ladies' night are far more degrading than the average peelers. I think my bf was pretty proud of the fact that I had no problems going to the Speakeasy with him . . . until we found quite a few other couples who do the same thing. In my opinion, naked women are more appealing to look at than naked men. This certainly doesn't mean that I would rather take a girl home than a man - simply that the female form is just nicer. =) At ladies' nights, the women are hootin' and hollerin' and making huge asses of themselves. Not so at the peeler's. Sure, there's some, but not to the extent that I've seen it in Dewey Steven's and the like. For the most part, the women on stage look like they're enjoying themselves. They're not being forced to dance, and they're making damn good money, too! =) However, I'm only human, and on some days ('fat' days come to mind), I would rather not spend a Friday evening looking at women who are much prettier and skinnier than me. You know, it's interesting how it's much more socially acceptable for women to do a lot of things men wouldn't even consider, sexually. Let's start with the tame stuff. It's perfectly OK for women to hug and flirt with and even kiss their friends. I don't know many men that hug each other, let alone kiss. It's just not done unless you're gay. Women can compliment each other or make appreciative comments about goodlooking women without causing much commotion. For the more adventurous, not many people will think a woman is disgusting or homosexual just because she's experimented on the same sex. Yet that's the common opinion if it were a man doing the same thing. I guess there are some pretty good things about being a woman. =) Say, did anyone ever catch that Life Network show about switching genders? Two men and two women spent two weeks or so creating a personality of the opposite sex and living as that person. None of these people were considering changing their gender permanently or anything like that . . . it was just a human experiment. It was crazy. One of the girls cried when she had to have her hair cut . . . I don't blame her. My hair is part of what makes me consider myself feminine. Anyways, it was just interesting, and it made me think that I'm very happy being a woman and would never voluntarily change that!

On the subject of flirting I believe that flirting is a very important human behaviour. We do it with the opposite sex, and often women do it with their friends, too. For the most part, it's all pretty innocent, and makes everyone feel good. I miss flirting. After a relationship has officially entered the "long-term" zone, sure you still flirt occasionally, but it doesn't have the same effect as flirting with a stranger. My boyfriend is definitely a flirt. Not the schmarmy, creepy kind - he's just very friendly and social. And this doesn't bother me. In fact, most of the time, I hardly even notice if he's flirting with the waitress or cashier, because there's nothing disrespectful in the way he does it . . . There's some funny stories on that subject, but I'll keep that for another time. I like to flirt, too, but it has to be the right situation. Although it may seem cheesy, I like the attention I get when I'm out with a group of girlfriends at a nightclub or bar. Sadly, we haven't done that in ages. It renews my sense of sexiness to know that random men still think I'm attractive. How did one friend put it? . . . "Reassurance that I've still got it." I know some people, though, who think that any form of flirting with someone other than their S.O. is just plain disrespectful. I think it all depends on how it's done. If a guy goes out, sans his girl, and he intentionally leads other women to think he's single, and that he might go home with them - yes, that's disrespectful. Or if he overtly ogles or makes catcalls when he's out with his girl - that's disrespectful. These same people probably think strip clubs are degrading. Hmmm, maybe I'll make that my next topic.

To add a positive spin after my smoking rant . . . I think my bf and I have found a nice and very healthy solution to a common complaint. Recently, we were both lamenting - I that the only swimming pool in the city with an actual swim practice now seemed so far away; my bf that his gym now seemed so far away (he used to live just blocks away from it). Then it occurred to me - both of these places are within a couple minutes' drive from each other. What if we coordinated it so that we went together? And that's what we did last night. I was very happy. I haven't been swimming in at least 6 months, and it's one activity that I always miss. There's only one pool in the city that offers conditioning swim, which is basically like a drop-in swim practice, with a coach who gives a workout and everything. I can't do the lane swim thing - I need structure and feedback. Otherwise I get bored. I don't have to try out, it's reasonably cheap (city pool admissions are about $5.00, I believe), and it's only 2 nights a week. Very manageable. And my boyfriend likes going to the gym. For both of us, it's just a matter of getting motivated. I hope we can keep this up. Although I'm exhausted this morning. =) I'm very glad we have similar views on being active. If there's one thing that's very important to me (inherited from my mum), it's being fit, and being active with my s.o. We don't always have to be doing something together, but it gets very hard to stay fit when you're with someone who would rather just sit on the couch all the time. And I find it to be a very good bonding experience to do active stuff together. To some people, it's not that important, and that's fine. But it is to me. So that's another good thing about my bf. =) And one more bonus - maybe being more active (doing the gym thing twice a week) might give him an extra little push towards quitting smoking. I believe that he will quit one day. I'm not holding my breath . . . and maybe he might just cut down to a few a day. That would be fine with me. But I think, the older he gets, the more he realizes there are so many benefits to not smoking, or at least not being a slave to smoking. Just as an aside - kissing my bf is nothing like licking an ashtray (not that I've ever done that). Unless I make the mistake of kissing him when he's in the middle of a smoke, of course. =) I'm not sure where advertisers got that idea.

My cat is a smoker Well, he would be if he was human. I really don't know how it started - most cats I've known are completely turned off by the smell of tobacco. Not mine. At first, it was cute. When my boyfriend first started coming over, he'd let Tigger sniff him over, and Tigger would always linger on his cigarette hand. Soon, the cat was feverishly licking his index and middle fingers. And now that we've moved in, I've seen cigarette butts in odd places around the basement. I've caught him chewing on them occasionally - I have yet to figure out if he actually eats them. Yesterday, I went home at lunch to find one ashtray tipped over and butts scattered everywhere. This can't be good for him. I mean, smoking isn't good for humans - imagine what it must do to an animal less than a tenth of our size! It got me to thinking - it bothers me that the cat eats cigarette butts, but how often have I thought about what second hand smoke is doing to him? Or my boyfriend's cat? Or to myself, for that matter? I always figured that because I didn't live with him, it wasn't a big deal, and besides, it wasn't my place to tell him what he could and couldn't do in his own home. But now that we do live together, it's becoming a bit of an issue for me. When I first met my boyfriend, it didn't bother me. For the longest time, it didn't. But I tell ya - whenever I'm sick, and first thing in the morning, it's really harsh and irritating to not be able to get away from the smell. That's one thing that has kinda gone without saying - no smoking in the new house unless it's in the basement and only once the exhaust fan is installed. I can certainly see why debates between smokers and non-smokers gets so heated (pardon the pun). Really, who's rights are more important? The non-smoker's right to clean air and their own health? Or the smoker's right to lead their life as they please? I don't deny that smoking is an addictive habit and extremely hard to quit. And I could never force my boyfriend to quit. But at some point, I'm going to have to think about my own health. And that of any children, should they ever come into the picture. To be honest, I think if there was ever a baby in the picture, there would be absolutely no question - there would be no smoking anywhere near it. And I wouldn't have to ask for it. Well, that's it for my smoking theme today.

My cat's not skinny anymore! I have lots of innane things to talk about today. =) Yes, my skinny cat is looking a little beefier these days. Now I'm having to refill it after only a few days. I think if they start looking fat, we'll have to start portioning it. But for now, they just look like healthy, well-fed cats. Which is good. The two cats - my bf's and mine - play-fight a lot. Last night, they were fighting for real. And my reaction to the situation made me wonder how on earth step-families do it. I didn't actually see what was going on, but my bf checked up on the cats when they were a little more vocal than usual. When I wandered around the corner, he had mine pinned down and his was around the corner. My immediate reaction was to get defensive and think "What about your cat's part in this?". True, mine's got claws and his doesn't, and he's probably twice her size, but she's got a mean bite and knows how to defend herself. But I let it go. There wasn't really any harm done. But it struck me how instinctive it is for me to feel protective towards my cat. I had the exact same problem when I lived with my dad - there it was two on two (he had two, I had two). But whereas my bf will quickly admit he might have acted hastily, my dad always maintained that my cats were always in the wrong. Funny, he often had the same favoritist attitude when dealing with his kids. Personally, if I ever have kids, and they get caught fighting, I don't care who started it or who did what, they will both get punished. But that's just me.

A Night for Introspection I was all by myself . . . nobody was loooooooooking . . . I was all by myself . . . I'm all by my lonesome tonight, so I thought I'd take a little time to think . Normally, I would write in my journal. But really, I reserve my journal for explosive and urgent emotions - neither of which I'm feeling tonight. =) I get very intimidated when I'm faced with alone time. Not in a bad sense, really . . . more like I'm overwhelmed with the possibilities. I could work late . . . go to the gym . . . call up some friends and go for martinis . . . go visit my mum . . . go do a million and a half things I only think of doing when I'm too busy to do them. It's hard to decide what to do with myself. Especially when I have advance warning. Tonight, the bf is off at a course about ice machines , I think. I have no idea when he's going to be back. So I started by working late. I've been swamped, and I figured since I'll only be going home to an empty house, I might as well try and catch up a little. Over the course of the day, I heard numerous ads about tonight being martini night at Moxie's. Hmmm - I could call up a few friends for an impromtu get together. That one was tempting, but with my low alcohol tolerance, I'd be leery of driving home after just one. Scratch that idea. What about the gym? Well, that idea was strong, too, until I started thinking of my very cold, ratty and not-terribly-clean gym clothes in the back of my car. I want so badly to get a new pair of sweats, but it's an extra expense and extra spending has to be okayed by both parties. =) Hmmm, but C's getting new work pants . . . so it should be OK. I'm not really a huge shopping freak, but it seems like all my clothes wear out or feel old all at once, so I get the shopping bug once or twice a year, and then I spend lots of money all at once. Gotta curb that this year, in the interest of saving for the house! Well, all rambling aside, I'm not unhappy with how this evening has developed. The night's still young enough that I could blog to my heart's content and still go out and get some new gym pants. =) Hehehe - cute new pants would certainly do wonders for my motivation! But I did begin this entry with some sort of purpose. It's something that's been in the back of my mind lately, but I keep pushing it back there. I'm trying to abide by the policy of "if it ain't broke . . . " And really, nothing's broken. It's just something I think about. I read lots of stories and see lots of examples around me of people who "just knew" as soon as they met their significant other that this person was "the one." I've never been a huge romantic, and I've never really put much stock in love at first sight or the concept of soulmates. But there must be a point at which you have to stand back and say "Am I ever going to want to marry this person?" I do believe, though, that it is a feeling you just get. Like the cliche - "When you're in love, you just know ." Actually, that's an opinion my bf expressed very early on in our relationship. It's kind of hard to put in clear terms . . . but as long as he can't NOT picture being with someone for a very long time, everything's OK. But as soon as he can definitely not see them longterm, there's no point in continuing. And I agree wholeheartedly. The tricky part is when each party has a different picture. It's so very true that it takes two people to make a commitment, but only one to decide that it's over. I have such contrasting examples of marriage around me. There's my parents . . . after 17 years, it ended in a very bitter separation and divorce. In fact, the last 8 or so years were very cold and bitter. I don't even know if I have memories of my parents ever being affectionate with one another. 5 years later, my father met a woman in the States, visited her twice, and proposed on the third visit. They're still married, to my knowledge. I don't even know if I can explain my mum's (now-ended) 5-year relationship after the divorce. I don't see my friends' parents often enough to know how they get along. But mine are the only divorced ones, really. Then there's my aunt and uncle, who still seem to be in the honeymoon phase after 3 years. And my other aunt and uncle, who are neither terribly warm nor cold, but they have weathered a lot together. Come to think of it, I don't think any two marriages are alike. An outsider has no way of knowing what goes on on the inside. So really, all my introspection tonight has only served the purpose of working myself up. =) As long as what C and I have going is working for the both of us, things are OK. Neither of us is thinking marriage, and that works for us right now. No matter what anybody else thinks. When one of us starts thinking about marriage, it'll be something to talk about. But until then, no worries. Maybe somebody else might think it's not right if you don't know if a guy is "the one" within the first week of meeting him. I believe it takes time to truly know someone, a lifetime even. So there's nothing wrong with taking 2 or more years to make that decision. Whew - OK, enough about marriage! =) Darn, it's now past 9pm - no cute new sweats for me tonight! :(

Received in an email today: I had to take my son's hamster to the vet. Here's what happened: Just after dinner one night, my son came up to tell me there was "something wrong" with one of the two hamsters he holds prisoner in his room. "He's just lying there looking sick," he told me. "I'm serious, Dad. Can you help?" I put my best hamster-healer statement on my face and followed him into his bedroom. One of the little rodents was indeed lying on his back, looking stressed. I immediately knew what to do. "Honey," I called, "come look at the hamster!" "Oh, my gosh," my wife diagnosed after a minute. "She's having babies." "What?" my son demanded. "But their names are Bert and Ernie, Mom!" I was equally outraged. "Hey, how can that be? I thought we said we didn't want them to reproduce," I accused my wife. "Well, what do you want me to do, post a sign in their cage?" she inquired. (I actually think she said this sarcastically!) "No, but you were supposed to get two boys!" I reminded her, in my most loving, calm, sweet voice, while gritting my teeth together. "Yeah, Bert and Ernie!" my son agreed. "Well, it's just a little hard to tell on some guys, ya know," she informed me. (Again with the sarcasm, ya think?) By now the rest of the family had gathered to see what was going on. I shrugged, deciding to make the best of it. "Kids, this is going to be a wondrous experience," I announced. "We're about to witness the miracle of birth." "OH, Gross!" they shrieked. "Well, isn't THAT just great! What are we going to do with a litter of tiny little hamster babies?" my wife wanted to know. (I really do think she was being snotty here, too. Don't you?) We peered at the patient. After much struggling, what looked like a tiny foot would appear briefly, vanishing a scant second later. "We don't appear to be making much progress," I noted "It's breech," my wife whispered, horrified. "Do something, Dad!" my son urged. "Okay, okay." Squeamishly, I reached in and grabbed the foot when it next appeared, giving it a ginger tug. It disappeared. I tried several more times with the same results "Should I call 911?" my eldest daughter wanted to know. "Maybe they could talk us through the trauma." (You see a pattern here with the females in my house?) "Let's get Ernie to the vet," I said grimly. We drove to the vet with my son holding the cage in his lap. "Breathe, Ernie, breathe," he urged. "I don't think hamsters do Lamaze," his mother noted to him. (Women can be so cruel to their own young. I mean what she does to me is one thing, but this boy is of her womb, for God's sake.) The vet took Ernie back to the examining room and peered at the little animal through a magnifying glass. "What do you think, Doc, a c-section?" I suggested scientifically. "Oh, very interesting," he murmured. "Mr. and Mrs. Cameron, may I speak to you privately for a moment?" I gulped, nodding for my son to step outside. "Is Ernie going to be okay?" my wife asked. "Oh, perfectly," the vet assured us. "This hamster is not in labor. In fact, that isn't EVER going to happen . . . Ernie is a boy." "What!?" "You see, Ernie is a young male. And occasionally, as they come into maturity, like most male species, they um.... er.... masturbate. Just the way he did, lying on his back." He blushed, glancing at my wife. "Well, you know what I'm saying, Mr. Cameron." We were silent, absorbing this. "So Ernie's just . . . just . . . excited?" my wife offered. "Exactly," the vet replied, relieved that we understood. More silence. Then my vicious, cruel wife started to giggle. And giggle. And then even laugh loudly. "What's so funny?" I demanded, knowing, but not believing that the woman I married would commit the upcoming affront to my flawless manliness. Tears were now running down her face. "It's just . . . that . . . I'm picturing you pulling on its . . . its . . . teeny little . . . " she gasped for more air to bellow in laughter once more. "That's enough," I warned. We thanked the veterinarian and hurriedly bundled the hamsters and our son back into the car. He was glad everything was going to be okay. "I know Ernie's really thankful for what you've done, Dad," he told me. "Oh, you have NO idea," my wife agreed, collapsing into laughter.

More Inane Monday Morning Brain Farts . . . Cold pizza doesn't have anywhere near as many calories as piping hot pizza. Swear! Cuz it's not greasy anymore, see? =) And don't try to tell me otherwise, cuz that's today's lunch. I'm such a little stress puppy. Really, I am. So Much More Than I Thought The more I read and the longer we're with Rascal, the more I realize how involved raising a puppy can be. Don't get me wrong - I'm not about to quit or say I'm in over my head at this point. We're finalizing the adoption tonight, and I don't intend to let this puppy down. But I do, however, need to learn some patience, and remind myself of something very fundamental: Dogs are eager to please, and never do anything out of malice. I - and the bf, for that matter, cuz we're a team in this - need to learn to read his actions and how to teach him things appropriately. I've discovered quite a bit this morning, and something needs to be done soon. The puppy had me scared two nights ago, because he was hacking periodically and his breathing seemed somewhat laboured. The bf assured me he would be fine, but I still did not sleep easily or heavily that night. This morning, he was sounded rather stuffy, like he had a cold. When I brought this up at work this morning, Sue - my source of infinite wisdom - said that he almost positively had the start of kennel cough. I had heard this term before, but didn't know what it was or how it was caused. I'm told it's like asthma to a dog, and it comes from being in a confined space for too long. This makes sense - when we're at work, Rascal is in his kennel, and when we sleep, he's in his kennel. So he's only out for 5-6 hours a day. More on weekends, but still. I feel horrible. So I think I'm going to suggest that we train him to sleep on a blanket or dog bed in the bedroom, instead of inside the kennel. The second thing I learned is that we are definitely not doing the crate-training thing properly. He definitely does not like going into his kennel, and does not go willingly. I was of the opinion that, if we kept putting him in there, he would learn to like it. Well, that's pretty illogical thinking. It wouldn't work with humans: forcing someone to do something they didn't like would definitely not make them like it eventually. I learned that you need to gradually get them used to crawling in on their own, and associate the kennel with good things, like food and treats. So we need to start fresh with the crate training. And third, poor Rascal definitely has separation anxiety. I don't really know if it's mild or severe, but I think it's probably somewhere in between. We need to get him accustomed to seeing us leave for short periods of time, and teach him that we ARE coming back, and that he doesn't need to get anxious everytime we go to leave. And this is likely to take quite a while. Again, more patience on our part. So I'm going to try and talk to my boss today about bringing Rascal in to work with me while we work on this issue. Presuming he doesn't become a big disturbance, of course. He's reasonably well-behaved, especially considering he's a puppy, so I'm hoping it wouldn't take long for him to be calm in this new environment. We'll see if it works . . . I just spoke to my boss and he said he'd get back to me this afternoon on it. His biggest concern - because he's allowed it in the past - is soiled carpets. So I assured him that Rascal's become quite good at letting me know when he needs to go, and I'd look after any accidents. So we'll see if he'll allow it. I'm hoping it'll help. So many changes coming for the poor pup - especially with us moving in a few months. Well, things should stabilize after that, because I can't foresee any more big changes after we move.

A Magic Crystal Ball On one of my numerous blog-stalking excursions I came across this novel suggestion - what if someone could show you your future? Would you want to see it? This got me to thinking - say there was a video floating around out there called "Ang's Life", and it was a complete video, would I want to see that parts I haven't already seen? There are some very good reasons for wanting too . . . avoiding bad decisions, catastrophic events, and the like. Basically you would know in advance where all the bad parts are and you could fix them. But I would have to say that I'd decline. Where's the fun in living when you already know the outcome? What makes life so unique and interesting is not knowing what's going to happen, and part of the fun is thinking that anything can happen. Good or bad. You always hope it's good, but the key ingredient is not knowing. Would you want to see your future if you could?
Hopefully more cheerful posts will come out of the cheerier design.
Well, that's a little more spring/summer-like . . . I might keep tweaking with it, though.
Gotta work on the colours - neon green is just a little bright for me!

I really am a coward. I would love nothing more than to hide in some dark hole and get someone else to fix my problems for me. But I'm supposed to be a big girl, one who can fix her own problems. Even at almost 24, sometimes I really wish I could still go home crying and have someone say that everything will be OK. To 'not worry, I'll take care of it." But I haven't done that in years, and don't intend to start. *sigh* Yes, more on the car. I've made so many phone calls today. I really wanted to get it dealt with. But I called the police one more time, just to double check that I wasn't going to show up and suddenly have the tables turned on me. I'm glad I called ahead of time. It was a different officer/detective (I'm clueless when it comes to titles), and this one told me that it was a civil matter and the police don't get involved. Since I had pretty much planned out how the afternoon would go, it took me a few teary-eyed moments to compose myself. I figured, "Fine - if they won't help me, then it would make sense that they wouldn't help him, either." So I resolved to make definite plans with the guys from work to "repossess" my car. They were more than happy to help me out, but wanted to be sure it wasn't illegal or anything. So just to be on the safe side, I called the police one more time. Don't worry - they booted me off for an emergency call, so don't fret that our boys in blue were tied up with my petty problems. =) I asked if a car shop manager could report a car stolen, or if it had to go through the owner. She hesitated and said, "Well, we prefer to deal with the owner. Why? Are you calling from a car shop?" Me, not having thought this through, said that, "No, I'd be the owner." Obviously she was a little confused and asked what the situation was. I told her - the shop did repairs I didn't authorize, I wanted my car back but they wouldn't release it until I paid them. I said, "It's a civil matter, isn't it? I can't be charged with taking back my own car, can I?" Well, ladies and gentlemen, yes I can. If there are new parts, that's theft. The labour is up for dispute, and he'd have to sue me for that. But if there were any new parts put in the car, I could be charged with theft. That scared me shitless. The last thing I wanted was to be charged when I'm the one getting screwed! So I've spent the better part of the afternoon (at home - I took the afternoon off) mulling over what the hell I could do without breaking any laws. Trying to think of every possible angle to every situation. In the end, I decided I definitely needed some legal advice. Most lawyers offer a free initial consultation, so maybe they could tell me what my options are. I'm waiting to hear back about making an appointment. So now I need to try and sort this all out into clear "problem and solution" terms so that I don't waste the lawyer's time. And I think to make things less complicated, I'm going to have to ignore the fact that I'm trying to sell it. Let's see if I can put it in clear and simple terms: Problem : I feel that the repair shop in question wrongly charged me for repairs that were very likely due to work they did previously on the vehicle. Ideal Solution : The vehicle is released to me with no further charges to me, I get a second opinion (at their expense) that it is in adequate running condition, and I get reimbursed for the unfair charges I've already paid. Compromised Solution : I get my car back at no further expense to me, and the second opinion at their expense. I guess we'll see what happens. I promise I'll try and blog about something different next time. =)

All is right with the world again . . . Well, right enough at least. There's just no denying that I'm not a morning person. I just can't deal with stuff first thing in the morning. It's now 2:41pm, and everything is OK again. My blog actually does seem to be replacing my journal. Often, when things aren't right, all I need to do is vent about it. Then suddenly things don't seem as bad. The only exception being the car, since it's a physical problem I'm actually going to have to deal with. Anyways, I'm going to leave that thought alone, because my day is going alright now. No need to spoil it. It's over 18C outside, and I think we've had our week of spring. Summer's here. *L* That seems to be how weather works here in Calgary: We get 4-5 months of reasonably mild winter, followed by a week of spring, 6-7 months of summer, followed by a week or so of autumn. It won't be long until our weather is strikingly similar to Vancouver's. I brought Rascal by work on my lunch break. It's a good thing that the atmosphere is reasonably lax around here . . . I've started taking 1.5 hour lunches simply because there's really no reason to be rushing back to the office. Despite my best efforts to look like I was walking a dog, he was walking me. That's OK - the exercise definitely wouldn't hurt me. He definitely needs to go to the off-leash park before dinner. Not that I tend that way, but as I was walking Rascal at lunch, a girl drove by, then stopped and backed up. She rolled down her window, and asked "How old?" I was a little taken aback - I'm not used to complete strangers stopping to talk, especially from their cars! So I chatted with her a few minutes. She said he was really cute, and she had a 4-mo-old Rottie at home, just down the street, and maybe they'd meet in the park sometime? Really, people - if it had been a guy in that car, it totally could have been a pick-up. So I'll have to make sure I'm always with the bf when he goes out with Rascal . . . ;) Naw, I'm not really the jealous type of girlfriend (99% of the time, anyways). So all in all, it's not such a bad day after all. I forgot to pick up my gym clothes, so I guess I won't be going to the gym after work, but that's OK with me. I'm sure we'll go for another walk with Rascal tonight, and maybe go see the house again, and it's all good. And all the sun reminds me that I should start looking into tanning again . . . I burn so easily, I need a slight tan from faking and baking just so that I'm not as prone to it when I'm out in the sun. I'm not really all that concerned with the tan itself - I just really don't like burning all the time. Because really, when you're out having fun, sometimes it's hard to stop every hour or so to refresh the sunscreen. Over and out for now!

I'm Going to Make a Horrible Mom Someday . . . I couldn't wait to leave the house this morning. And it's just a puppy. I knew there was a good reason why I always said I didn't want kids. It hasn't been a good Monday so far. And it's only just after 8am. *sigh* The weekend wasn't going so bad by Sunday evening. I think Rascal was getting used to us and we were getting used to him (and his habits). We kept him busy on Sunday, with a big long walk around noon, and then taking him over to Easter dinner at the bf's mom's house. She's got three dogs of her own (all smaller than my cats). He'd met them the day before, so we knew there wouldn't be any real problems. He was a good boy for the most part. By the time we got home after dinner, he was pooped (in the figurative sense). He fell fast asleep by 7pm. Unfortunately, this meant that by the time we went to bed at 10:30, he decided he was awake and wanted to play. He whined and scratched at his kennel door for a good 10 minutes before we wondered if maybe he needed to go outside one more time. BF came back in very unimpressed - it became apparent that he didn't need to go, he just didn't want to go to bed. So we left him to whine himself to sleep. Then, this morning, we didn't think ahead. Our usual habit on weekdays is to set the alarm clock a good 1/2 hour before we really intend to get up. Then we gradually wake after each 'snooze'. Obviously the puppy was not going to follow our lead. So, since the bf had taken him out last, I offered to take him out this morning. I already wasn't too impressed at being up 40 mins before I needed to be. I'm not a morning person. He raced up the stairs, but when I didn't go out with him, he was hesitant. I was in my pjs and shivering, so now there was strike 2 at having to go out on the deck and wait for him to pee. I should have waited longer. But as usual, as soon as he pees, he comes bouncing back to whoever is out with him. So we went back in and I fed him. I'd shut the bedroom door so the bf could get a couple extra minutes in bed. Well, Rascal was extremely restless after eating only a small portion of his food. I thought maybe he was just anxious because the bedroom door was shut, or maybe he wanted to play, but when he disappeared into the computer room (he's only pooped in the bedroom and the computer room, both of which have shag-like carpets) and I could see him in a squatting position, I was devastated. Strike 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 . . . . . not a good start to a Monday morning. So I shooed him outside mid-poop and felt like crying. I swear, it will take weeks after he's finally fully house-trained before I get the smell of puppy poop out of my nose. That is nasty stuff . . . if you've ever smelled the runny green stuff in baby diapers, you can relate! So I cleaned it up, brought him inside and he went straight into his kennel. At this point, the bf and I agree - we really don't care what any articles say about negative reactions. He goes in his kennel after something like that . . . it's almost for our benefit more than his, so we can cool down and then deal with the situation properly, rather than improperly because we're angry and frustrated. Even after he finally did his business outside when I let him out one last time, I just couldn't not muster even a half-hearted "good boy", because I tried to get him to sniff it and he just wasn't listening. I was very glad to leave for work. I just know I would make a horrible mom. I'm too impatient, and I get angry and frustrated far too easily. I'm hoping by lunchtime I've cooled off considerably. It's my job to take him out at lunch to do his business, and preferably for a walk as well. I was also thinking of bringing him by the office for a short visit, but I won't let him in the car before he's done his business, and sometimes that takes a while. On the plus side, we got a few tips from the bf's mom (I really like her *s*). She said that sometimes you can encourage them to go by massaging the little indent between their belly and their back hips. This seemed to work this morning (after the accident) and once last night. So I think we'll keep it up when we take him outside. She said it's what their mothers do to get them to go. So far, I've strongly discouraged the bf from doing things the old-fashioned way - rubbing the dog's nose in the mess. I'd heard/read from numerous sources that this is ineffective and can confuse the dog into associating the negative reaction with pooping in general. At this point, though, I'm willing to try anything. So long as he's not rough with the dog, and still shows him where he IS supposed to go, we'll see if we have better luck with that. I kind of liken it to a spanking . . . so long as it's done properly, perhaps it's what's needed. Wow, I can sure talk up a storm about puppy business . . . but it feels a lot better to have vented!

Puppy Update Well, what would the weekend be without an update on the puppy? =) First off, let me say that no amount of warning from people or reading material can quite prepare you for how much of a lifestyle change a puppy really is. If this is even 1/10 of what it's like to have a baby/kids, I've definitely got some more years of preparation ahead of me! When we first picked him up, immediately we noticed how much he'd grown! Despite being told that his mom was small (about 30lbs), it's obvious there must have been a large papa involved. He's at least 1 or 2 inches taller this week. So we listened to his habits and any advice his foster mom gave us, and had our first decision to make. Should we put him in his kennel for the ride home, or see how he fares when he's left on his own? He started off in the kennel, but whined horribly. So a few blocks later, he was let out. Well, we quickly discovered that it would be much better for all parties if he stayed in his kennel, at least for this ride. We got home, and figured it might be best if he could roam freely and get a feel for the place without introducing the cats. When we finally did let the cats out, it was surprisingly quiet. Stupid was definitely not amused, and made that known. But Tigger was simply curious, not hissing or getting defensive. And Rascal gave them their room - he's obviously learned already that cats aren't creatures you want to aggravate. =) The house training is not going quite so well. After one or two peeing accidents, we've figured out just how much and often puppies pee. So in anticipation, we simply make a conscious effort to take him outside once an hour, and especially just after he's woken up or had a big drink of water. Unfortunately, the pooping is a different story. Anyone with experience and wise words would be most definitely appreciated. He's only pooped twice in the 24 hours we've had him, but both times have been in the bedroom (despite our frequent trips outside and avid attention to any excessive whining). We cleaned and "Febrezed" the area the first time, and his kennel is right there, too, so we're not quite sure how to effectively correct this. One idea we've had if it happens again is to put the mess outside and have him sniff it there. I guess we'll see if it works. So much to learn. So many more stories to come, I'm sure. And probably a few disagreements over how to train for desired behaviour and discourage the bad. It's all a learning experience, huh? =)
