A Rant About Animal Treatment OK, I have this topic on my mind. I have personally boycotted Petland for this reason, but we stopped off at one on Saturday anyways. They've recently incorporated an adoption program in addition to their usual animals for sale. To be honest, the adoptive animals seem to have much better living conditions than the ones you pay big money for. I just don't think it's right. Have you ever seen the little cells these puppies and kittens live in? They're about 3' x 3' x 4', and I may be overestimating. The floors are wire so the animal just voids itself wherever, whenever, and they can slide out the tray below and clean it. Logical and efficient, sure, but hardly humane in my opinion. I saw large-breed puppies that occupied nearly 1/3 of their living space. One particular puppy caught our attention - a Husky/Malamute cross. We inquired about her, only to find that they wanted $688 (for a mixed breed??), and this was considered a discount because she'd already been returned once, and diagnosed by a vet as a possible fear biter. They wanted $700 for an animal that needed extra attention and special training? I would have been more than willing to consider a "special needs" puppy, but not if you want me to pay you $700, and then cough up more to have it fixed. The poor thing is almost guaranteed to become a fear biter, and will probably end up at one of the rescue foundations. It makes me sick. We didn't stay there long, obviously. There should be laws against places like that.

Brain Farts for a Monday This is one thing I've never been able to get used to in my industry . . . the busy/dead cycle. When it's on, there's just no stopping. Being 3-4 weeks behind is usual. At least in most jobs I've had. And when it's off, everything just stops dead in its tracks. In Jan/Feb, I was constantly 3-4 weeks behind, and it bothered me to no end. March saw me catching up reasonably, and work was still steady. Now, halfway through April, things have ground to a halt. I'm caught up, just waiting for some last little bits of data to trickle in so I can officially empty my "ongoing" folder. So my thoughts to turn mundane but potentially crucial tasks. Although it's entirely possible that nothing will happen, I decided it would probably be immensely useful if I outlined my job description. It was felt that, when my predecessor went on mat leave, 5 weeks was almost not long enough to train someone new. They were a little panicked 6 weeks in advance. To be perfectly honest, the first week was valuable, but beyond that, I learned all I needed to know in the weeks just after she left. It's not a complicated job, but there are lots of little things that can make the difference between a satisfied customer who will return and one who is disappointed but never says anything and doesn't return. And there's always lots of little organizational things I can do that will make my (or someone else's) life easier when things do pick up. But I sure hate the slow times, because my mind goes idle and it becomes far to easy to waste time because there doesn't seem to be anything productive to do. So, what on earth could my idle mind be mulling today? Perhaps the house? Perhaps the previously-mentioned post about a puppy? Perhaps the possibility of new employment opportunities? Or perhaps all of the above and many other mundane things? Yup, all of the above. The house comes along quickly . . . I worry on a daily basis if we'll have the amount required by the possession date. I will worry until it's paid. It's just my nature. I joked to the bf the other day that I could win the lottery and I'd still worry about money. Don't really know who I learned that habit from, but oh well. The puppy. THE PUPPY! =) I shall elaborate on this one, since it's mostly all I think about (consciously, anyways). Same as the last few weekends, Saturday afternoon is the designated "dog window-shopping day". We browse the pet stores, particularly Petsmart between 1-3 and the Humane Society. We're looking to adopt a puppy rather than buying. I still cringe when I walk into Petland, but that's another story for another post. We've become quite familiar with the local rescue foundations, the biggest of which being urlLink ARF and urlLink Heaven Can Wait . ARF updates their website almost daily, and is based out of Calgary. They bring a couple of dogs every week to Petsmart on Saturdays to advertise. Their dogs are placed with "foster" homes until they're adopted which, while I think is better than being in rows of cages a la Humane Society, has it's drawbacks. Heaven Can Wait is very similar, and is based out of High River. (If you want an idea of what our potential puppy looks like, he's one of "Eden's pups" on the website). The latter just happened to be at Petsmart this weekend. While we hadn't been greeted with the warmest enthusiasm by the ARF reps in the past, the HCW people were more than helpful and willing to talk to us. We initially expressed interest in a Husky/Sheppard older pup (5 mos), since she was the breed/mix we'd had in mind. The rep gave us great detail, and asked us questions to help identify what kind of animal might suit us best. Unfortunately, due to early malnutrition, this particular dog was delicate and would never live up to the reputation of either breed (Husky or Shep). I just couldn't see my bf being happy with indoor dog that would never be able to run. We needed an active one. The lady advised us that there would be puppies arriving shortly, and perhaps they would suit us better. So we left, thought about it, and returned a short while later. True to her word, there were three Heinz-57 pups toussling with each other when we returned. One had been claimed earlier by a family, and one had potential bone issues, so she offered to let us take the third one for a short walk around the store. That's all it took . . . we were both smitten. Being the wise lady she was, she told us to go home and think about it, and she didn't want to hear from us until at least the next day. We'd be first in line, and no one else could adopt him until we called her back. She explained that if we still wanted to look into adopting him, they would give us a 4-day "trial", and they'd supply everything. If we still wanted him after the four days, then we paid the nominal fee (for surgery, etc) and adopted him. We called her back the next day, and the bf said she sounded really excited to hear from us. We were excited ourselves. *L* We go to pick him up from High River (I love little excursions outside the city) on Friday evening. We spent Sunday doing an extra-good job of cleaning . . . suddenly it seemed like I got "parent eyes" - seeing all the possible choking hazards, and things that could get knocked over by an excited puppy tail (he's got the skinny, whipping Lab tail), and just re-organizing things so there was more play room. There's still a few other little things, like clearing out a space for the kennel in the bedroom, and getting something to cover the backseat of my car. Holy, am I excited. I've never had a dog before. I spent last night browsing for articles on raising a puppy. I think the cats can tell something is up. I hope they all get along. There will definitely be some adjusting, but apparently the puppy has already been exposed to cats, it's just a matter of our cats adjusting to him. =) Sheesh - it never rains but pours, huh? My life can be mind-numbingly dull for months, and then everything happens at once. OK, so there hasn't really been a dull moment for the last couple of years. Will I be able to deal with it when things settle down?
I only have one thing to say (and on my mind) for now . . . Puppy, puppy, puppy, puppy, puuupppppppyyyyy . . . !!! More to come later . . .

I hope her sister hasn't done hers yet, either. =) She didn't want them done on the computer, which is more than fine by me, I just have to get in touch with Biskette again to let her know I'm all for it. Enh, a girl's gotta get her kicks from somewhere, n'est pas?

Dilemmas and Excitement Well, let's start with the excitement, shall we? We took another drive by the house last night, since progress is so rapid these days. They had the first floor walls up, and they were just about to put up the second floor. Went in to the office to sign a sheet acknowledging that the city now knew where all the utilities were going to be (luckily not in our backyard!) . . . sheesh, there's a sheet to sign for everything! Anyways, we got chatting with the sales rep and he was telling us that things were really moving along on our house. Another 3-4 weeks max and they'd be ready for the framing walk-through, at which point they give us a possession date. And the possession date is often 45-60 days in advance. Holy cow! I couldn't believe this was all actually happening. We'd resigned ourselves to a late-Aug/early-Sept possession, and now it's looking like late July. When I say "July", it sounds far away, but put into terms of months - 3 to 3 1/2 - it's soooo close! OK *deep breath* I will try and calm down now. After that, we went and visited with a guy my bf knows from work and his wife. They live just around the corner from our house, which only made me more excited. They're cool people, and they'll be just around the corner! We'll have neighbours we like! *L* On to the dilemma part. Things have slowed down considerably at work, and while I still have a few things to catch up on, I'm not in any huge hurry these days. And so I'm browsing the net a little more. I have a habit of passively checking job postings at other oil & gas companies when I'm bored. And horror of all horrors, I come across what seems like the perfect job - the one I was hunting for when I got laid off last summer. Go for it, you say? I would absolutely love to. But here comes the dilemma part. The company is one we've worked for in the not-so-distant past. And with the house possession coming up, I'm not sure how switching jobs will affect our mortgage status. In the last few years, the almost 9 months I've been at this job has been my longest stint at any one job. I really wanted to be able to stay at one job for a while, but I knew within a few months of starting here that I was going to be itching for more very quickly. Every job has it's ups and downs, it's pros and cons, and this one is no exception. I don't delude myself that another job would be any different, but advancement and learning opportunities are very high on my list of important things for job satisfaction. This one ranks very low on those points. Well, I have until May 3 to make up my mind. This might be a good thing to discuss with the bf, as it would have an impact on him, too. Oh - and did I mention there'd be a salary increase, too? =) Oh my, just too much on my mind today! Guess the best thing to do is distract myself with work until it's time to go home!

I Hate Being Sick I'm such a baby when I'm not feeling good. Thank goodness I have a boyfriend who's totally sweet when I'm sick. =) Ohhh, ohhhh, maybe it's SARS?!! Sheesh, those people drive me up the wall. There's been how many? - 8? - deaths in Canada . . . Canada . . . out of how many people? 25 million? And people are going nuts, acting like it's an epidemic. If my memory serves me, these people all had low immune systems for one reason or another. For other immune-suppressed people, sure, take whatever precautions you think are necessary. For the rest of us - take a chill pill. As for me, I'm pretty sure it's just my usual "sickness". For lack of a better term. It knocks me out enough to not be able to go to work for a day or so, so to me that's stronger than a cold. But I'm rarely attached to the porcelain throne, so it's not really a flu, either. I'm just miserable, often with a sore throat, and complete void of any energy. And a little nauseous. About 50% of the time it ends up being strep throat. But seeing as my GP is out of town and I don't like any of the other doctors at the clinic, I'll tough it out this time. OK, now that you all know my medical history . . . *L* I'm going back to the couch and the TV to veg and be miserable . . .

Isn't it fun to imagine what you'd do with that kind of money? Even $25M split 6 ways is still just over $4M - more than I'd know what to do with! And it would be even sweeter because it's just us women at work that pooled . . . can you imagine the chaos that would be created in a small business where basically all the office staff quit at once? =) That's the best part of the imaginings . . . Did I Do The Right Thing? Instead of contemplating the situation, I should really be preparing, but I need to expunge my thoughts. I got a new job. I thought I'd agreed with my outgoing boss that I'd keep working parttime in the evenings until it picked up. I was sick on Tuesday, and came back on Wednesday to pandemonium. A job ad had been placed without my knowledge or input (I had actually volunteered to do just that the day before), and resumes had already been submitted. It turns out he changed his mind and wanted someone in tout suite so I could train them before I left. So I started looking over them, but didn't see any that really jumped out at me. There were 12 in total: 8 were grossly overqualified people with engineering degrees from foreign countries, 3 were supposedly recent or about to be recent grads from the same program as me, and one wanted a change of pace from his current career in telecommunications or something. So later that day, I ended up going out for coffee with a friend. I knew she was desperate for a new job. Even though I knew my boss wanted someone technically knowledgeable, I did the math: friend who needs job + boss who won't leave me alone until I have replacement = me not having to read resumes, interview strangers, and then train one of said strangers. So I suggested it to my boss this morning. Said if you're really that desperate to have someone in here right away, I have a friend who can be here tomorrow morning. I said - very truthfully - that I could teach her all she needs to know, but that she wouldn't be able to do as much technical stuff as I do right now. It seemed like a win-win situation at the time - friend gets job she thinks is just the bomb, boss gets replacement on short notice. But it leaves me feeling slightly guilty. I know the company would probably do better with someone who had the background knowledge to eventually do more with the position (like I had intended to do), but I also feel like I wasn't left with many choices. I could have taken another 3 weeks or so to see if any really good candidates applied, and then could spend half the time training them. I'm not saying my friend isn't capable - just that she's not familiar with the industry, and there's a lot more I'll need to explain to her so she can do a good job. But no, everything's got to be a huge panic. I know my boss well enough that I should have anticipated this, but I guess I was worrying about other things at the time. So now I'm filled with self-doubt. Despite his assurance that he doesn't, is he going to hold this against me? I don't want to lose another potential reference. Is my friend going to be overwhelmed by what there is to learn? Am I going to make her feel dumb trying to teach her this stuff? Is she going to hold me responsible if this job isn't all she thought it was going to be? Is my boss going to hold me responsible if she decides it's not her thing in 6 months? Am I going to be able to teach her everything in the little time I have? Am I going to make it sound too complicated? Basically, if things don't work out, is either party going to hold me responsible? I think it's a little much that this was all put on me to begin with. Although it was said half-jokingly (my grandpa says all joking is at least 50% true feelings), I was basically told that since I was inconveniencing the company by quitting, the least I could do was find and train my replacement yesterday . I don't know many companies who put this much responsibility on their employees. Heck, I even offered to continue working for a while. But I don't want to be responsible for this indefinitely. I'd like to add that I gave them 2 weeks' notice. Yesterday, one of the field techs up and quit with no notice. Maybe in hindsight I should have done the same. Even though I've given up on church and religion over the last several years, you may find me praying for help to get through the next few weeks gracefully. Because not only am I still going to be stressing over a job I've technically quit, I'm going to be learning new rules and a new job description. And the new company uses the old company for work on occasion, so grace is going to be of utmost importance. I think I need a beer. =)

Conspiracy Theory du Jour I cannot claim credit for this, as my bf is the conspiracy theorist in the house. Has anyone else noticed this "coincidence"?? The Canadian dollar was making unusual (and encouraging) gains about a month ago. Up to nearly $0.75 to the USD after only a couple of weeks, compared to the $0. 65 or less it had been for ages. And then comes along a sole case of MadCow disease in Alberta. And the dollar starts to slide back down. If it hadn't been for that incidence, the Canadian dollar might still be holding strong, if not still making gains. And who was the first to close their borders to Canadian beef imports? Coincidence, I ask? I'll let you think about it.

Don't Give Me That Look Thanks to the great example of a fellow blogger, urlLink Desiree , the impending "swimsuit season", and a host of other reasons, I want to get serious about losing a little weight. Some people I know give me a disgusted look when I say this, so I avoid the subject around them. These same people can recite the WW point-value of almost every single food out there, and it drives me nuts. Other friends understand that it's all relative. Just because someone else may desire to lose 50lbs, or 70lbs, or 100lbs - or perhaps even aspires to the figure I have - doesn't mean I should be looked down on because I would feel better with a leaner frame. I want to do something about it before I wake up one morning and realize I've got 50lbs to lose instead of 20. If only stupid things didn't keep coming up just as I make this resolution . . . *L* That's my biggest problem, it seems. I make a mental resolution to establish some sort of routine, and then something comes along to shake things up. I can make a list as long as my arm of excuses I've used just in the past year. I honestly have the best intentions, I'm just very easily influenced into changing my priorities. What's the saying? "The road to hell is paved with good intentions" . . . It's hard to choose going to the gym over seeing the new house - the gym will still be there in another 2 months, but the house changes every day. I was doing fairly well at going to the gym after work - I'd leave around 4pm, and get there early enough to beat the after-work rush. But now, I'm driving the bf to and from school (so we don't have to pay for parking, and so I can still do bank runs for work), and that's thrown things off as well. And now with the sunburn . . . it's always something. I have personally banned the word "diet" from my vocabulary . . . I admit that I could eat better, and I do try, but I refuse to resort to counting food points or calories. There's paying attention to what goes in your mouth, and then there's obsession. (No offense meant to anyone who abides by Weight-Watchers successfully - it's just my personal opinion.) So the only reliable method of weight-loss (or maintenance) for me is through exercise. So - next week, it's back to the gym for me. The plan is to get my butt off the couch just after dinner, and aim to be at the gym around 7pm. By then, it's died down enough so that I'm not spending half my time waiting for equipment to become available. I can still get home in time to watch my favorite shows, which don't tend to be on until 9 or 10pm. 4 days a week is the goal. I guess we'll see if I can stick to it . . . And kudos to Desiree, who seems to be making excellent progress with her own resolution. Also to urlLink Leah , who goes swimming all the time now (perhaps motivated by the recent appearance of hotties in the pool? *L*), and my other friend Daisy, who's going to yoga classes. You guys rock!

No more of this 'just thinking about it' . . . The Interview The interview went OK on Tuesday. I felt pretty relaxed, thought I did a decent job of answering their questions, got a few of my own answered. But they did a 'behavioural' interview - I'm not a big fan of those. There were three guys interviewing me . . . one did a monotone presentation about the company and read his questions straight from his booklet, another only contributed here and there, and the third guy was the best. Whenever I seemed stumped by one of the questions, he'd clarify what they were really looking for. He seemed to have a much better idea of the true purpose of the interview, and did a very good job of making me feel more at ease. The worst question of the interview? "Have you ever encountered conflict in the workplace? How did you deal with it?" I should have had some stock answer prepared in advance, but I'm too honest sometimes, and it's always getting me into trouble. I opened my mouth before thinking, and then looked like an idiot while I paused trying to figure out how to get out of this one gracefully. There's no such thing with me. See, I've been fired from two jobs in a row now. Not something I'm proud of, and it caused me incredible grief and consternation for some time. The first one was a summer position. At the end, they got to do a review on me, which would be made available to HR. The last two questions - Would you (the supervisors) hire this person back again? and Would you recommend any other department hire them? - and I got a resounding "NO" for both. It didn't come as a huge surprise - we didn't get along from the start, and I've since found out (a good friend still works there) that my supervisor's opinion is definitely the minority. Whatever. And the second time, I admit that my attitude at work stunk, but I was stressed about school, and once that was over, I made a conscious decision to improve. Despite this - and despite my boss admitting that I'd improved - he stated reason after invalid reason that I was a terrible employee that he had to let go. I got the feeling that he was being pressured to fire me by another employee who didn't like me. Guess I'll never know. Anyways, stupid me volunteered "yes" to the question in the interview. Gave very bare and sugar-coated details of the first job. Tried to recover by saying that we got off to a bad start and it never recovered from there, but that I'd learned a valuable lesson from it, and it hadn't happened again. Unfortunately, there seemed to be a few more questions throughout the interview about interpersonal conflict and its resolution . . . I mean, really. How honest do you think someone's going to be in an interview? "How would you deal with someone who was being difficult?" Well, depending on how important that working relationship is, and how closely you work together, and how difficult they're being . . . there's an infinite number of responses. Overall, I think I did pretty well, but you never really know until you get that last phone call. Either they thought you were the best candidate, or they feel someone else is. I'll find out next week. More Job Possibilities In the meantime, a friend/mentor with a really big oil & gas company alerted me to another opportunity. Now I'm torn. I gave her my resume and she's going to recommend me for the position (as it was only advertised internally) . . . but the competition doesn't close until June 6. I'm trying not to think about it until it's actually an issue. Although I have been trying to weigh the pros and cons. Current job: - Very flexible work hours. This weighs very heavily at the moment . . . I like the freedom of being able to come and go when there's nothing to do, and not having to worry about someone getting on my back about it. The emphasis is on getting a job done, not on clocking X hours a day - Very close to home - No opportunity for advancement - what I'm doing now is all I'll ever be doing - Very relaxed dress code, I can wear jeans and a T-shirt every day if I want - Blatantly corrupt environment, with lots of disgruntled employees and lots of grumbling that goes on when the boss is away (very often). I don't want to be sucked in by that First job opportunity: - New position in a small company - I would be creating my own job description, to an extent - Lots of opportunity to learn from people, room for advancement for at least a good few years - More of a career than a job, current position is more of a job - Downtown - I miss the atmosphere, and going for lunch with friends who work in the area - Possibly a 'clock-punching' mentality - I didn't get a good enough read from the interview to determine if this is the case or not - More strict dress code, but that doesn't bother me too much - Evil word - commute. It will probably involve public transit in some capacity, and definitely an earlier rise in the morning Second job opportunity: - Not even really an opportunity at this point - haven't even been selected for an interview - Big company - many more future opportunities for lateral or upward advancement - Big company - tendency to 'get lost in the crowd' and become anonymous (this is good and bad depending on the situation) - Big company - potential for bigger salary?? not sure about this one yet - Downtown again - same pros and cons as above There's a lot to think about, but as I said, it may not even be an issue if Opportunity #1 offers the job to someone else.

OK, I'll try this again. My day went from ho-hum and dreary to hopeful and exciting with one solitary phone call. Remember my ongoing quest for a new job? Well, a career is more accurate. And remember how I applied for one specific position a couple of weeks back? Well, it had been a week since I faxed in my marks, so I figured it was fair enough for me to call in to inquire about the status of the position. Has it been filled? Great - I can keep looking. Still deciding? Great - I know to keep waiting. I called up, and the HR director exclaimed, "Ohhh, Angela! I'm so glad to hear from you. I was actually going to call you later today to see if you could come in for an interview." Right on! This makes me very hopeful. In the past, every interview I've had (with the exception of one) resulted in a job offer. I'm not saying that's how it will go this time, I'm just saying that's how it's been for me in the past. I got first pick of interview slots - there were 6. So I picked first thing on the first morning. Tuesday at 8am (the choices were 8am or 10am, Tues/Wed/Thurs). Trust is Important It's kind of funny . . . I look around at some of the relationships I see on a regular basis, and I'm often left shaking my head and thinking to myself, "Thank goodness we're/I'm/he's not like that." I had another example this weekend. I'll share it, since I'm pretty sure none of you personally know the people involved and won't make the situation worse. =) I went to my bf's mom's place for dinner. It felt weird that she was making dinner for us , but the bf assured me it was what she wanted. So we picked up some wine and a card and headed over. The bf's brother was going to be there, too, with his wife (they just got married in January). We were kept pretty busy making sure Rascal wasn't trampling his mom's 3 very tiny dogs/puppies, so I wasn't very aware of what was going on until a little later. But shortly after his brother arrived with his wife, I noticed that his mom came out into the backyard and was brushing away tears. It didn't take me long to figure out that there was news of a baby on the way. But the wife seemed rather reluctant to talk about it. I would have thought a newly-married couple (especially the wife) announcing a pregnancy would be all giddy. Turns out it wasn't confirmed by a doctor yet, and the husband had spilled the beans before she'd wanted to. She wasn't planning on telling her own mother until she'd been to the doctor's. I felt kinda bad for her. I also felt the smallest twinge of jealousy, but we'll gloss over that, because it's doesn't relate to my point. =) When we got home later, I comment to the bf, "I'm so glad I know you would never do something like that." I just couldn't marry someone that I didn't trust to keep my secrets, or at least respect my wishes to keep certain news quiet until it was appropriate. I'm still not ready for marriage, but every day, it occurs to me that my current bf has a lot of the qualities I would want from a husband. He's a wonderful man - albeit with the requisite annoyances, but ones I can live with - and sometimes I feel guilty for not always telling him so. Then again, that's another thing I love about him - he's not mushy. Neither am I, so I don't feel pressured to be mushy. It works for us. But it's still nice to find ways to tell each other how much we appreciate the other. Hmmm, I wonder if all these musings have something to do with an anniversary (2 years! *s*) coming up . . .

Requisite 'Survivor' Commentary Is it just me, or were there too many good shows on last night? With Survivor taking up 3 hours from 9pm onward, there was much channel-flipping going on at my place . . . There was the Simpsons, Survivor, and Law & Order: CI all at 9pm. Then the Sopranos and Survivor at 10pm. It's amazing I still managed to know what was going on . . . How on earth did Jenna - as Jeff put it himself, the 'whiney, 21-year-old swimsuit model' - manage to win the $1M?? And I was getting a little queasy watching her hang off Matt when they did the show from NYC. What was up with that? Anyone hear any rumours about them hooking up or something? When they were headed back to camp on the last night, I blurted out "Come on - have sex! It's the last night and there's just the two of you . . . " But did they listen to me?? Noooooo, of course not. That would have been entertaining . . . I'm always rooting for people to have sex on those reality TV shows . . . =) What can I say? I think we all have a bit of a voyeur in us . . . Grrrr. Whiney, lazy, self-centered Jenna won. Going by the game's motto - Outwit, Outlast, Outplay - Rob was the one who deserved that. But, seeing as he didn't make it to the final 2, it should have been Matt. He was honest . . . he said so himself, how he was naive in the beginning, and did lie to a few people along the way, but he was a strong player when it came to challenges. He contributed lots to the upkeep of the camp. That fire sure was a nice twist, wasn't it? I didn't feel too bad for them when that happened . . . I just couldn't believe it hadn't happened sooner. Why the heck would you leave a fire burning - under a wooden 'fire hut' no less! - unattended for a good couple of hours?? Why?? And then to have Jenna snivel over all the irreplaceable items she lost . . . why the heck would you bring those out to the wilderness in the first place? Serves you right . . . Boy, I'm just so compassionate, aren't I? =) OK - and now a rambling commentary on the appearance of some of the survivors. Heidi was scary when she filed out for her first jury session. Boy, oh boy. Tone down the lipstick, hun! I swear she looked like she was wearing a Halloween mask . . . Matt looked much better during Survivor than post-Survivor. I liked the goatee and sunken cheeks and protruding eyes . . . I quite enjoyed that slightly-off-kilter-sharpening-my-machete look of his . . . =) His full cheeks and clean-shaven look post-Amazon just didn't do it for me. By contrast, Rob looked much better in the aftermath. If it weren't for his whiney "poor-ugly-geeky-me-who-the-girls-never-want-to-date" attitude, he'd probably have no need for that attitude. I imagine he's had quite a few post-show groupies to raise his . . . errr . . . self-esteem. OK, this is going back a bit, but did anyone notice that Christy was the only one with a boyfriend who showed up for the 'loved-ones' reward? I thought that was hilarious . . . here are these young girls, always going on about how they're so much better and prettier and sexier than everyone else, and they don't even have boyfriends who'll fly to the Amazon to see them? I was pleased to notice the slightly smug (and definitely elated) look on Christy's face that day . . . OK, I think I'm done for now. Feel free to comment and leave your own two cents.

Something's bugging me, and I just don't know what. Despite all the great things going on in my life, I've been in a funk the last week or so, and I don't know how to shake it because I don't know what's causing it. I used to be hyper-analytical about anything and everything going on in my life, but it made me a constant emotional wreck, so I learned to stop. Maybe I went too far the other way. I'm sure the boredom isn't helping. But that can't be the only reason, can it? When I was in my post-secondary days, I got this ailment I dubbed "the 2-month itch." It never failed that, 2 months into a new semester, or a summer of working, I would get this incredible sense of restlessness, like I was going to crawl out of my skin and needed to completely overhaul my life. I would usually manage to create some kind of drama or crisis, and if I was in school, it would mess up my entire semester. My marks would take a nose-dive, I would start skipping classes all the time, and often missing homework deadlines. If it was the summer (or in my year off), I started slacking off at work and got a really bad attitude. I think it's under control now, but I definitely get it from my mother. Not that I would ever tell her to her face, because she's my mother after all and I love her, but she can be one heck of a drama queen. There's always something traumatic going on in her mind - be it problems with co-workers, problems with divorce settlement issues (sadly, still), behaviour problems with my youngest brother, or some sort of illness. Still - could this be my problem? A x-month itch? I feel disconnected . . . like I'm aware of all these things going on, and I know I should be happy and excited and grateful, but I just don't feel anything. Except maybe guilt. I feel guilt a lot because I've been rather fed up with the dog lately. I know, in my head, that lots of the things he does is just part of him being a puppy. But the whining gets to me, having to wash my sole pair of jeans every other day because he's always jumping up with muddy paws gets to me, the constant no-rascals, down-rascals, off-rascals get to me. And I feel guilty. Although I never enjoyed being alone much, maybe I miss having the option of retreating to my own apartment every once and a while. But I don't feel stifled or anything. Maybe I'm jealous of my friends who still don't have to worry about rent, or utilities, or paying back student loans that cost as much as a new car, and who can plan impromtu weekend trips and still have the energy and motivation to party at a moments' notice. But that was never really me in the first place, so I don't think that's right, either. Or maybe I'm just a girl who's prone to mood swings for no reason every now and then. Yeah, I think I can live with that. It doesn't require any work on my part. *L*

Something has occurred to me lately, and if I still have any readers left, I'd like to know what you think, too. It seems that a lot of people I know have this common opinion - that things in life that are commonly considered "good" should never involve negative emotions. Let me give you an example . . . I was sharing with some people a story - in the short week-and-a-bit that our upstairs neighbours have been home, I've spoken with each at least once. You know, "How's it going with the new baby?" Both their reactions have been a big sigh, and then something along the lines of "there have been a few rough nights" usually followed by "but when it's good, it's good." Their reaction didn't surprise me, but the people I was relaying the story to seemed almost shocked. It was like they thought that people shouldn't have negative emotions or things to say about something as wonderful as a new baby. They figured the sigh must have had more to do with my question (and the fact that they probably get asked it all the time) than an actual response. And another example - my new job. I've shared with some people the fact that I'm not overjoyed by it, even though I was looking forward to it so much. But I always add that I knew that I would miss certain things about my old job. I knew I had to trade certain things for other things I wanted more. But it seemed like they were trying to tell me that I shouldn't be having (or at least expressing) these negative things because it was something I was looking forward to. I just don't agree. Even the good things in life are going to have ups and downs, and shouldn't we feel free to express both sides with our friends? I thought nothing of it when our neighbours openly expressed their exhaustion (with the new baby). And I hardly even know them. Maybe the whole matter boils down to learning which people you only deliver the sugar-coated and superficial good news to, and which people you can talk with frankly and openly to. In case you couldn't tell, I'm lacking the "frank and open" types lately. =)

It's Everywhere, I Tell You Egad, I'm starting to regret having offered continuing support for my old job. Last night was the first night I had to go in, and I only stopped between jobs long enough to eat some dinner. And I didn't get home until 9:30pm. And boy was I grouchy . . . oh well, I don't think I'll have to do it too many times. But that's not really the point of this whole post. Babies are everywhere all of a sudden. We share the house with another couple who lives upstairs (separate suites, of course), and the wife/girlfriend has been pregnant since they moved in in November. We found out this month that she was due June 22, and yesterday afternoon they'd left for the hospital. We finally saw their car pull up late last night. I spent half the night in a light sleep, woken up at the slightest sound. And of course, I would then strain to find out if it was a baby crying (as we couldn't tell if it was just the husband/bf that came home, or the whole little family). And I spent the other half of the night dreaming about how clueless I would be if I got sent home from the hospital with a baby to care for. I have this intense curiosity when it comes to babies lately. I haven't really been around babies since my youngest brother was born, and I was 6 at the time. So now I'm seeing babies and pregnant women everywhere I go. I told you I'd be prone to this baby-fever thing. I still maintain that I'm not going to have one of my own yet.

Big Changes I was going to post about this earlier, but then didn't want to be guilty of spilling the beans too early. On Friday, the bf went out golfing with a couple of his friends. He came home with a big announcement - a good friend of his was going to be a daddy. This came as shocking news, even though I should have expected it. They've been married 4 years now (even though they're only 24), and they're perfect potential parents in that they're not big partiers and don't mind staying at home lots. We have another couple who are very similar to them, and I'm willing to bet that they make the same announcement within 6 months. That's just the way these two couples are - a tad on the competitive side. (Just as an example, the last time us three couples got together, the youngest guy of the bunch - 2 years younger than the other two - proceeded to talk down to and give advice to my bf regarding owning a house, seeing as we'll be the last to take possession of ours. He preached about how we didn't realize just how many things would need to be done in the first few months, and how we were going to need more money than we thought. Etc. Etc. Read: I'm older and wiser about this stuff because we're 6 months ahead of you. He even proceeded to brag that by the end of the year, he and his wife would have made more money than us. Needless to say, this didn't go over very well.) So I'm very glad that we've started to make non-baby-planning couple friends. I have nothing against people who want families - it's just not where we're at (heck, we're not even married, so I would hope so!). And as much as everyone says "It's your choice to do what you want" . . . if you're spending most of your free time with people who talk about babies and nothing else, you start to wonder if you're missing out on something. And I could see myself starting to get baby fever even though I know it's not what I want right now. You know? =) I'm still digesting the news . . . this is the first time I've been close friends with someone who got pregnant (and especially, deliberately). I always knew it would come, and should have expected it, since the wife just recently finished her schooling. But it's still big news to me, and I'm having a hard time imagining how things are going to change over the next year. I certainly don't plan to stop hanging out with them completely, because they're still good friends. But I don't want to catch baby fever, either. House Countdown: 2 weeks and 4 days! Baby Due Date: January 28, 2004

Day Four I don't think I've ever made such a big deal about a job change before. Dunno why this one is different. Anyways, I think I'm beginning to see the seeds of settling in. Yesterday, I just about broke down in tears at work, I was so frustrated. I was still running around in circles, and it seemed like everytime I would try to ask someone for clarification, they were either busy or not in their office. Finally, shortly after lunch, one guy did pop by and I made him sit down and explain things some more. I seem to work that way - I need things explained once (preferably the 'big picture' first, then the smaller details of what I'm actually supposed to do), then go away and let me see if I've got it. I often need two or three rounds of explanation/let-me-do-it-myself cycles before something clicks, and then I'm off and running. I think yesterday afternoon was the clicking point. Now all my questions are just about the smaller details, and I'm sure I'll have those for weeks to come. Now all I need to do is personalize my office a little more, and perhaps things won't seem so bad. Plus, I'm trying to figure out how I can fit the word "active" into my lifestyle now. By the time I get home, it's often 6pm or later (depending on what errands we have to run), and then there's dinner, and little household things, and a little vegetating, and a shower, and before you know it, it's past 10pm and I'm ready for bed. So, after a few days of being turned down by someone I thought would be a regular lunching buddy, I've decided that maybe lunchtime would be a good time to do something. Maybe I'll become one of those "lunchtime park bunnies" - one of those women who head out to Prince's Island and the Bow River pathway for a run at lunch. And I intend to hold Biskette to her word . . . she said that shortly after she started getting paycheques from her new job, she'd buy a bunch of passes to the City pools, and I would have to make sure she used them. No arguments there. I would love to go swimming once or twice a week, but motivation is lacking lately. Having someone to go with would definitely help. And has anyone else discovered that when they make a personal resolution to eat better, all the "forbidden" or "bad" foods start to smell twice as appealing? After discovering that it's fruit season, and almost everything is on sale and finally affordable, I stocked up last night. The idea being that I would start taking lots of fruit to work with me and try to avoid all the tempting treats and dining options, if only for lunchtime. I had visited Jugo Juice yesterday, and decided I would go back today. I'd heard that their smoothies were basically meal equivalents, and that a 1oz shot of their "wheatgrass juice" was the same as taking in 2.5lbs of leafy green vegetables. I figured, heck, if I can get that many veggies in a 1oz shot, it was worth a try. It's actually not all that bad. A little bitter and grassy (obviously), a little sweet, and all over in one small gulp. The jury's still out on the smoothie and it's staying power. I'll get back to you on that. But the whole point of that way to say that, on my way to Jugo Juice today, I had to pass a chinese buffet restaurant. And oh man, did the smells wafting out to the sidewalk ever tempt me. So yeah, the world's not quite so dark and weepy today.

I Feel Like Crying But crying isn't something I really do very often, so I'll write instead. I'm very sad tonight. Well, I started getting sad on Friday, but it's been getting worse. I'm starting to wonder if I made the right decision in leaving my old job when I did. On Friday, we (meaning all my co-workers, plus Biskette) went out for lunch at noon. We never made it back to work. By the time I got home just after 7pm, I was completely plastered, and had a rather rough night ahead of me. But you know how drunk people get - they say too much. Two of the guys are Russian, one older and one younger, and the younger one was drinking up a storm. He started gesturing wildly as he talked just as animatedly - I think he might have had a little crush on me. Poor Biskette - he put her through the wringer! She was the only one not drinking, so even though nobody else was taking him seriously, she was. I kept trying to convince her not to pay him any attention. Anyways. I really enjoyed myself. And even then, I started missing them, and wondering if I was doing the right thing at the right time. It had seemed right when I applied for the job . . . it still seemed right when they wanted me for an interview . . . but when the job offer came, I hesitated. Of course, I eventually accepted, but I wonder if there wasn't something in my gut that told me the timing just wasn't right. I know in my head that I'm just upset because it's a new job, and it'll take time to get used to. I know there are lots of good things, and things I've been wanting for a long time, in this new job, and that it will open lots of doors for me. But for now, I'm just missing what I had. My old co-workers will be spending most of this week at the Oil & Gas Show, meeting tonnes of people, not having to do stressful work, and probably drinking. I had that ultimate position of actually understanding what my job was about, of having insight into what would make it more efficient, and by the time I left, almost felt like an expert in what I did. Of course, I knew there was plenty I could learn, but for my job, I was in a very comfortable position. And it was the first job that I never felt a sense of dread about going to work. I had enormous personal freedom, and knew exactly how far I could bend that freedom. With it being summer now, and with moving in just over 3 weeks, it would have been very nice to have had that freedom for the whole summer. *sigh* And I don't think it's been helping that sleep is hard to come by. Sunday night, of course, was pre-first-day-of-work jitters. Didn't sleep very well. Last night, it was the dog being sick. He was quite for the first couple of hours, but then he started whining, and the whining got more insistent, until the bf decided maybe he really needed to pee. So he took him out. Came back in, but the whining continued for another while. We figured that maybe he was just playing a game and tried to ignore it. And then it stopped abruptly, and a horrible stench filled the room. The bf urgently told me to turn on my bedside lamp, but we both knew what had happened - Rascal had pooped in his kennel. My mind told me, "He wouldn't poop in his own kennel just for the heck of it. There's gotta be something wrong." But the rest of me was pretty darn pissed off that this had to happen at 2am. There was no avoiding it - we were both gagging, the stench was so bad. The dog got put outside while we cleaned it out and tried to air the place out. About half an hour later, it's clean, and we decide maybe the kennel shouldn't be in the room, since it was doubtful that he would be quiet again. After about an hour of trying a few things (bf thought maybe he was really hungry, or something), we finally decided to ignore the whining, and managed another hour of fitful sleep. I think he must have quieted down at some point, but again around 5am, it suddenly started up again, and had a rather urgent tone to it. Resigned, we both got up to find he'd done it again - and extremely runny this time. By now I was pretty concerned (though pissed off with sleep deprivation), and started worrying about what we were going to do with him. Was I going to have to call in sick on my second day on the job to take him to the vet? Bf assured me that it wasn't that serious yet, but we still had to figure out what to do with him during the day. Obviously he didn't have complete control of his body, and the earliest someone could be home was 3:30pm. So we rigged somewhat of a doghouse using the shed and left him in the backyard. He seems OK now, but we haven't fed him yet tonight and don't plan to. I guess - just like with humans - there's a wide variety of reasons a dog might get diarrhea, so unless it's persistent, or he seems lethargic and in pain, there's really not much for us to do. I think I read today that we could give him immodium or pepto, but I only use that on myself in the direst of circumstances. Is this all just part-n-parcel of having a puppy? Anyways, I think I want a shower and an early night. In the hopes that maybe tomorrow I won't feel like crying again.
What is up with you, blogger? I can't load anybody's page today! =(

Update on Conspiracy Theory I offer one more piece of evidence to back up this theory - urlLink More than 1500 head of cattle have been destroyed . . . To date, all test results have been negative." And they'll continue to slaughter more, but they'll never discover the origin of this lone diseased animal. Why? Because you can't find the origin of an animal that's been planted!! Duh, people.

The Lighter Side of Things On the brighter side . . . we signed our mortgage papers yesterday evening. Some scary numbers, I tell ya. We only have a 3 year term, and yet we'll be paying about $32K into it, but nearly $22K of that is strictly interest. Our principal will only go down by about $10K. Then again, over 3 years, we'd probably end up paying over $30K in rent, and NONE of that would be equity. And we'll be in the house for nearly 2 months before we have to make a mortgage payment. So I'm happy. =) 4 weeks and one day til we move now. Not long at all. And Monday marks the start of my career as I would have liked it to start a year ago. Better late than never, I believe. =) I'm getting excited about it now. I'm looking forward to hopefully challenging my brain a little more. And perfect timing, too - summer has got to be the best time of year to be downtown. Lunchtime walks, people everywhere, and so many shops . . . I can't wait! Rascal gave us a bit of a scare today. We came back from looking at the house to find our upstairs neighbour outside with our puppy wrapped in a blanket. It turns out she'd heard a horrible sound from the yard like he was being tortured. She raced out to find her dog on one end of the pen (it's a good 15m long, if not 20m), and Rascal on the other. They've played together on numerous occasions without incident. And Rascal was bleeding profusely from his nose. But like a nosebleed, not like he'd been bitten or anything. He had a lump on the side of his nose, but no punctures. He seems OK now, and the bump has gone down somewhat. But I guess we'll never know what happened. We think maybe he got bitten by a bug, and in his surprise, perhaps hit is nose hard on the fence or side of the house. Or maybe in tousling, he whacked it. I hope it was nothing serious. It's very scary to come home to find blood all over the back yard and your upstairs neighbour! I'm so very grateful that she was around.

Wow, the response to that post was better than I thought. It's just something I've been thinking about lately. I've been thinking a lot about relationships - not necessarily romantic ones, but in general. Perhaps the majority of my problems lie in my naivete - it makes me awfully vulnerable to disappointment. I won't divulge the specific one that's been nagging at me lately, but I actually had another example of it today. I thought I was on pretty friendly terms with most of the women I work with. OK, at least one doesn't fit into that category, but the rest seemed pretty OK with me. I talked with them about my pet woes when the puppy first arrived, my excitement over the new house, and most recently my new job. I've written about the stress I felt over leaving my current position, and how I felt I did the best I could given the circumstances. By the way, Biskette is doing awesome, and I think she'll do just fine. But apparently there's been some unrest among the 'harem' at work. She still hasn't been given a firm 'yes, this position is yours', and I've gotten uneasy vibes from my supervisor. It turns out a few of the women have complained to the general manager over how much she's getting paid and the fact that she doesn't have a technical diploma. And the fact that they feel she 'got in through the back door'. For one, almost the entire parent company is comprised of people who are related to the owners/managers, or know someone related to them. And maybe half of them are actually capable of the jobs they've been given. Second, my friend doesn't even have an offer of employment yet, much less an established salary. The woman before me had no related education, or even post-secondary education to speak of, and she was making more than even I am now. The position was advertised at $1000/mo less than this, and I had just assumed that's what they might give her. I suppose I shouldn't have been surprised that things could get that petty - half-jokingly, we (as in, us women) were constantly griping about ineptitude around the office and complaining about others behind their backs. Disappointment is what I felt when I heard this. It makes me wonder what was/is probably being said about me when I'm not around. I think I need to learn to shut my mouth a little more often, and not get so friendly with the people I work with. How many times have I learned this lesson, and it never sticks?? I hope I can remember it this time around with the new job. I made an actual good friend at one job, and they fire me over it. I only think I have friends at another job, and it still gets me in trouble. I keep to myself, try to keep things professional instead of personal, and I'm perceived as a snob - cold, too good to associate with my co-workers. There doesn't seem to be a middle ground. Anyways.

Third Time? Time To Give Up! Ever the optimist . . . It's time to give up on the idea of having a new washer and dryer set, at least for another year. Yes, I thought I'd decided that we were going to take the less stressful road of buying a used set, but then we had to fill some time last night while the clothes were drying at the laundromat, and we still hadn't made any progress in the used direction, so I figured we'd make one last attempt at the "new" route. First stop - The Brick. Slightly overpriced, so we left pretty quickly. Next stop - Leon's. We found the same model $100 cheaper than the Brick, so figured 'what the heck, might as well see if we can qualify'. Filled out the application, and the guy even came back and started asking us which payment plan we wanted, when we wanted delivery . . . so I thought that meant it was in the bag. I was so relieved and excited . . . and then, as he was looking up delivery availability, he got paged, and the news wasn't good. Same story as before - it's not that you have bad credit, it's that you have too much, and even if you don't owe anything, credit companies still see a $1000 or $3000 card as being $1000 or $3000 of debt, because you can still use it, blahblahblahblahblah . . . We left extremely disappointed and resigned that this was just not meant to be. So, it looks like I'm in for at least another week or two of laundromat trips. It's really not all that bad, except for feeling guilty about having to leave the dog alone for yet another 2 hours.

"Hindsight is 20/20" I've had a lot of this lately. Looking back on things - some that are reversible (to an extent) and other that aren't - and realizing that there was a better path. For one, getting a puppy . . . at the time, I thought it would be best to wait until we were in the house, and settled into that change. But I got caught up in the excitement, and it drown out my rational self. Unfortunately, this is one of the somewhat reversible things. Two, changing jobs before we moved. This was just one of those 'deal with it' things, and it's just how things worked out, but it probably would have been a lot less stressful if I'd stuck with my old job for a little longer. Three, buying a house as soon as we did. My bf and I were actually talking about this just last night. It's rather uncanny how we often have the same thoughts, but don't realize it until one of us voices it. But he mentioned that we might be better off right now if we'd simply rented a bigger place for 6 mos-1 year and paid off all our debt, and then gone for the house. It was uncanny, because I'd been thinking the same thing earlier in the day. But that's just one of those things you chalk up to a learning experience, and deal with it. Four, holding out for $3300 for my stupid car when a guy was willing to pay me $3000 for it. I have to not think of this one much, because it's one of those things that makes me want to kick my own ass for being so optimistic (really, greedy might be a better word). If only I'd known what I was in for . . . OK, so now this is degrading into a list of regrets, which wasn't the purpose when I started. Because those first three, I don't regret. It's just that things might be different (easier?) right now if I'd/we'd chosen differently. But things happen the way they happen for a reason, and I've always maintained that they happen for an ultimate good. I'm having trouble applying that one to the puppy situation, but sometimes it takes a while for the good to become apparent.

Sad Days I wasn't even sure I wanted to post about this, because people I know in the flesh read my blog and I'm not sure I want to feel judged. But people would find out eventually, anyways. We've had to make a tough decision. Things aren't improving with Rascal, and it's getting to the point that we're worried he'll grow into a disobedient dog if we keep him much longer. He's not a bad dog, but he definitely needs more attention and more training than we can offer him. And the situation isn't likely to change anytime in the near future. I don't believe that Rascal is happy, and I don't think we are, either. So today I have to make the awful phone call to the rescue agency we got him from, and admit that we failed. We made a decision that we ultimately couldn't commit to, and it feels awful. The part I'm dreading most? The looks and comments we're likely to get from our friends when they find out. My bf thinks that they'll be too pre-occupied with their pregnancies, and that one couple will have to get rid of their own dog, but I'm not so sure. I've been on the receiving end of one or two cutting remarks before, after I gave one of my cats back to my ex . . . as in "you shouldn't be allowed to get a kitten, because you already gave up one of your cats" . . . And I'm worried that we'll be black-listed for years at the agency. *sigh* Guess we'll be cat people for at least the next couple of years.

That Evil Green-Eyed Monster What is it, exactly, that causes us to be irrationally jealous? Even when our logical selves tell us there shouldn't be any reason for it? I don't think I'm a jealous person for the most part. I may get mildly insecure in some situations, but nothing severe enough that I'd call it jealousy. But there's one person who causes this irrational jealous in me, and it bothers me. It's the younger sister (not quite 18 yet) of a girl my bf dated 'way-back-when'. Now, I've met and hung out with this ex (and he's got lots of them from his younger years, but not serious exes), and I quite like her. She's a nice girl, easy to get along with, and I have no beef with her. I mean really - if I got insecure at every ex he's had, this relationship wouldn't have lasted more than a couple of weeks. But her sister is a different story. The first time I met her, she was just barely 16, and it was a backyard BBQ that my bf was hosting. She rubbed me the wrong way from the moment she arrived. She was a whiney attention-seeker, and spent the night playing games with my bf and another guy who was there. Plus, she was drinking, which I'm sure only made it worse. She'd disappear into the house (while everyone else was outside around the fire), my bf and J would go off in search of her, and she'd put up this dramatic scene/adolescent tantrum as they carried her back up to 'join the party.' Now, in my bf's defense, he'd promised her older sister that he'd watch out for her and make sure she had a good time. And he'd been drinking - deep down he's a sweet and caring man, but he puts on a tough macho act most of the time, but when he's been drinking, this softer side sometimes comes out. So he thought he was just trying to make sure she had a good time. Those of us who were a little more sober and detached from the situation saw differently. She thought it was a game. Well, fine, whatever - I felt neglected by him, mentioned it, and he said to be more forward if I was feeling left out, and to walk over and tell him so. Unfortunately, that's not exactly my style, so I stewed most of the night. As the night wore on, the party split up between the upstairs (this was when we had close friends living upstairs) and downstairs . . . I went upstairs to visit for a while, as I wasn't interested in the movie being watched downstairs. When I finally did go down, what I saw wasn't entirely suspicious, but I lost it. They were sharing the love seat, she had her feet on his lap, and they were both under a sleeping bag. My logical self said "Hey, she's like a little sister or something, there's nothing to get riled about here." But I still lost it. This was about a year and a half ago. More recently, she was one of the few people who showed up the day after we moved in to the house. At first, it just never dawned on me . . . I knew who the older sister was, I knew she'd brought her younger sister with her, but my mind never connected it to the previous incident. Lucky for both of us, I guess. Even so, the moment I saw her, I got this irritated feeling that I couldn't pinpoint. But I forced myself to be sociable, and we all went out to a pub for a couple of drinks, and she only irritated me more. I just chalked it down to her age (not yet 18) and mentality (high school). It wasn't until about the last half hour that we were hanging out that I clued in . . . And then the other night, we were just about to go to bed, so I was standing beside the computer chair as my bf sent an email. I wasn't even focussing on the screen, really, because I don't feel a need to be nosy or anything. But then he somewhat awkwardly says, "That's so-and-so." (the younger sister) "Huh?" So I look at the email address - "superhotsexychick" or some such thing - and I can understand why he might have felt compelled to tell me who it was. And I was hit by that jealousy again. And once again, it bothered me. Because I can't think of any good reason that this should bother me. It hasn't crossed my mind that he's cheating on me, because I know he's not. Especially not with someone so young. But I think I'm bothered because I have no idea what her intentions are. And she irritates the hell out of me, and she has a way of commanding his attention when she's around, and I feel belittled by it. I've tried to put myself in his shoes, or liken it to a reversed situation, but it's not working. All I can think is, "Thank God we don't see much of her." Has anyone else who's normally not a jealous person had one person in particular who inspires an irrational bout of jealousy in them?

It's Gone!!! It's Gone!!!! This has been a most excellent weekend, for several reasons, but one very ginormous one - THE DODGE HAS BEEN SOLD! That frickin' malignant tumour that has been plaguing me for nearly 9 months now, is finally gone. I hope it was the auction house owner that bought it. I got a bid 4 weeks ago (first weekend it was there) for $200. He tried to convince me that the most I could expect for it was $300-$400. I said I'd stick with my reserve at the time ($1500), figuring at the very least, I could sell it for parts for more than $200. Then, last week I finally dropped the reserve to $1000, and got a call this Saturday, saying there was a bid of $700 on it. I was ecstatic, but asked if they'd take $800 - I had decided that was the lowest I wanted to go - but gave him strict instructions to call me back (I wouldn't lose a sale over $100). Not 5 mins later, he called back and said they'd take it. I hung up and screamed. Scared my bf, since he was driving at the time. That is one huge, enormous weight lifted from the back of my mind. It's a significant amount of money that can help pay down a credit card or two, and it's no longer my problem. And another good little bit of news - about an hour after selling my Dodge, my bf got a call about his. Of course, he's selling a Dodge/Chrylser Daytona Shelby, which is actually a good little sports car, and the only reason he's selling it is so he can get a new engine for his '79 GMC truck, which he sorely misses. The guy seems pretty interested, and hopefully he calls back today (he came out to see it last night). Some other good things about this weekend - we checked out pricing for a deck, and it's less than we'd thought; we decided to go with a used washer/dryer, and be done with it; we got our CMB (community mail box) finally; Rascal got bathed and doesn't smell bad anymore; we got to go shopping for a tent for this coming weekend; we went for ice cream at My Favorite Ice Cream Shop on Sunday afternoon . . . you can't beat a double-scoop ice cream cone on a hot summer afternoon. Now I've just gotta get through the week, and we get to go camping! I'm excited about that!
