West Nile Hype You can't go a day now without hearing some reference to the West Nile virus on the radio, or TV. I'll admit - due to ignorance, I had begun to believe that this was a serious issue. We ran out and bought a big can of Deep Woods Off (which we needed anyhow), all the time looking for the highest DEET concentration. Then I was in Co-op yesterday, and read a few little tidbits about the virus. Even where the West Nile virus is present, only approx. 1% of the mosquito population actual carries the disease. And out of the people who are actually bitten by those mosquitoes, only 1% develop serious symptoms. The other 99% might develop very mild ones (similar to a cold/flu, I believe) and then recover without even knowing they'd been infected. There's good reason to cover up and use bug spray - mosquitoes are damn annoying, and a mosquito bite is even more annoying. But I'm not going to get paranoid over getting bitten more so than any other summer.

A Lesson In Bathroom Etiquette (for Men) I don't claim to be an expert in this area, but I'll share with you what I've learned from observing my boyfriend (mainly) and various other men. 1. Flushing is optional. If you made an especially impressive deposit, feel free to leave it for the next occupant to admire. 2. A quick wipe on the pants/shorts/shirt is sufficient - why waste water? 3. Anyone within earshot is dying for a status report - ie. "Phew, I think I'm 5lbs lighter!" or "Wow, I think that was a triple-coiler!" (see #1.) 4. Warnings are for wimps - dry your eyes and stifle your gagging as best as possible when you leave so as not to raise suspicion on the next victim until it's too late. 4a. If caught, passing the blame is also for wimps - a real man takes pride in his bodily functions! 5. More than 2 shakes and you're playing with yourself. 6. A half-bathroom right next to the front door is perfect after eating a super-sized MacDonald's meal right before you expect company to show up. 7. Closing the door is optional if you're standing up. Guys - did I miss any?

A Lesson In Bathroom Etiquette Maybe I'm imagining things, but there seems to be an unspoken etiquette among women when it comes to communal washrooms. Especially in the workplace, where you see the same people on a regular basis, but may not be particularly close to. So for the few who may be ignorant of these rules, I thought I'd write them out. 1. ALWAYS FLUSH. There is nothing worse than a chance encounter with a yellow bowl full of floaters. 1a. ALWAYS WASH YOUR HANDS. I think this should go without saying. 2. If there is a wall between you, do not start a conversation. Of course, if you're close friends, and the convo started before you reached the loo, that's OK. But don't initiate a conversation from either side of the stall, and especially not between stalls (the exception being if you're out of paper). 3. If you walk in to a small multiple-stall washroom, and one is occupied by someone being incredibly quiet, do your business and leave as quickly as possible. Most women I know prefer to do anything potentially noxious or noisy in complete privacy. If someone is being oddly quiet, chances are they are waiting for some privacy to resume their business. And if it so happens that you have gone in for that very reason, hold it if you can and return in about 15 mins. The first person there has priority. Of course, if you're so inclined, you can always initiate a competition to see who will wait the longest. =) 4. In a 3-stall row, where all the stalls are empty, DO NOT choose the middle one. Unless of course someone has forgotten #1 in both end stalls. This is just plain ignorance - it's like sitting in the middle of a 3-seat row at the doctor's office. It's common courtesy. 5. Coughing is an acceptable means of attempting to disguise a much-needed fart (or telltale wrapper crinkle, if you're the painfully self-conscious sort). We all know what you're trying to do, but we appreciate the effort nonetheless. 6. Closing the door is never an option. These rules are essential in order to reinforce the stereotype that ladies are clean and attractive beings who never make rude noises or bad smells. And hey, if you know of any others, feel free to share them!

Don't Worry, Be Happy, Mon Like I've discovered so many times before - it's amazing what a day, and a better nights' sleep can do to my mood. I've decided that so long as the bills get paid, and we can buy groceries, and still enjoy the odd little luxury or night out, things will take care of themselves. They always have. We're both fairly new at both our jobs - promotions and raises will eventually happen, and things will get better. There will never be enough money for all the things we want, and that is just life. And part of that is learning to decide what is worth splurging on, and what really doesn't matter. And another part of that is resigning myself to another year or so of our current lifestyle - sacrificing toys and trips for the sake of paying down debt and getting some savings started. I think the catch phrase is "living within ones' means". There's just no point stressing out about it, and becoming a crabby-stingey-miserable-selfish person over it, because it won't change anything. I firmly believe that all things happen for a reason, and for an ultimate good. Perhaps our most recent experiences were meant to drive home the reality that we can't keep spending money and getting credit without paying it back at some point. So that we can eventually enjoy our income as we please instead of constantly wasting it on interest accrued for things enjoyed 5 years ago. "It's all Zen, man . . . " (OK, don't ask where that came from) And now, time for some more sun, cool drinks, and trashy lunchtime Cosmo reads. =)

I Need To Complain I figured I might as well be upfront - the sole purpose of this post is so I can complain. This new house has held a few more surprises than I had counted on. But then again, if I had planned for something, it's not exactly a surprise, is it? =) The biggest thing right now is laundry . . . we had been told by friends - months ago - not to bother buying a washer and dryer because they'd be replacing their set. The practical and sceptical side of me told the bf that things would be much simpler if we simply bought a washer and dryer along with the rest of the appliances. Then, they'd be included with the price of the house, and thus included in the mortgage. Then, if said friends later decided they couldn't afford a new set, or some such thing, we weren't left in a lurch. But the bf talked me out of it - 'why pay for something we can get for free?' Yet another occasion where I should have listened to that inner voice. Now, nearly 3 weeks after moving in, we have had to resort to doing laundry at the laundromat. Silly me - I had been leaving it up to the bf to ask his friend about it. Guys just aren't much for remembering these kinds of things. So I was out with the female half of the couple two weeks ago, and I decided to ask her once and for all. Turns out she had been prodding her husband for weeks to mention to my bf that the dryer was on the fritz and they didn't want to give us a broken dryer. And of course, like my bf, he had simply forgotten. At the time, I figured 'no big deal' - Sleep Country had eagerly offered us an interest-free financing option, surely we'd qualify for the same at an appliance store? And failing that, surely the bank would let us open a line of credit? Ha - just goes to show how naive I still am. I'm convinced it was botched somehow (the salesguy left my bf's name on the app when he put my info through), but we were turned down for a Sears Card. And apparently lines of credit are very hard to get. Even though the guy who took our application was very optimistic. He ended up submitting an incomplete application (of course, I don't find this out until AFTER), which they construed as deliberate lying on my part. Of course, they always give several reasons when you get declined. I was rather angry when I found this out - I intend to call back today and give them a piece of my mind. So - we're back at square one. Now we have to figure out which of 3 options is going to be least stressful. We could keep going to the laundromat indefinitely, but that's a huge inconvenience. We could look around for a used set, but I'm paranoid about anything that is mechanic and used (especially after the car). Plus, we'd have to come up with the cash right away, and a used set would probably add a fair amount to our utility bills. Or, we could use an alternate funding source to get the new set we'd planned on, which wouldn't add as much to the bills, but would probably take a year to pay off. Or, I suppose we could come up with some sort of combination of the above. I'm tired of making so many 'responsible' decisions. I miss feeling young and (relatively) carefree. Maybe we weren't ready for the house after all. So now I'm eagerly volunteering for extra work at my old job, in the hopes that I can earn enough to pay straight up for a new set. I don't know if that will happen, though. I hate worrying about money. It makes me a crabby, stingey, miserable and selfish person.
No Dilemma Today Yup, no debating it today - I wanna head outside, grab a cold drink, and read my trashy Cosmo. =) Maybe I'll catch up later - for now, the sun is calling . . .

To Blog . . . or to Jog Well, OK, if I wasn't blogging, I wouldn't exactly be jogging. More like moseying around. But still. I'm aiming for a little of both. I feel very guilty lately. As I've mentioned before, we got a puppy a little while ago. My bf is a dog person, and this has only confirmed that I am definitely not. Even so, I'm feeling very guilty lately. Between moving, working extra for my old job, longer hours at the new job, and my bf having longer summer hours, Rascal has been sadly neglected. Given his age and breed mix, he definitely needs more attention and exercise than we've been able to give him in past weeks. Sadly, this causes a chain reaction - he has all this pent-up energy, and starts misbehaving. Then, I get frustrated with him, and either make my bf deal with him, or I'll just get very mad at him. So I feel guilty for two reasons - the dog is alone and in his kennel far too much, and he probably thinks I'm a miserable bitch. Hmm, some days, that's not far from the truth. =) We'd talked about possibly giving him back, but even being a non-dog person, I've had a really hard time making any decisions in that direction. I talk to some people (mainly, other dog owners), and they're often encouraging . . . he'll be less active as an adult, and things will get better. That we shouldn't be too hard on ourselves, we're human. Basically that our situation is temporary. And others feel that if I'm/we're stressed out by it, by all means, eliminate the stress. Coincidentally, these have been the non-dog owners. After thinking about it for nearly 2 weeks now, and having had things settle down somewhat, I think things would have to get really bad before we'd be able to decide to give him up. I mean he'd have to destroy things around the house (which he thankfully hasn't shown any tendency towards), and be completely unmanageable. I think we just need to give it a few more weeks for things to settle down, and register him again for training classes (we had to cancel out - there just wasn't enough time). Sheesh - all my friends are having babies, and we can barely manage a dog! *L*
Ignorance Really Can Be Bliss Sometimes, I wish I was ignorant about a lot of things. "What you don't know won't hurt you." Yeah, I'll leave it at that.

By Golly Gee Whiz . . . Guess who's pregnant now? Yuppers - the other couple we tend to hang out with. Not even 6 weeks along, and she's eagerly announcing her news. Hmmmm, less than 2 months apart . . . who called that one? Personally, this one disturbs me somewhat - they're only 21/22, bought a house, aren't married, yet were trying their darndest (OK, I think SHE was trying her darndest) for this. That picture just isn't right to me. If I ever get pregnant, I'll probably be the one who doesn't even suspect something until 2 months have gone by, and even then, I probably won't bother telling anyone (except maybe respective mothers) until I started to show.
It's all for . . . what?

My Get-Rich Scheme I came up with a get-rich-quick scheme last night - I'm going to find the switch that stops time. But I know for a fact it has a timer on it, so nobody can switch time off indefinitely. Which is good - no one wants to be suspended forever. But not like they'd know or anything . . . You know what I'd do if I found that switch? I'd turn time off for a few days, so I could get all sorts of stuff done, and then one day extra so I could do nothing. Yes, this is a common theme in my life lately - there just aren't enough hours in a day for my liking. I need more hours for getting stuff done, and I need more hours for sleep. *sigh* Good thing Friday is just around the corner.

Moving So it all began on Friday morning. The bf went off to work, and I headed to the north side of the city to pick up our keys. It took all of 10 minutes, so I was on my way again sooner than I'd thought. "Awesome, maybe things'll go a lot smoother than I'd hoped today!" Haha. So after picking up the one set, I still needed to get a second set from the contractor foreman at the new house. So, despite my tummy rumblings by now, I headed back south to pick up the second set. Unfortunately, I got to the house, went in, waited a little, and still no Neil. Darn. Well, I wasn't going to wait around all day - I figured I'd be making a few trips back with small carloads of stuff, and would probably run into him at some point throughout the day. (As a note, we STILL don't have that second set of keys!) Despite having a full day planned, I thought it would be time well spent if I got a hearty breakfast as opposed to something quick. Mmmm, Denny's. Nothing beats eggs, sausages, toast and hash browns when you need a long days' worth of energy. =) Even after breakfast, I was surprised by how slowly time was going by. "This is great!" Next up was a little shopping. I had planned to get a few small things - bathroom items and a bed set, mainly. So we wouldn't be scrambling at the last minute, or have to run out the next day when we needed to be unpacking. Spent only about 2 hours at the mall and in various stores, but came out surprisingly empty-handed. No luck on the bed set - I'm just too darn picky. Around this time, I'm trying to arrange for some last-minute help so I can start moving stuff before my bf arrived home from work. There was still a fair amount left to be packed, and I figured a little help might not hurt. Meanwhile, I get a phone call from the bf saying he was on his way to pick up the truck and trailer! I hadn't expected to hear from him for at least another 4 hours. So change in plans - head home and start packing the last of the stuff so we can start loading. We were on our own for a good hour and a half, and it was slow going with only 2 people. Around 3:30, my brothers and mum finally showed up, and by the time 5:30 rolled around and everyone else was finally off work, we had the trailer fully packed and ready to go. Since my mum had already left, and one brother needed to be home too, I figured I'd drive him home and pick up food on my way back. It was just after 6:30pm. We took a swing by the new house (he was stopping by later to pick up the other brother), and I drove him home. By the time I headed back, ordered pizza for everyone, picked up a sandwich for myself (I was feeling ill at this point, and the thought of pizza only made it worse), went back and waited far too long for the pizza, and finally arrived back at the new house, it was 9pm. I couldn't believe how late it was. I was dead dog tired, achy from working hard and then sitting in a car for 2.5 hours, and feeling ill from hunger and exhaustion to boot. A sandwich and couple of beers later, I was feeling a little perkier, only to have the bulk of our friends leave. No big deal, I guess - they'd be back for the house warming the next day. I was a little disappointed though - I'd spend the entire evening driving around, and hadn't been able to help unpack or set things up. I felt a little left out. The next day, I woke up exhausted. Not a good thing. Construction started across the street around 7:30, there were no blinds, and it was a restless night. We had to be up fairly early - Shaw was scheduled to come between 10-12 to hook up the internet, and Sleep Country was coming between 11-2pm to deliver the bed. While the bf stayed behind again, I went out for some breakfast and to fetch all our shower stuff from the old place (we were both depressed from feeling so dirty). It took me 2 hours to run such piddly errands. Frustration. I get back, and we eat, and luckily Shaw and Sleep Country come within about an hour of each other. So we're free to go out and get a few more things for the house, fetch more stuff from the old place, and start unpacking some more. By the time 6pm rolled around - when the house warming was supposed to unofficially begin - I was NOT in the mood for company. Now, we'd invited hoards of people. Or so we thought. Our "closest" friends (I say that with a touch of bitterness and sarcasm) claimed we'd never told them about it, and the one driver was already drunk, so . . . . they never showed up. Fine, whatever. One good friend showed up, and a few people I hardly knew. A little later, our friends from down the street came by. I was so frazzled from the hectic day that I completely forgot that I told at least one person that I'd call her and let her know when to come. And later, it turns out that most of the people my bf works with had heard about the party, but hadn't been told personally, so they weren't sure they were invited. Sheesh. =) So, I guess we'll be having an official house warming a little later on. That's fine with me. It gives us a chance to fix up the house how we like it, get rid of all the boxes, and maybe even start some of the finishing touches (bench for the porch, a dog pen, maybe even a deck). And officially invite people instead of giving out verbal blanket invitations. =) Egads, it's 1:15pm already . . . I'll have to continue this later. Well, Sunday was finally a bit of rest and more unpacking and a little shopping, so that's not exactly interesting.

STOP! Wait for me! I need to catch up! That's what I want to do this week. I've commented at least a few times that, had I taken a whole week off after moving, I wouldn't have been bored for one minute. Even without having any TV hookup. And now that I'm back at work, I realize I probably could have taken the whole week off without much incidence - with it being Stampede, hardly anybody is working anyways. Oh well. C'est la vie. You know, initially, I thought this move would be much like any other - it's a change, but eventually things fall into the same rhythm as before. I don't think that's going to be the case this time. There's just something different about moving into a home, and being a homeowner. It changes you. I have a new level of pride in where I live. I want everything to have its place, and I want things set up to reflect us. I don't want it to be overwhelmingly "his" or "hers". And I've seen both. As much as I didn't think this change would be a big impact on our relationship, it's becoming obvious that it will. But I don't think it will be a bad thing, and I think we'll be fine. It has been stressful with the dog, though. We don't want him soiling the brand new carpet, but he has to be closely supervised outside. We don't have a penned area for him to roam, and his whining echoes throughout the neighbourhood because the houses are still sparse. Oh well, I know we'll all eventually adjust.
We're in the house! Not much time to update right now, but I promise I will as soon as I can. It's all very surreal still . . . We definitely love hanging out on the porch. =)

One More Sleep . . . And plenty of work left! Here I am, on my day off, cramming in a couple of minutes of down time. It's been crazy. The lawyer's office finally got a hold of me this morning, and told me both of us had to go in, and it had to be this afternoon. I was not impressed - my bf was already at work and I didn't know if he'd be able to get time off. But we made it all the same. All the i's have been dotted and the t's crossed . . . as far as financing and legal matters, we're all set for tomorrow. In other matters, we're far from ready! Today has breezed by, and it feels like I haven't done anything productive yet. But I have, in a way. I decided that a day off was a perfect time to finally get some routine bloodwork done. The darn sheet from the doctor's office has been sitting in my car since February! But I tried to go on a Saturday once, and the lab is just insanely busy on a Saturday. And there's really no other good time, when you have to fast for at least 10 hours, no more than 16. So I went this morning. Icky needles . . . but at least the nurse was really good - she had to change tubes 3 times, and the needle didn't jiggle once. So after that, I headed back home, picked up the post-it with our final amount owing, and headed to the bank to get a certified cheque. Picked up some breakfast from good ol' Timmy's after (by then it was after 11pm and I hadn't eaten), and took one last boo at the house, since I was in the area. All told, I got home just after noon, and had to leave again at 12:30 to make it downtown for our lawyer's appointment. And now I'm finally back home, and just waiting a little while for my mum to get here. She's gonna follow me up to the auction place so I can drop off my Dodge. Yes, I still have that frickin thing. This is my second-to-last resort. Final resort is selling it for it's value in scrap metal, and maybe the tires. I'm really hoping it sells this weekend - they're having a Stampede breakfast, which always brings crowds. And then when I finally get back, hopefully I can start the last of the packing. Even though there are boxes everywhere, it still seems like there's lots left to do. And the place is a mess. I have to try to block that out (a messy house stresses me out), because there's no point cleaning it until we've moved out. I can't wait until we're moved and unpacked. Tomorrow's going to be my shopping day (assuming everything else gets done today). I pick up the keys at 8:30, and then I'll open up the house, take one last set of pictures before we move in, and go buy a few things. I'm so excited. And then on Saturday, we'll be having our housewarming party. It'll be insane if everyone we've invited shows up! I'm kinda hoping they do, but in shifts . . . like one set of people shows up late afternoon, another early evening, and another a little later. Guess we'll see what happens . . . I'm so excited. And Sunday we'll probably be recouperating. I'm not going to want to go to work on Monday . . . I'll just want to sit around the house and soak it all in! Oh well, can't pay for the house if we're not working! =) So that's about all that's on my mind right now. Well, that and the fact that Rascal has turned into a very hyper and challenging adolescent. And unfortunately, we haven't been able to walk him as much as we'd like lately with all the moving hullaballoo. But we've got ourselves signed up for basic training classes that start soon, so I'm hoping that helps somewhat. We need to learn some new ways to remind him of his place in the household, and also constructive ways for him to use all his energy! That said, I'm off for now . . .

I don't think I'll ever have a need for a dream interpreter. The few dreams that I remember upon waking are often so transparent, it's like a teacher who over-enunciates to her kindergarten students. I woke up from one this morning that almost had me in tears. I had to hit snooze one extra time in an attempt to dull it's effect on me before starting my day. My mum had organized a birthday party for me, complete with a rather large group of guests. I got dropped off by a friend of my bf's, but once I got out of the vehicle, I was either inappropriately dressed or nearly naked (I can't remember which). Whichever it was, it gave me this overwhelming feeling that I had to go home and shower and change before I could face all those people in my mum's house, especially since they were all there for me. My house (in the dream) was not all that far away, but just far enough that walking would take a good deal of time. And seeing as I got dropped off, my car wasn't handy to just drive myself there and back. I was hiding out around the side of the house as I watched the guests arrive. I was quite annoyed when I noticed that my bf had arrived with the same friend who had dropped me off earlier - I had figured he would drive my car, and then I could race home and change and race back. As I was debating what to do next, I could hear them all starting to celebrate inside the house, as if they couldn't be bothered to wait for me any longer - or worse, that the party wasn't for me in the first place (even though it was my birthday, in the dream). I finally just started walking home, feeling angry, invisible and worthless. I hadn't heard anybody ask once "Where's Ang?" And once I got home, do you know who I found there? My boyfriend, all concerned and asking where on earth I'd been, how come I wasn't at the party. He was the only one who cared enough to go looking for me. Some of the elements are pretty mundane - I get very frustrated when I don't have a vehicle at my disposal, because I hate being dependent on other people, especially for getting places. And tomorrow, my car is booked in for a servicing that's supposed to take 2 hours, and the only hair appointment I could get overlaps it. I've been passively mulling all week on how I'm going to get there. But the other is definitely an echo of feelings I've been trying to gloss over lately. I've been bitter whenever I'm reminded that most of my 'old' friends have nothing to do with me anymore. I try to convince myself that I shouldn't be, that people change, and circumstances change, and so will friendships. That those starting families have new priorities, and those who are single want to be spontaneous and party. But I'm still bitter. The one good part? - I don't question whether my boyfriend cares or not, because I know he does. Yeah, no trouble interpreting that dream.

Yay! Cable's Finally Back! Grrrr . . . I'm getting fed up with the whole new neighbourhood thing. Our cable - TV and internet - just up and disappeared last Friday. They promised someone would be by in 48 hours or less to check all the externals, and then made an appointment for a week later for someone to look inside. Well, they called last weekend and said everything had been fixed, but when I checked, we still had no cable. So we waited patiently for our appointment this weekend, only to be told that it was external! A small outage only affecting a few houses. The bf was talking with our new next-door neighbours today, and found out from them that someone driving a heavy-equipment truck had actually flattened the outside box, but luckily everything is up and running today - obviously. We're thinking of checking out satellite options. And then just today, we were out running some errands and visiting people. We came back to find my bf's Daytona about a car-length further down the street and the rear-end all smashed up. Thank goodness the guy was upstanding enough to leave a note in the windshield. My bf was more than willing to take a cash settlement, since he's selling it anyways, but within one phone call, the guy said he'd already informed his insurance company, so there's really no going back. We FINALLY got the pop machine moved, so hopefully they finish filling in the backyard this week. I'd sure like to be building a deck next weekend. The park across the street is starting to take shape . . . And the inquiries about marriage and kids just doesn't end . . . *sigh* Oh well, guess I'll get used to it. It has sparked a few more conversations between us on the subject though . . . =)

When Life Hands You A Bunch Of Sour Grapes . . . Betcha I have ya thinkin' I've got more griping to do, huh? =) Not so! You know, I was thinking earlier today that most of the time, it seems like I only write when I need to purge negative feelings or reactions. More often than not, the happy moments just kind of slip by, enjoyed at the moment but never hashed to death during a ranting. Actually, I think I heard it summed up best by a band's motto - "You don't need an outlet when you're happy." Needless to say, their music is very anst-ridden, though great to listen to. So this girl though she'd write for once about how happy she is. And I am. When I think back to all the times I said (or felt like saying) "you know, I'm really happy right now" . . . there have been an awful lot of them this year. I recall telling someone earlier this year (at the risk of jinxing myself, even) that I was convinced this would be my year. So yeah - I'm happy. Life seems to be settling down at home - and in a very good way. I'm starting to find room for fitness in my week, the house is starting to take shape, and I love going home to my boyfriend. It's actually kinda funny (or I think so) . . . he could be gone just for a regular work day, and if I can see his work van parked outside the house on my way home, I get excited. And if it isn't, I'm a little disappointed. And when he does come home, and I hear the door open, I get excited. Not little-kid-wild excited, but like a little internal "yay! he's home!" Is that what love is like for everyone? I love the little moments we have . . . just vegging on the porch with a beer, talking up a storm about the things we want to do next month, next year, in the next few years. I think that's how - before there's marriage talk - you know that your man sees things in the long term. Oui? Non? There are two basic types of questions I get asked these days - "So when are you guys getting married?" and "So, do you think you guys will end up married?" - and I take great offense to the first, and don't mind answering the second. I was somewhat amused, but also put off, when my boyfriend's dad approached me when I was alone at the company BBQ last weekend. He asked me 'where my husband was.' This didn't phase me, as most of the people I associate with casually refer to any significant other - married or not - as a husband or wife. I said that I had no clue and waved vaguely off in the field, knowing he was playing on the quads. So his dad pauses, gets this half-soft-half-joking look on his face, and then starts tapping his watch, saying "So when are we going to do this, huh? You know, I can always use with another daughter-in-law." I laughed and said I had no clue, which is the honest truth. At this point, it's not something I'm eager for, but should I get asked, of course my answer would be yes. And I think my boyfriend knows this. It's not something I want to pressure him into (or, inadvertently, away from). Boy, I guess this is what I end up with when I start writing with no particular purpose in mind. =) So, to encourage comments, I'd love to know about those of you who are or have been married - what was the proposal like, and were you expecting it? And do you still get that "yay! he's home!" feeling? =)
Well, I suppose I should update this sometime in the near future . . . but it won't be this morning.

Don't You Just Love Strange Phone Calls? It leaves you with something to gossip about for days! =) I got one on Monday night. A little background for you - I have 3 younger brothers; the 2 youngest (17 & 20) live with my mum, and the oldest (22) flits in and out of our lives as he pleases. It's very rare that any one of us will know where he lives, where he's working, or what he's up to at any given moment. In fact, it's very common for all of us to be pretty clueless. Yes, it's sad, but it's how our family works. So on Monday evening, I get a call from him. It went something like this: HIM: Hi. (no mention of who he is - although I recognized his voice after a few seconds) ME: uhh, hi HIM: How are you? ME: uhhh, fine *long pause* HIM: What's wrong? ME: uhhh, nothing (I was completely baffled at the possible reason for this call) HIM: I guess you're wondering why I'm calling you. ME: Well, yeah. HIM: I moved. ME: OK. HIM: To 14th Street. ME: OK. HIM: To a 2-bedroom. ME: OK. (still baffled) HIM: (getting sniffley) Dad suggested that I call you. ME: Oh really! (dripping with sarcasm) And why did he say that? *at this point, I'm extremely curious as to where this is going* HIM: Well . . . (getting quieter) . . . cuz I'm kinda strapped for cash for the next week and a half. ME: Well, sorry C, but you called the wrong person. I just moved into a house. HIM: Oh . . . uh . . .(trailing off) well . . . *hang up* Now, family members have bailed my oldest brother out in the past. And I'm not opposed to helping out family members - goodness knows I've gotten my share in the past little while. But he is notorious for being out of cash, and never learning from his mistakes, and never paying people back. Even if I had a little extra to spare at the moment (which I obviously don't), I would pretty much have to consider it a donation, and not a loan. I have yet to get in touch with my mum to see if she knows the story behind this, or if he's called her as well. The intriguing part is that my dad told him to call me. My dad and I have a non-existent relationship at the moment. And he's obviously doing well for himself - I found out last night that he has a toll-free (1-800) number for himself. Can't be that badly off. Anyways . . . gotta love strange phone calls, especially from family members!

My First Medical Condition! I was excited to find out yesterday that I have my first medical condition - a urlLink ganglion cyst . At first, it was pretty disturbing . . . I just looked at my hand one day, and there's this bump on my wrist. No idea where it came from or what it could be. My very first thought was "broken bone", but I wasn't in any pain, so that was quickly dismissed. Cancer didn't even really enter my mind, because it appeared so suddenly. So I made a doctor's appointment. At that point, I'd never even heard of the term "ganglion". I was telling a friend about it, and she said her sister had had the same thing, and she called it a ganglia. I wasn't sure how much of her story to believe - she said her doctor told her she could either bash it back in herself, or get surgery. So yesterday, I did some research online before my doctor's appointment. A ganglion fit the description to a tee. It's actually kind of cool - for now, because it's not causing me any pain or restriction in motion. I can gross some people out with it, too. =) But there are basically 4 treatments - a) do nothing, b) as mentioned, bash it back in myself, c) have the doctor aspire it (meaning needle - yikes!), or d) surgery, if it ever gets bad enough. They can come and go, and generally don't cause any problems. So yeah, I have my first medical condition! I thought I was past the stage of "firsts" for a while . . . =)

Living With Your Decisions It's only been a few days, but I find myself missing the things I used to consider hassles. Walking in the door and hearing the "thudthudthudthud" of someone who was excited to see me. Well, excited to see somebody at least. And the same "thudthudthudthud" when one of us would finally come down the stairs in the morning. Having the company when the bf works late, even if it meant I couldn't always do what I wanted. I don't know that we made the right decision, but it's the decision we made and there's no turning back now. It was even harder than I'd thought . . . several times during the afternoon, as I was driving about town and running errands, my eyes would well up as I thought about how things would be different. When we were finally heading out of town, it didn't even faze me that he was drooling terribly - in fact, I was impressed that he didn't get carsick. And then we got to Kim's house - the same lady we picked him up from 4 months earlier. She was all sweet and wonderful to Rascal, but obviously pissed off at us. This is what got to me most . . . there were so many times in that 5 minutes we were there that I just wanted to grab him away and say "Forget it, we'll find some other way" . . . I was trying not to get emotional, and she only made it worse. I realize that I probably complained a lot about the dog . . . I still won't claim to be a dog person. But Rascal had started to grow on me. I know there would have been more problems down the road if we'd kept him, but damn I miss him now. This isn't at all like when I had to give up one of my cats. I knew he was unhappy where he was, and that he would be much happier with fewer cats and more people around, and I felt comfortable that that's what he got. I never doubted my decision once after it was made. But this is different. I feel like we should have tried harder, done more, I feel like we gave up too easily. I wish we'd taken him camping with us, had one more weekend together instead of feeling like we were dumping him on our way to more important things. But then we definitely would have been more attached, and only made the decision harder to carry through. But maybe that's what we should have done anyways. Maybe if we'd seen what he could be like with a little more attention and company, we'd have decided differently. *sigh* I gotta stop this. What's done is done and that's that. I gotta live with my decisions and move on. There's no saying that there won't ever be another dog. And next time, we'll be good and ready for one, and we'll be able to give him/her the life they deserve. Rascal, I'm going to get updates every couple of days to make sure that you really do end up somewhere better. I hope you get lots of attention, and walks, and treats, and petting. I hope you maybe even have a brother or sister to keep you company when your people leave. And I hope you forget your time with us easily. I hope your next family keeps you for your lifetime. Yeah, I'm a suck sometimes. =*)

Today is painful, folks . . . I have been counting down the minutes since 1:30pm . . . it's now 3pm and I still have 2 more hours of counting minutes before I can go home. I was just over at urlLink madpony , reading about college narcolepsy and sleepwriting . . . and unfortunately, it's not cured when you graduate. Ahhhh, I remember those days . . . the last two months, when I was working 8 hours before going to school at 7am, were especially fun. Luckily my professors knew and (strangely enough) liked me by then, and cut me A LOT of slack. But I would be sitting there at my desk, genuinely interested in what was going on, and the next thing I knew, my eyes would be snapping open. I'd fall asleep sitting up and not even know it. And the harder I tried to stay awake, the sleepier I'd get. It even happened at work. The absolute worst was when I was asked to cover reception for a little while in the afternoon. The boss's office was right next door, and I was just sitting there doing my work (or so I thought) when he comes around the corner and I'm woken up by a sarcastic comment from him. That was horrifying. I got fired from that job eventually. =) I sure hope I don't get fired from this one. Instead of doing work (which there really isn't any left to do at the moment, only adding to my problems), I figured I would blog about being sleepy, in the hopes that I at least looked like I was being productive. I tried reading the Daily Oil Bulletin, seeing as I have about 5 days' worth to read, but today that has the same effect on me as a textbook. And I can't even drink coffee, cuz my tummy's already upset from the 3 sips I had this morning. Being bored and tired at work really REALLY sucks.

There is just so much to say about this past weekend. But where to start? At the beginning, I suppose. As you know, Friday was the funeral of a dear friend. I cannot claim a 'close' friend, but I think 'dear' covers it. I really wish I had known what exactly a prayer service is - there was one on Thursday evening. I opted out, thinking it would be more religious than personal. Unfortunately for me, it was just the opposite . . . if there was only one thing in this world I could change, I'd want to have gone to that Prayer Service. Well, time being what it is, it's in the past now. The funeral was more emotional (for myself) than I had expected. The last funeral I went to was my grandma's when I was 12 years old. I didn't even think to take kleenex with me. It was really touching to see so many people show up. But I think it speaks volumes to the type of girl she was. It was made even more emotional by the fact that the deacon presiding is the father of one of her best friends. There were many times he had to stop in mid-sentence to clear his throat, and we could all hear the tears in his voice. I think the hardest part was the very end, just before they led her casket out of the church - her mother walked up to her picture to collect a few flowers, and her heartbreaking sobs were felt throughout the entire church. There were many consoling hugs shared in the lobby afterwards. I think (personally) the best part was when the song "Sherry" came on, by the Four Seasons. It was turned up loud enough to hear outside, and some people starting singing along and dancing. Shari probably giggled from her vantage point when she saw that. After most of the people had drifted elsewhere, a group of us gathered at a friends' house. Perhaps there's a bit of Irish in most of us, but we felt it was a time to get together, drink and share stories. One thing that made it rather uncomfortable was the presence of BF's ex-girlfriend. They had a tumultuous on-again-off-again relationship that ended very badly, and through a mere one degree of separation she has always been in the background. I wasn't sure how I felt about this - it was already an emotional day, what good could possibly come of this? I could understand her presence at the funeral, but was rather surprised when she showed up for the gathering afterwards. Well, can you blame a girl for feeling a little insecure when you know your current beau thought he was going to marry this ex? Surprisingly enough, they talked and BF came away feeling a lot lighter, having been able to put a lot of bad stuff under the bridge, so to speak. It was eery - the atmosphere was such that I think a lot of us were expecting Shari to walk through the door at any point. But I think there was a lot of comfort to be had for a lot of us in getting together that night. There were lots of discussions going on, and a lot of closeness. It made me resolve that, no matter what stage each of us were in our lives, I would try harder to stay in touch. With two of our friends having babies soon, it's been awkward - we feel neglected and left behind, and I'm sure they half-expected us to follow suit. I heard something very nice that night. At one point, I was outside chatting with the two 'husbands', and of course children had come up. I blurted out that they both had to have well-behaved babies for my sake. They asked why, and then one piped up "cuz you want one yourself, don't you?" I said no, but that I hoped to one day, and I knew BF still wasn't keen on the idea. And joked that if they had well-behaved kids, he might change his mind. The one husband (BF's best friend of a long time) said quietly "Wellll . . . . I've heard enough from him to know that he's not against them [having kids] . . . I think he's just afraid of you getting gung-ho about the idea." And given some of the stories I've heard about his exes, I'm not surprised. So, anyways, trust me to turn a weekend about my friends into one about me. =) All in all, I don't know how else to describe it, except as a "Helluvaday". Especially when we got home, and BF uttered a few words that I'd forgotten I'd been waiting to hear. There's a bit of history behind this, but the short version is that we discovered quite early on that we have very different associations with the words "I love you." Around 4 months into our relationship, I just felt it, like a cartoon Cupid's arrow suddenly striking me . . . I waited a week to test the waters, and didn't get the response I expected. Over the next few months, it turned into a big deal, until we finally talked about it, and I found out that to him, "I love you" is about 2 shades away from "Marry me." So I let it go. I didn't feel it was worth ending a good relationship over. And in the last week or so, I've heard the phrase twice. As silly or distorted as it sounds, I'm almost afraid to break the spell by saying it back, even though I've been feeling it for so long. It rolls around in my head daily, wanting to spill out, but held back for fear of making him anxious. Part of me worries that if I voice it again, he might get freaked out . . . and the other part begs me to say it soon, lest he think my feelings have changed. So yeah . . . There were so many dimensions to this weekend. Maybe I shouldn't have mooshed them all into one run-on post, but that's just how it came out. Saturday was spent nursing a hangover, and Sunday was more visiting again. Same friends from Friday (just two of them), and then friends from down the block, who just got a new puppy. Although I wanted to write about all of this when it was still emotionally fresh and raw in my memory, I wouldn't trade the way I spent the weekend for anything in the world.

A quick update on the accident I only hear this stuff third-hand these days, because I'm only an acquaintance of the injured girl, and never met either of the guys. So I almost feel like it's not my news to share. But I think it's OK to let you know that one of the guys is out of the hospital today (he had a wound on his leg and is using a wheelchair for now), the one girl is in a body brace for a while, and the driver is still suffering from internal organ injuries. But I think they're all hoping to be able to go to the funeral tomorrow. I guess he (the driver) spends a lot of time trying to figure out what happened that night. I feel pretty badly for these 3 people - they have a long hard road ahead of them, and not necessarily in a physical sense. I can't imagine having to deal with that kind of a situation. I think I have one more post to purge some of these "death" thoughts from my head, but after that, I'll try and keep that topic to a minimum. I don't want to depress the few readers I have!

More accident updates urlLink Here's the most detailed news story on the accident. I went over to a friend's house earlier tonight, and at 11pm, they stopped the movie they were watching to scan the news channels. It was pretty gruesome. The picture in the article is nothing compared to the video footage we saw tonight. A mass of metal barely recognizable as a car was resting on it's roof, on the wrong side of a cement barrier, with a power pole where the engine might have been. Hard to believe that 3 of the 4 people in that car are in the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. And it hurts to see that anonymous "24-year-old woman" description . . . but I guess they can't release names until they're sure the family has been notified. I dropped him off at 2pm - nearly 12 hours ago!! - for a bachelor party that he was sure wouldn't last very long. The plan was to do some go-karting, and then the rest was up in the air. I heard from him around 8pm saying they were on their way to something else, for me to go ahead and do whatever, he had no idea how long he'd be out. That he'd call me later if he needed a ride. And now I can stop the horrible images from flooding my brain. I know the only person he would likely get a ride from is his brother. And I'm terrified because I have no idea if he's crashed (as in, passed out) at someone else's place, or if he's still out, or if he got a ride from his brother and . . . . There's no way I can sleep until he's home, or at least until I've heard from him. I'm so morbid.

Ain't he just adorable? Do you just wanna eat him up? I do. That's my baby. Yes, this non-dog person's fondness has grown exponentially for pooches since having to give up her own. I keep in touch with the agency every week or so, and last weekend, they happened to be at my usual pet store - and Rascal was there! I wasn't prepared for the reaction I would have - I got all choked up, I was so emotional. I had to dart down an isle to compose myself, because I didn't want to look like an idiot in front of all the people milling around. They had him there to advertise (with some other dogs, as well) . . . and I was just so happy to see him. When I'd finally pulled myself together somewhat, I went looking for him. I wasn't sure if he recognized me, but his eyes and his manners seemed to say that he knew I was familiar, but perhaps wasn't sure why. Which is OK. He's been at the agency over a month now, and he seems so much happier. But there haven't been any good candidates to adopt him. Which is good and bad - good in the sense that I can still check up on him, and even see him from time to time. Bad in that he deserves a permanent home. It would be nice if things were different now, and we could take him back. Not that they'd probably let us, but we can dream. Sadly, things aren't really much different, so there wouldn't be much point. I'd love to have him back, but I know things would just go back to the way they were and that wouldn't be good. So I'll settle for looking at pictures, and the odd chance visit.

You Will Be Remembered Fondly, Shari It's just not right. I still don't fully believe it. I was woken up this morning to awful news . . . BF came in the room, said our friend Shari had been in a car accident last night, and had passed on. She had a friend with her in the car, and as of right now, neither of us knows whether she's alive, in the hospital, or suffered the same fate. People my age just aren't supposed to die. Especially not people I know. It's one thing if it's someone I'm complete removed from - I can feel horror at the tragedy, sorrow for the surviving family, but it's not personal . This is. While she wasn't a best friend of mine, she was always someone whose company I enjoyed. We didn't see each other terribly often, as she was best friends of another friend . . . but everyone was thrilled when she'd stop by, and would always give her a hard time if she left early for another engagement elsewhere. She was a lively, bubbly little blonde girl, who always seemed to have a giggle bubbling just under the surface. Yes - I've even said such things when she was still around. She was always lamenting her single status, as most of her friends were paired off with long-term partners. Until a few months ago, when she finally divulged to her best friend - after a month! - that she had someone special. We were all eagerly waiting to hear from her again so we could meet this guy and see if he was worthy of her or not. What do you say to her parents, her best friend, our other friends who were closer to her? "I'm sorry" is just so over-used, so shallow, so inadequate for something like this. Shari, know that you had endeared yourself to every person you met, and that the absence of your sunny presence will be deeply felt by all of us. (6:00 PM - an update) A few more details have trickled in, and it only makes matters worse. I don't know if it's from a paper, or the verbal grapevine (ie trusted source), but this is what I heard a few hours ago - Shari's boyfriend was driving, and there were two other passengers besides her - her friend and her friend's boyfriend, we are left to assume for now. Alcohol is believed to be a factor, and it was a single-car collision. Her boyfriend was driving down the road, lost control, jumped on the median and hit a light standard. While the boyfriend is in the hospital (no word on his condition), the other two walked away with pressumably minor injuries. Again, as I get all my information third hand, I have no idea what the source is. But if this is all true, it's only going to make things harder for her family and those grieving with them. I'm not one to pray, usually, but I think I will make a special case tonight. I never ever imagined that drunk driving would hit so close to home. But then again, who does?

I'm Usually The World's Biggest Skeptic . . . but I think I've found something pretty cool. As I've mentioned before, I've been making a half-assed effort at losing weight (who isn't)? My goal is only about 20lbs, but I'd rather lose it now than let it get out of control, and need to lose 60lbs in a few years. And my efforts really have been half-assed, for the most part. Only recently have I (once again) renewed my resolution, making a concrete goal to lose 15lbs by BF's Christmas party (8 weeks away). There's only so far I'm willing to go with a diet - yes, I will do my best to eat more fruit. Yes, I won't eat at MacDonald's once a week. Yes, I will try and choose more health-conscious snacks for those mid-afternoon munchies. But I won't completely revamp my eating habits, or completely cut out carbs, or start eating nothing but steaks and bacon, or anything radical like that. Because chances are very good that it won't last more than a week (at most). No sense doing something that isn't going to stick. Which means it's all in the exercise for me. And my biggest obstacle? Having enough energy to workout after dinner. So after 3 weeks of only being able to drag my butt out to the gym (or swimming) 2 out of 7 days, I decided I might need a little help. WalMart has this huge mid-aisle display of something called urlLink Xenadrine EFX . . . I noticed it very plainly stated "Ephedra-free", which was a good start. Normally, I'm a huge skeptic when it comes to weightloss aids, feeling that willpower was the only reliable way to go. But since it was more directed at increasing your energy levels, I figured it was worth a try. If it didn't work, no big loss. If it did, great. It's only been 5 days, but I notice a huge difference already. Not in weight loss, but in energy level and focus. I took my first dose on a Friday, so I didn't notice much difference at work. But that evening, I was hyper. This worried me a little, but figured my body probably just needed to adjust to the chemicals and vitamins. So I persisted. Monday rolled around, and amazingly enough I was alert - all morning long. And it was no trouble at all having the energy to go to the gym after dinner. And my friend even joined me at the gym last night, which was awesome. While I don't mind working out alone, it sure makes the time pass more pleasantly when you have company. So we'll see if it helps me lose weight. Even if it doesn't, I've got more energy, and I'm not exhausted when I get home from work. My mood is even better (but that's harder to attribute to any one thing), and I just generally feel good. The only concern . . . and maybe urlLink Desiree , being a former nurse, might be able to shed some light . . . is that it might change the effectiveness of the pill. The Dreaded Family Gatherings This weekend was filled with activity. Friday night was spent with a few friends around a fire in our backyard. I'm hoping we can have a few more of those before it gets too cold. Sunday we took part in the Breast Cancer run/walk. And Saturday was a wedding. In BF's family, of course. I have such a small family of my own that weddings are few and far between. In fact, I'm pretty sure the next one won't be until I get married myself. BF has a huge family. I mean HUGE. His dad is the youngest of 12 kids, his granny is still around, and many of his aunts and uncles have children and grandchildren of their own. For the most part, I don't mind his family. But lately, every large family gathering is turning into a trial. I think all you unmarried or married-without-children couples out there will know what I'm talking about . . . the first thing out of everyone's mouth is "So . . . when are you two getting married?" And with a family as big as his, it gets old . . . FAST. People I hadn't even met before were asking me when it was going to be our turn. Some asked him first, and then would turn to me as if to say "Well, what's wrong with you that you haven't made him ask you yet?" Others would skip him (knowing him better) and ask in a more conspiratorial tone, "So, when are you guys going to do this?", nodding towards the newlyweds. I think we spent most of the 45-minute drive home coming up with things to say at the next occasion. We already know that another cousin of his is getting married in June next year. His brother got married this past January, and they're expecting their first baby this coming January. All eyes are on him now, with almost every other relative (over 20) being married and/or having kids. And I don't doubt that when we do eventually get married, the interrogation won't stop. Then it will be, "So when are you guys going to have a baby/give me grandkids/etc." *sigh* I guess it's all part of the package. I think BF is getting off incredibly easy - I don't see a whole lot of my own family, and when we do, I don't think I've ever been asked when we plan on getting married. Of course, my mum knows the deal, and I've talked to her. The last time I went over to visit, she admitted as I was leaving that she thought I'd come over to say I was engaged. And then proceeded to tell me if I DID get engaged anytime soon, I couldn't get married within a year cuz she just wasn't ready. I love my mum. And she's never bugged me about grandkids, either. I still haven't figured out if she meant she wasn't ready from an emotional point of view, or financial. Don't get me wrong - BF and I have pretty much agreed that it's mostly a matter of being able to afford it completely on our own. But I know my mum, and I know she would feel a lot better if she could offer to help out. Especially knowing that BF's father is very well-off. But apart from all the questions, it was a good time. BF was very happy to see his granny (as she lives in Ontario and probably doesn't have many years left), and as much as he may complain about his family himself, he enjoys being able to visit with them. I think the highlight of the evening was a twist on the wishing well . . . "I'm Too Sexy" came on, and several of the bridesmaids cornered the groom on the dancefloor and proceeded to strip him. He got right into it . . . after the jacket, vest and tie had been shed, the shirt came unbuttoned and he leaped up on to one of the tables. There were several older women sitting there, and they cheered him on and started tucking bills into his pants!! I've never seen that at a wedding . . . it'll be something to remember, that's for sure. As much as I complain, and as much as they can be overbearing, BF's family sure knows how to have a good time. I think I'm looking forward to the next wedding.

Score 1 for Angela after 14592 for Telus Finally . . . I get somewhere. And lucky for them (and me, I guess) it was enough so that I have lost the motivation to look elsewhere for telephone services. Maybe 3 really is the magic number . . . this was the third customer service rep I dealt with on this issue. #1 made vast promises, but they never materialized. #2 was just plain stubborn and refused to budge an inch. But #3 knew what customer service is about. I have been trying to get acknowledgement from Telus in the form of a credit, because it took so friggin long for them to get our phone service hooked up at the new house. And it was made even worse when I got that $45 moving charge. And today, they finally reversed it. I didn't have to lose my temper, or be a bitch, or anything. I told her very reasonably that I understood they needed to charge a moving fee, but that I just wanted some sort of a credit for the inconvenience of having to wait 6 weeks, and thus generating horrendous cell phone bills. I probably would have been fine with $20, but she said, "OK, your account has been credited the $45, and it'll show up on your next bill." And now I'm happy once again. I feel just a little less taken-advantage-of, and that's a good feeling.

I hate fighting. Especially with someone I come home to every day. Especially when it's still unresolved when we leave for work. I've always been a pleaser. Since I was a kid, I never wanted to disappoint, meaning I was a helluvan easy child to discipline. All my dad had to do was give me that 'look', and I immediately felt bad. Over the years I've mellowed a bit, realizing that I can't please everyone all the time, and that often some things just aren't worth making myself miserable for the sake of someone else. BF is quite the opposite. He'll do what is right by him, regardless of how it affects others. Well, OK, he's not callous, but it makes for some interesting dynamics between us. It can be such a demanding job sometimes, striking that balance between independence and being considerate of one another. I think it's the biggest challenge a couple faces when they live together (whether married or not). Last night was one of those nights that things are out of balance. I'm pretty sure BF thought there wasn't a problem, and I take part of the blame in that I should have said something last night. Unfortunately, I learned far too much from my dad, and sometimes I will resort to old habits by pretending things are OK, and then make a snide comment when the opportunity arises. I waited until he was almost out the door this morning to say anything. And we have this routine. BF knows when he's done something I'm not thrilled with, and he'll ask, "Are you mad that I . . . [insert whatever]?" And after 2.5 years, I've learned that this has two translations: 1) "Do I have some sucking up to do before I can get laid tonight?" and 2) "You'd better not be mad cuz I had every right to do what I did." Usually I can tell by his tone which one it is. Last night was a #2, and this irked me because I thought I had every right to be upset. It was something pretty non-major - he wasn't home when I got there (no big deal - a commone occurrence) so I called to see when he thought he would be. So I'd know whether to go ahead and eat or wait for him. He said he was over at a recently-ex-coworkers' having a few beers. But now, I don't remember if he said "A beer" or "a few beers", because in our house, it's a huge distinction. "A beer" means "I'll be home soon" and he often specifically says so (that he'll be home soon). "A few beers" means "I've already had a couple, and maybe I'll have a few more, who knows?" He didn't say if he'd be home soon or not. I knew that he missed the 'farewell' pub night for this particular guy, so it was rather ambiguous. As a side note - have any of you noticed how the longer you're with someone, the more translations you learn, and the more assumptions get made when you're talking to each other? Anyways, Thursday is the night with all the good TV shows, and this causes me much consternation, as it's usually an exercise night. So I'd planned on going to the gym early in order to still be able to watch them, which meant I needed to eat early. Which meant that I felt malicious as I cooked enough for two, not knowing whether he'd be home before it got cold and getting more and more irked the more time went by. And I was too stubborn to simply call and find out when he'd be home. I mean, I fight hard against that whole "nagging girlfriend" stereotype. And on top of it, I was somewhat jealous - he's always got someone to go out for a beer with after work, while I never have that opportunity. So I ate alone, and left for the gym rather steamed (he still wasn't home). So I was pretty mad by the time I finally got home. And thus began the routine . . . "Are you mad that I went for a beer after work?" . . . to which I replied "No, but I'm upset that you didn't say when you'd be home" and left it at that. But I was still mad, and waited until this morning to say "So am I going to hear from you if you're not going to be home tonight?" (yes, I can see some of the cringes out there). There was a somewhat shocked pause, and a mumbled but unmistakeably pissed "yeah sure". So yeah, we left for work this morning mad at each other, and I needed to vent about it. By tonight, I'll probably have calmed down enough to say all this to him, and he'll say he's sorry (but he won't say that it won't happen again, cuz we both know it eventually will), and all will be fine again. Assuming he isn't so pissed off that he goes out for 'a few beers' right after work tonight. But I really hope not. Who knows? Maybe we subconsciously play these little fights out just for the makeup sex . . . =) But I still hate fighting . . . especially with a person I love.

Office Pranks on a Grand Scale Ever remember hearing a story when you were younger about a garden gnome that went missing from his yard? And how the owner would periodically get "Wish you were here . . . " postcards from around the world, prominently featuring the missing gnome? Well, we seem to have our own little version going on at the office. Only instead of a garden gnome, it's a coffee mug with sentimental value. At all started when my office-neighbour started campaigning around the office - "Have you seen my mug? Someone's got my mug! You know, the one with 'Pepperdine University Dad' on it? Is it you?" He just happens to be the office prankster, so many of us got a good chuckle, hoping that perhaps he'd met his match. And thus started the adventure. Within a day, emails were being delivered to the distressed mug-dad along with incriminating photos. To our delight, we're being kept updated via the office kitchen. It appears that the coffee mug just wasn't feeling appreciated. That it needed some space, some time, and wanted to explore new things. There were a few photos of it on a dashboard, obviously headed out of town. The emails became taunting . . . a photo of the delinquent mug proudly perched on the hood of his dad's truck. The written messages morphed into sassy poems - "Roses are Red, Violets are Blue, I'm Sitting Right Here on Your Truck - Where The Heck are You???" And this afternoon is the best yet . . . during a staff meeting, our president announces that a suspicious package arrived today. That after the bomb squad gave it the 'OK' (joking, of course), they found a tape inside. What we watched next was a taping of the A-Channel Big Breakfast Show . . . which featured Dave Kelly pointedly displaying his mug every chance he got, and even nodding to the camera once or twice while doing so, as if toasting someone out in the audience . . . and yes, it was Larry's mug. Seems this mug is really out to make a point. Apparently he needs celebrity lips in order to feel appreciated these days. I wonder where he'll turn up next? Maybe he'll come home for Christmas . . . ???

Shouldn't We At Least Get a Kiss Out of The Deal? I'm absolutely livid this morning. I got my car insurance renewal notice last week. I was angry then, but had to wait a week to deal with it since I was on course. My history? Never a claim, never a ticket (other than parking, which doesn't count), never a break in coverage, absolutely clean since I got my license when I was 17. And when other people have been at fault? Nothing but headaches and hassles and fighting just to get my car fixed properly. While I heard of friends and acquaintances getting thousands for almost non-existent injuries, I've NEVER gotten anything above and beyond the cost of fixing my car. Despite this, I'm being told that my premiums have gone up by nearly $240 for the next year. My initial reaction - "What about this rate freeze we've been hearing about? Aren't you breaking a law or something?" Their response - "Well, the government hasn't told us how we're supposed to deal with that yet. We have thousands of clients, and nowhere near the manpower to review every account and credit them." My reply - "But this was drawn up after October 30." I didn't get a satisfactory answer to that one. So I said I'd be shopping around. She was polite enough, saying she wished she could do something but her hands were tied. So I called around. I knew that my ASET membership entitled me to group benefits at Meloche, but they quoted me an even higher rate than the one I'd been bumped to by TD. So I hopped on Kanetix, but to no avail. Even with them, their lowest quoted rate was barely $20/yr less than what I'm currently supposed to be paying. What made it even worse was that my premiums got withdrawn today. $20 more than I've been paying the past few months, and $20 more than I'd budgetted for. Of course, $20 on its own is not hard to come up with, but it's the principle. So I called TD back. Said that if I had no choice but to pay these new rates (making it VERY clear how angry I was about it, but trying to be diplomatic), I wanted to add my BF to my policy since he'd sold his car and would be cancelling his policy. I think I really would have lost it if they'd told me this would increase my premiums even more. Luckily, it didn't. I'll admit, given that they're probably getting a helluva lot of these calls lately, she was very patient with me. Told me the only course of action I had at this point was to call the government myself, and even went so far as to give me the number. I intend to call. That doesn't make me any less angry at the insurance company - they're profitting off me, for cryin' out loud. Anybody else going through this at the moment? This came out of left field to me, because up until this month, they were offering me discounts all over the place - for having a multi-vehicle household, for having property insurance as well, etc. My monthly premiums had dropped about $9 from what I'd originally been paying when I signed up last December. And in my brief search, I found the urlLink CAC Auto Insurance Rates Review . Turns out Calgarians are paying among the highest rates, and have also experienced one of the highest increases as well. Being the control freak that I am, this is probably the highest level of frustration for me - knowing there's basically nothing I can do about it. I mean, shouldn't we at least be getting a kiss before they f*^@ us over like that?

Tragedy Chez Ang My beloved Civic has not been doing so well lately. I guess it's not brand new anymore, but still. We have a new street by my house, and it gets me home from the main street faster than the old route. And there's a bonus - with all the snow, and a lack of houses on that street, it's perfect for practicing e-brake turns. Only problem is, I must have done something wrong last Friday. Luckily (or unluckily), the curb was well-padded with a pile of snow. So I jumped a snow bank instead of a curb. But I got stuck. Between Shari and my grandma, they're sure keeping on top of me up there, cuz our neighbour came by just seconds later (it's not a heavy-traffic road or anything), and went home to get his 4x4 Toyota and a tow rope. I was on my way again in less than 10 minutes. But the story doesn't end there. As I went on my merry way to a double-session of Pilates, the car started vibrating something horrible. Panick-stricken, I pulled over to see if anything was visibly wrong - perhaps a flat tire, a big chunk of ice, or a bad alignment from the snow-bank-hopping. I couldn't see anything, so just kept driving, albeit a little more carefully. It never happened again, so I chalked it up to a chunk of snow or ice being caught underneath the car. Until we went to wash it this weekend. Between BF and I, we're diligent car-washers - always paying close attention to the wheel wells, as that's where rust often starts. And that's when BF noticed that the front passenger side wheel was missing the plastic piece that isolates the wheel well from the engine compartment. Darn, darn, darn. I was almost hysterical, until BF said it was just a plastic part and he could replace it himself if I got the part from Honda. And last night, I got my first rock chip on the windshield. That one makes me mad, because I have no control over that. But I suppose it's about time - there have been several occasions when I've been driving along and something very loud hits the windshield, and there's not a single mark. Last night scared the shit out of me, it was that loud. Poor, poor, car. I'm sorry you got stuck with me - apparently it's not just my luck, it must be my driving. And I promise I'll replace your bumper just as soon as someone rear-ends me . . .

A Touchy Subject It's not very often that I mull over controversial issues on here. Mostly I just ramble on and on about things that are only relevant or important or interesting to me and nobody else. But for reasons I'd rather not disclose, I've been thinking a little about the topic of abortion lately. For those of my 'in-the-flesh' friends reading this: No, it's not because I've had one. Mind you, I doubt I would admit to it even if I had. And hey - it's been in the news, too. The Americans have decided to revisit this volatile debate in regards to partial-birth abortions. It makes me wonder - how would I feel about an unexpected pregnancy? At this point in my life, it would likely be undesired in addition to unexpected. But which option would be harder to live with: the knowledge that I terminated the pregnancy and thus deprived a baby of its life, or the changes and accomodations I would have to make for parenthood? Because really - if I wasn't emotionally attached to or felt responsible for that thing inside me, would it really be that traumatic to terminate it? I really couldn't say without actually being in that position, and I hope to God that I never am. The fact in itself that I don't know what I would do in this situation causes me some unease. I grew up in a Catholic family. My beloved grandma, when she was alive, was a very active and vocal member of a pro-life organization. I grew up with the assumed belief that abortion was inherently wrong. No self-respecting or life-respecting person would do such a thing. But as I grew older, I realized that this was a very personal issue. I changed my stance - though rather quietly - to one of pro-choice. Even so, I always maintained that for me, personally, abortion could never be an option. And now I'm at a rather precarious point in my life. I have friends making the choice to get pregnant and start families. I'm old enough and reasonably financially stable enough to potentially care for a child. And with a long-term boyfriend and all that entails, there's always that miniscule possibility. It's not as if I'm still a child myself, still in school or working minimum wages jobs, or single. On the one hand, it seems like it would be very hard to justify an abortion to myself, given my lack of reasonable excuses. I don't think I could ever admit to anyone if I went through with one. The only excuse I have is that I'm not ready. But is that a reasonable excuse? OK, excuse is really the wrong word to use here. What I mean is, is not being ready a good enough reason to live with whatever guilt (or maybe not?) might ensue? Then again, is it fair to impose such a responsibility on myself, my boyfriend, and the baby that will eventually come? Through all of this contemplation, I've come to a conclusion: I'm going to stop thinking about it unless I have to. I'm pro-choice - end of story. Even if such a choice might cause me great pain and agony one day. I will just cross my fingers (and take my pills!) and hope I never have to make such a decision.

I HATE the stupid people in SUVs and big trucks who tailgate me when 40 is the fastest I can safely go on the icy side streets. Then again, keep it up - I wouldn't mind a new bumper at your expense. I HATE leaving home at 6:30am and getting to work at 7:30am. I miss having a stress-free 5-minute drive to work. I HATE arriving at work and leaving again with all the other lemmings. I HATE working downtown. On that same token . . . A Rant About How Much My New Job Still SUCKS WHY? WHY did I have to leave my old job? SURE , they were all chauvinistic pigs there. BUT , they were less so around me cuz they knew I knew stuff they didn't, and joked back with them. I HATE how I still don't know a whole lot at my new job. I HATE how everyone else has a purpose, work to keep them busy all day long. I HATE how I'm the only one who doesn't seem to know what their job is. I HATE how I have to bug other people for work when I get bored. Which is all the time lately. Because they're all busy. And have to stop what they're doing to give me something to do. I HATE how I seem like the stupidest person here. Because I'm not. At least, I'm not a stupid person. Because I used to be one of the smartest people at my old job. And that felt good. And this doesn't. I'm constantly paranoid that one day, my boss is going to come in and say "Come see me in my office" and I'll go and he'll give me a talking to for wasting time on the internet, when really, I've been around to so many people asking "Is there anything I can help you with?" and they say "No" or "I'll see" and then they never get back to me cuz they're all busy. IT SUCKS. I WISH I'd never left my old job. But then I wouldn't have an RRSP plan, or a real benefit plan, that ends up covering most of BF's dental surgery cuz his plan sucks. And then my friend wouldn't have a regular job that she seems to like. And I would probably be getting paid less. But I wouldn't HATE traffic as much. I wouldn't have to HATE taking the train, because I wouldn't have to take it. I wouldn't have to feel guilty about wasting time on the internet, because I'd know what to do to keep myself busy. Or it just wouldn't matter. I HATE how the hours are so rigid here. "7:30am to 5pm" , no flexibility. Gotta leave early for a doctor's appointment? Better make it up to the minute by working lunch hours! Or staying late! Old job said - is your working getting done? Is there anything urgent that needs attention? No? Then don't worry about it! We're not keeping track! Here, nobody likes someone who wants to bend the rules to suit them. There, nobody cares, so long as the work gets done. THIS SUCKS.
