Winter Blues I sure hope I dont suffer from urlLink SAD . . . otherwise itll be a miserable winter. But I just havent felt like myself lately, and because I cant find a reasonable explanation for it, it bothers me even more. Great sarcastic thanks go out to my mum and my friends sister . . . youve made me paranoid until next week! Earlier this week, I was telling my mum how I hadnt been feeling 100% the last 2 weeks, but not outright sick. Just a little queasy some of the time, and generally exhausted for the rest of the time. Mum: Well, is it that time of the month ? (sadly, yes, thats how we talk in my family). Me: No, not until next week (thinking she was trying to draw a PMS conclusion). Mum: Well, I guess if it doesnt come, then you know youre in trouble or something to that effect. Yeah, thanks mum. And then, just to reinforce my paranoia, we were over at my good friends lovely new own digs on the weekend, when her sister blurted out something very similar (though quite out of the blue, if I remember right). Of course, I dont either of them are right, but that small kernel of doubt has been planted nonetheless . . . because no matter what you do, theres always that small chance. But 90% of the time, the thought doesnt even cross my mind. But now with all the pregnant women around me, Im starting to wonder if it really is something I can catch. =O And just to add to my winter blues, two weeks of absenteeism (thanks to not feeling great) and an abundance of Halloween candy have undone the good results Id gotten from 4 weeks of hard work at the gym. =( Boohoo. Now I have to work even harder and ignore not feeling well if I want to reach my month-end goal. Speaking of Halloween, I think it was the quietest ever. I was kind of excited about having a house that kids might actually come up to. I didnt expect many, being in a new development still under construction, but I was hoping for a few. Despite my initial Ba-humbug attitude, I got excited and was hurriedly putting up decorations and tracking down ice melt at 5pm on Friday. I carved my very first pumpkin, too! I thought it looked pretty good. I get such pitying looks from people when I tell them I carved my very first pumpkin this year. =) All for 2 trick-or-treaters. And one looked like he might have been stoned, if he hadnt been so young and perched on Dads hip. =) I dont think he had a clue what was going on. The other totally made up for the first ones lack of enthusiasm . . . we could hear him screaming Trick or Treat!! from the sidewalk! And he couldnt have been more than 2 or 3 feet tall . . . that was cute. So, around 8:30pm, we decided wed seen all the trick-or-treaters we were going to see, shut off the porch light, and headed over to a friends house. Theyd had about 30 kids, they figured, but they were done for the night, too. We watched a little TV, chatted for a bit, and then played a couple games of Labyrinth. Its hardly the exciting pub-crawl night of some, and even though it made me feel kind of old and boring (even though we were both feeling a little under the weather), I wouldnt trade in the quality time with friends for anything. Saturday saw a good friend of mine moving into her first apartment! I felt a little bad Id told her Id help, but then realized I might not be of much use since I didnt have a truck. I didnt feel as bad when she told me a couple of male co-workers (one with a truck) showed up, but still . . . I did say Id help. But BF and I went over later in the evening to check it out and keep her company for a while. Her sister and sisters boyfriend showed up, and her best friend was already there. Its a pretty good place, especially as first apartments go, and its got a lot of space! Plus, its right in the area of the city shes always wanted to live in. Im so happy for her, even though its lonely right now. Having felt a burning need to just go out , BF and I headed to the peelers after that. It used to be a little more fun . . . until about 6 months ago, youd never see a woman at a strip club, unless she was there to dance. Which meant I was special and got a lot of looks from the other patrons, and sometimes from the dancers, too. I guess Im an attention whore at heart, just like my friend urlLink Leah . Now, at the urlLink Speakeasy in particular, you often see groups of women right up in pervert row. Which I see nothing wrong with, but suddenly Im not so special for going. =) A lot of my friends think Im weird for going, but I see nothing wrong with it. But you definitely have to be in the right frame of mind for it. We were only there a short while, but I can home pleasantly buzzed and in a good mood much to BFs delight. *wink* Wow Im terribly longwinded today! Pretty unusual . . . =) And finally, yesterday was spent being a loving and caring girlfriend. =) BF had his dental surgery. When he came out, the nurse motioned to me that he needed a lot of TLC. Going in, his biggest worry was that the anesthetic would wear out, despite stressing to his periodontist that his body metabolized it unusually fast. It turns out they had to re-freeze his mouth 3 times, and he still felt way too much of what was going on. Apparently, what they gave him should have easily lasted 16 hours, and he was only in there for just over an hour! If theres one thing on this earth that I really cant stand, its seeing a loved on in pain. So I spent last night fussing over him. And Im sure none of this is interesting to anyone but myself, but I dont care. Its been a while since I posted, and I felt like writing a novel about my boring life. Maybe Ill come up with something interesting to write next time. Maybe not. =) Oh well.

Wow Is about all I can come up with. I keep trying to imagine what it would be like if it was me bringing home a brand new baby. And all I can imagine is being overwhelmed. It's kind of scary to hold him. He's so tiny, he can't do anything for himself. If someone sets him in my arms, and my arms start to get tired, I'm afraid to move him in case he breaks. What if I'm not holding him right? Terrified is what I'd be if it was me having to look after this little thing. Terrified. Dad is so funny. We still can't believe he's a father. We laugh at him everytime he jumps when the baby makes a sound. The way he rushes into the room when the baby starts crying. Mom seems amazingly calm and accepting of everything that's going on. Whether it's just the face she puts on for company, or whether that's how she just is, I'm not sure. But Grandma's opinion is that she's doing a wonderful job. I love BF's mom. I told him the other day that it's bad that he has such a good mom, cuz it makes me look like a horrible daughter. Because I probably see more of her than my own mum. I love how BF is so protective of me when it comes to my father. He gets angry whenever the subject of him comes up. We've talked vaguely about possible situations - like when lots of weddings were going on, we talked about things that might happen with our families. I said I really didn't know what I would do about my father. I don't think I'd want him there, but I don't know how easy it would be to just ignore the subject. Sure, he doesn't talk to me anymore, but who's to say he wouldn't come out of the woodwork when he found out about an impending marriage? Or even grandchildren? BF says he wouldn't let my dad near me until he'd had it out with him. And if my dad wouldn't have anything to do with him, then that would be it. And it makes me smile to think he's protective of me. And more recently, with the issue of grandparents and who's technically a grandparent, and who has the right to call themselves a grandparent. Because this baby's grandma is grandpa's first wife. He's on his third right now. So does Wife #3 have a right to consider herself grandma? Do Mom and Dad have a right to say, 'no, he's not going to call you grandma'? Is it worth it to make it an issue? Because now my dad has another wife. I was talking with friends about this, and they asked me 'Would you consider Connie a grandma if you had kids?' and my immediate reaction was 'No." She's had nothing to do with me, along with my dad. And we were talking about this the other night, BF and I. Because I said I was merely curious if a major event in my life - marriage, a baby, etc - would cause my father to come out of the woodwork. And if he did, it would almost certainly be as if nothing was ever wrong in the first place. If that were to happen, BF would be just as angry as me. As he put it, 'He (my father) wasn't there for you - why on earth should he expect to be a part of a grandkid's life?' Harsh words, some might think. Life is short, don't hold a grudge, blahblahfreakinblah. Exactly. Well, obviously none of these things are about to happen anytime soon, so the point is moot. For now. So no use wondering what the future holds. But it still makes me warm to see that display of protectiveness. It makes me even more sure that he's someone I want to spend a long time with.

Christmas Progress Is everyone pretty much ready for Christmas at this point? I don't think I ever am until Christmas Eve . . . and even then, some years it's a pinch. We still don't have the tree up. This makes me sad, but unfortunately it's pretty much my fault. BF and Sunnyboy got the couch moved downstairs on Monday, but I had to work Monday night. Last night, we still hadn't watched Bad Boys II that we'd rented on Sunday, and it wasn't over until just after 10pm. And tonight, I have to work again. Maybe tomorrow? I sure hope so, because I have about 3-4 bags full of presents I want to put under there! On the gift front, I was excited the other night to think that I only had 3 more people to take care of. Then I get home to boast to BF, and he reminds me that there's still another 6 people I'd forgotten about. All his family. Oops. My bad. The credit card is running up towards the max, but I'm not going to stress a whole lot about it. Hopefully next year I won't be so busy, so I can actually sit down and figure out how much we can/should be spending on people. This year, it's pretty haphazard. Enh, money comes and goes . . . just so long as I make sure it gets paid off in a coupla months and don't keep spending. My second job should yield another impressive paycheque at the end of the month, so that helps, too. You know, people rebel against the 'commercialism' of Christmas, and I agree to an extent. But it'll happen throughout the year that I'll come across something that just begs to be bought as a gift for a friend/family member/SO. So it's kinda like Christmas is a legit excuse to actually buy these things. But then again, I do get somewhat miffed at the concept that we're expect to exchange gifts with certain people. My biggest beef this year is BF's four half- and step-brothers. They're all teenaged boys who are pretty much spoiled by their parents (remember his dad owns the refrigeration business? yeah, they're his/his wife's kids). Maybe because they're not my brothers, but my feeling is - they'll get pretty much everything or anything they want, so anything we get them it'll be like "Gee, thanks". Is that bad of me? But in the end, BF liked my suggestion of getting them the same thing I'm getting for my brothers. Which is fine - it's only once a year. And last year, he gave them IOUs for taking them to the shooting range but the year just kinda slipped by without ever following through on it. So I suggested that if he's going to get them something this year, he should actually get something instead of promising something. =) And now, just because it's never far from my mind . . . kittykittykittykittykittykitty . . . =)~

The Decision's been made - now I can rest a little easier After a brief period of consternation yesterday, I made up my mind. I'll see if I can take a few extra holidays after Christmas (before New Years') so I can do some extra work, and I'll wait until the new year to give my notice. This was all preceeded by speculation that IF we were getting a bonus, perhaps they were waiting until the Christmas party this Saturday to give them out. And that makes a lot of sense. But another factor was also the complication of the holidays. I like a lot of the people I work with and wanted to be able to enjoy at least part of the Christmas party with them. If I resigned before Christmas, there wouldn't be much chance of that. I'm only obligated to give a weeks' notice, so I could just come back on Jan 5 and work my last week. So what about taxes and whathaveyou . . . BF had a good point that, as a manager/president/etc, it would probably somewhat ruin the holidays to get someone's resignation just before Christmas. Best to follow his example and wait til the new year. So I feel much better having made this decision. It's one less thing that needs to be taking up space in my brain. Now, if only I could hear back from FRFA . . . I think I'm going to call them this morning.

Crossing the t's and Dotting the i's Not like I really thought it was any different, but now it's just a matter of negotiation - agreeing what I'll be paid and any other little details. I talked to my old supervisor last night, and the GM even popped in while I was there to assure me/us that he'd be willing to have 3 people in that position for the sake of getting things back on track. Upon further discussion, it sounds a lot more reasonable - they'll keep the new guy on for another little while to see how it goes, and then determine if he fits or not. I think they just don't want anyone threatened by my return, and possibly any lawsuits - completely understandable given the company's history with trouble from ex-employees. But it sounds like they have the same impression as me - in a nutshell, that the new guy just doesn't have the common sense and attention to detail required for the job. So yeah, all I really need to worry about is when to give my notice, and what on earth I'm going to say. I read over the company's resignation policy, and I'm only required to give a weeks' notice if I've been here less than 2 years. So I think I'll wait until Friday, that way maybe the impact is softened by the time I have to come in for work on Monday. I'll work my 2 1/2 days left before Christmas, get paid out for my outstanding holidays, and if they want to refuse to pay me for the Christmas break (I've resigned myself to no pay for New Years'), I suppose that's their right. I'm going to do my best not to burn any bridges. Because I don't need that this early on in my career. I'm going to be so nervous for the rest of the week - I hope it goes by fast. But seeing as I'm seriously lacking in work to do again, it'll probably drag by. Oh well. I'll see if I can find any short-term projects to do in the meantime. And on BF's employment front . . . I can't believe what he's putting up with at work for the sake of getting through the holidays and leaving in the best manner possible. Maybe his boss/dad can sense that something is coming, I don't know. But he's definitely crossing the lines of professionalism these days. On Friday evening, it was a friend's birthday party. BF used to work with the girl's husband until he quite a few months ago, and they also live down the street. We're all pretty good friends and still hang out every coupla weeks. So of course we would attend her surprise birthday party. Apparently BF got his butt chewed out yesterday for this! Apparently, because said friend's husband is an ex-employee, that he shouldn't be socializing with him. That he has his priorities screwed up or something to that effect. BF's attitude when he was telling me about this was "I just need to make it through the Christmas season." Wow, he's strong. I can't imagine what on earth is going through his dad's head to be saying these things, especially on the job. As a boss - and even as a dad, for that matter - how on earth is it his business what an employee (or his son) does on his personal time, or who he associates with? It isn't! My only comment just before we fell asleep was - "Well, hopefully we'll both be much happier after Christmas." And hopefully a cute little ball of fur to come home to will help relieve stress in the meantime. =) Except that we still haven't heard a peep from urlLink FRFA . Maybe by the weekend. I know most of them are volunteers who have day jobs, so I've got to be patient. It never rains but pours, huh? =)

Mixed News Sadly, nothing about my job situation has been figured out for sure yet. And it makes me nervous, because 2-weeks' notice for the end of the year is Wednesday or Thursday of this week. And I'm stressing about what I'm going to say to the people here, and how it's going to be received. But I did get some rather exciting news this morning . . . I'm not supposed to know, but apparently the GM at the old job has instructed my old supervisor to "pay her whatever it takes" to get me back. That's more like it. I feel kinda spoiled, actually. I don't want to get cocky, because I know what happens to people when they get that kind of attitude. I don't want to be greedy, but it needs to be worth my while to be leaving a pretty good job after only 7 months. The mixed news? There's talk of keeping the new guy as well. First of all, that poses all sorts of problems - #1, there's a serious lack of office space as it is (with only 1 extra person, let alone 2). #2, they'd have to buy another computer, as well as licenses for the software, which is NOT cheap. #3, neither me nor my friend currently in the position can stand him. That sounds really bad, but he's very frustrating to work with. I just don't see how it makes any business sense to keep him around when he's only adding to the workload, and it's already been a month or so since he started. My friend was already working alone after only a week of training. And on another note, I don't see why he's doing this kind of work when he's technically qualified to do an engineer's job. I just think it would be better for all if he was doing work he'd be good at, instead of struggling (and causing much frustration) with something he isn't. Is that wrong of me? I just don't think I'd be anywhere near as excited about this change if it means he's still going to be around. Especially given the nature of the work - sure, it's busy right now, but when I left 7 months ago, we'd all literally been sitting around for 3 weeks. And for most of the time I was there, the work was just enough to keep one person steadily busy. OK, I'll let go of that one for now before I start a rant. =) So - I'm hoping this finally happens this afternoon! I've had to lie and say I have a doctor's appointment, so I'm leaving work at 3:30pm. I hate lying. It always seems to catch up with me somehow. And now a co-worker (and friend) is possibly leaving as well. I didn't really feel guilty about handing in my notice, because I don't feel like I really contribute much in the first place. But now that she's possibly leaving as well . . . man, THAT gap would certainly be felt. Guilty, guilty, guilty. Must be the Catholic upbringing. =) And I am SO unreasonably curious to find out what on earth this much-gossiped about bonus is going to be. Supposedly this afternoon. Hope I don't miss it by leaving early. Wow, I really hate waiting.

Obsessions For the next couple of weeks, my mind will be completely occupied by 3 things, and probably never all 3 at once (I'm not much good at that multi-tasking thing): - if changing jobs is going to happen (and what I'm going to say if I leave this one) - a kitten - Christmas The first one will be sorted out, change or not, probably by later today. The second one, who knows? There are certain requirements - like a kitten who is around 8 weeks old, female, and likes BF. I could just come home with one, but cats either love or hate BF. I wouldn't want to adopt one only to get her home and find out she hates BF. And the last one, well, if you don't know when that one will be over, you need help. I've still got a fair amount of Christmas shopping to do, and I've already spent too much money. Not too much in the sense that we'll be going hungry or anything, or that bills won't get paid, just that I may not be able to pay the whole amount off on January 1. Enh, these things happen. Hopefully it's the last year. And you never know - even though I've heard the word 'small' in the same sentence referring to our bonus, I could get a pleasant surprise. If not, the world won't stop turning. Speaking of Christmas shopping . . . it's amazing how two peoples' ideas of what makes a good gift can differ so greatly. At Walmart, I saw this really cute children's Pooh chair and table. We have 3 friends/family having babies in the next few months, so I figured surely they'd be a good gift for one of them? I mention it to BF, and he makes this funny 'what-are-YOU-on?' face. Apparently he thinks it's very gauche (obviously my word, not his) to give gifts for a baby when it's not born yet. I never would have thought of that. So he's been told he has to be with me when we get gifts for his family, or at least have input. My brothers were easy to shop for - I cheated and did theirs online this year. Less than 3 minutes for 3 brothers, baby. BF was, of course, easy to shop for. The hard part is remembering what I've gotten so I don't overspend. Single friends are done, coupled friends I still need to check if they had planned on a no-gift-exchange Christmas. Mum is hard for once. It seems like several years in a row, I've gotten her spa gift certificates or something she's specifically asked for. I don't to be monotonous, but she hasn't mentioned anything yet this year. And BF's family I'm leaving up to him. Gotta love the holidays.

I want a kitten. I think I've become obsessed. I'll probably stop at the petstore again on my way home tonight. Pictures like these don't help my cause. People say to me, "Kittens become cats eventually, you know." Duh. Like I don't know that. I've adopted one cat as almost full grown, and two as 8-week-old kittens. I don't mind that it'll eventually be a cat - I love cats. I just want to have that kitten phase again. And I'd willingly go through the puppy thing again, too. But only if I knew there was no chance of having to give him up again. Maybe I'm weird. Maybe my 'biological clock' is ticking in a weird way such that pets will satisfy me for now. Who knows. Or maybe I just feel like my life needs more animals in it. We're going to need a bigger house soon. But I like this one for now. It's plenty big enough for another cat, and perhaps a dog a little later on. I want to make it our own before we think of parting with it. It still needs a lot of work. I want to be able to have my 'me' time (read: gym/swimming/etc) but not feel like it's taking away from 'us' time and 'home' time. Yes, the old job would allow me that. Don'tcha just love my segue? So, tomorrow I'll talk with my old boss, and we'll see what happens from there.

An Update I was waffling yesterday after going out to the field yet again . . . wondering if 'moving backwards' was such a good idea. But now I'm back in the office again, and it makes the decision easier. Still the guilt is going to take a while to get over. And another sucky thing - I would need to hand in my notice a week from tomorrow, since the end of the year seems as good a time as any. But the company Christmas party is on the 20th (2 days later) . . . hmmm, somehow I don't think I'll be going . . .

Addicted to Chaos? I'm starting to wonder. I'll be brief for now, since CSI: Miami is on in about 5 minutes, and it's like an institution in my house. =) It seems I'm not destined for a stable life. Just when I think things might finally be settling down for a while, something comes along. Thank goodness it wasn't one of those 'oopsy-daisy' things . . . One of my old co-workers has successfully made me think seriously about returning to my old job. I made it very clear to him that I didn't think the GM would pay me what I would ask for, and listed a few other things that would be really hard to part with from my new job, but he said that he was pretty sure they'd do basically anything to have me back. It's nice to feel wanted. It's nice to have leverage, too. =) But I'm not evil. I'll work out what the RRSP-matching, pension plan, and better benefit plan would work out to in dollars, give them a high number, and negotiate from there. But I truly think I'd be much less stressed out and probably a lot happier at my old job. And I'd get to work with my friend! Some would say that's not a good thing, but having already developed a work-environment relationship with her, I think it would be all good. So long as we still make sure we go out as friends occasionally instead of always being co-workers! *sigh* We could get a puppy and actually keep him sometime in late spring! Road Rules of Etiquette Especially applicable for Calgary drivers!! After a few too many frustrating drives lately, I thought I would take it upon myself to provide some rules of etiquette when it comes to driving. Maybe I'll submit them to the AMA to include as part of their driving courses. 1. There's a reason for the term 'Sunday Drivers.' You have no place being on the road at 7am on a Tuesday morning. 2. Just because you pay your share of taxes DOES NOT give you the right to go 60km/h in the lefthand lane down Glenmore Trail when the speed limit is 80km/h. It does, however, give me the right to honk at you and gesture as I please. 3. Same goes for doing 90km/h in the fast lane on the Deerfoot. It's called the fast lane for a reason. 4. Another one for Glenmore drivers . . . everyone knows that the 2 righthand lanes back up for the Deerfoot turnoff. Don't be a jerk and sail down the lefthand lane only to stop dead and hold up traffic cuz you can't get into the turnoff lane at the last second. 5. Yes, semis are a pain in the butt. Especially at 6:45am. But if you're going to pull out from behind one, into traffic that is going the speed limit, DO THE SPEED LIMIT. 6. Every single car comes equipped with turning signals. USE THEM. And shut them off once you're done. 7. Construction crews give you plenty of warning if a lane is being pinched out. In case you have trouble interpreting these signs, they mean 'GET OUT OF THIS LANE AS SOON AS YOU CAN' not 'Be an ass and drive right up to the last possible second so that some poor sap has to slam on his brakes to let you in.' Cuz if that poor sap is me, you can be sure I will let you scrape my car before I make space for you. 8. Don't tailgate someone who is already speeding. If I'm going 90km/h in an 80 zone, and you come roaring up behind me, I'll slow down to 80 just to piss you off. 70 - or the speed of the car beside me - if I'm already in a bad mood. 9. You're not going to get home any faster by pulling up right behind the car that's only barely through the intersection. I could go on and on and on and on . . . instead, go check out what urlLink Katie did that I wish I had the guts to do more often. Cuz all these rules go double for anyone in one of those ridiculously huge SUVs. In fact, you should have to get a special license to drive those things.

'Mummy, where's my mummy? They've taken her away!' 'We'll help you find your mummy, son. Hop up on the sleigh.' Up beside the bag of toys little Joey hopped, But they hadn't gone far when Santa stopped. Unharnessed all the reindeer and Joey wondered why, Then he heard a faroff booming in the sky. Six white boomers, snow white boomers, Racing Santa Claus through the blazing sun, Six white boomers, snow white boomers, On his Australian run. Pretty soon old Santa began to feel the heat, Took his fur-lined boots off to cool his feet, Into one popped Joey, feeling quite okay, While those old man Kangaroos kept pulling on the sleigh. The Dreaded Christmas Parties are Upon Us Ahhh, the lovely Christmas season. Too much shopping, too many parties, too much drinking, too much being fake, too much to do, and no where near enough time for it all. I think the worst part is the Christmas parties. Especially the company ones. Some are great BFs company one was this past weekend. A fancy dinner, with dancing and booze and a hotel room in Banff are all paid for. And for a few, a special rate on an extra night at the hotel. We went up to Banff on Friday this year, wanting to take advantage of the opportunity and hopefully not be as stressed out as last year. All was good on Friday. We got up to Banff, and the weather was perfect only about minus 2C with plenty of big white flakes falling. BF did his Starbucks inspection in less than half the time expected, we checked in leisurely, and had a leisurely dinner at the Old Spaghetti Factory. Service in a small town is just so much better than in the big city. We joined up with some other early-arrivers for drinks and had a fun night, but not letting loose completely in anticipation of the real party on Saturday night. I had these big plans to make use of the Banff Centre facilities and either workout or go for a swim sometime on Saturday. I mean, the dinner wasnt until 6pm, that should be plenty of time, right? We got up leisurely, had another leisurely meal, and then remembered about the requisite socializing at the RosenCrown at 1pm. For some stupid reason, I was still stuck on this whole idea with working out, and left the pub after a half-hour. By the time I got back to the Banff Centre, found my swimsuit, and hemmed and hawed over whether to swim or workout, it was 2:30pm . . . and then I wandered all over trying to find the entrance to the swimming pool that was taunting me just up the hill from the sidewalk. When all was said and done, I returned to the room in a huff and took a bath . . . I could have simply stayed at the pub, relaxed and socialized for another hour. Uh oh. Bad start. Thats what I hate the most about these parties the feeling of needing to look your absolute best. Which usually involves at least a couple of hours of frustration, fussing and sometimes a few tears. Well, for me anyways. And then, youre rarely comfortable during the party itself, because dresses have this sneaky way of looking oh-so-good in the change room, and then mysteriously tightening justthismuch on the night of the party. Or youre blissfully unaware of that glaring bulge or roll in the change room, only to have it screaming for attention in the bathroom mirror once its too late to change your mind. Last year, my car broke down, I forgot my shoes and camera, my hair wouldnt work right, and my dress was uncomfortably snug. In addition, I left my chapstick behind in the hotel room which made me miserable all night long. So I thought I would be smarter this year. We went up a day early, I was pretty sure Id thought of everything I could possibly need, the dress was a stretchy-cottony type of material, and I had my shoes. I was going to forego fussing with my hair, because I get compliments even when its just curled and left loose, and I like it that way. What could possibly go wrong? The fabulous dress strikes again. It was a style definitely meant for smaller/skinnier/less-endowed girls. I thought it looked great in the change room, but I was still wearing a bra then, and duct tape definitely had no hiding place. Plus, I felt naked. Plus, once the party started rolling, the alcohol was doing nothing for me. Ever had that? Where you're anticipating a party thats going to involve drinking, and its almost like just because you expect that youre going to get drunk, you cant? Thats how it was . . . I didnt have lots to drink, but I wasnt even getting a buzz, and my stomach started protesting after only 3-4 drinks. Lovely. Meanwhile, BF is having a grand old time, drinking and socializing away, leaving me alone at the table for much of the night. He never means to leave me alone Im a big girl, I can take care of myself and know most of the people there, and hes just a social kinda guy. But between that and not being able to get drunk I was kinda miserable. Then we got kicked out of the hall, and tradition states that the real partiers congregate in the bosss room to continue drinking. I missed out last year, and BF stayed behind with me. This year, I was miserable again, not seeing the point in pretending to drink with other drunk people. But I wasnt going to make BF stay behind too. I was asleep sometime around 2am, and found out the next morning that BF didn't crawl into bed until after 4am. You can be pretty oblivious in a king-sized bed. Now, had this just been an impromptu gathering of friends, with me in comfortable clothes and drinking just cuz it tasted good, I probably would have had a blast and gone home plastered and happy (and had spectacular drunken sex, too, but shhhhh, I didnt say that). Im very tempted to claim a family commitment to get out of MY company party. I dont need another reason to be miserable for the sake of posterity, especially when there are so many other reasons to be stressed out at this time of year.

What Goes Around, Comes Around So all I can think of is that I must have been Hitler or something in a past life. Cuz I don't know what I've done to deserve this. Yes, I need to rant, and rant something horrible. But I'm at work, so this is about the best I can do. Two weeks ago, on my last day of work at the old job, the painter was FINALLY supposed to show up to do touchups around the house - after standing me up before Christmas. I was not a happy camper to begin with. He was sitting in his truck in front of my house when I pulled up. As I approached, he pulled forward - so, of course, I pulled in behind him to park in front of my house. I was just parking when his reverse lights went on and he plowed straight into my car. Pretty darn cut and dried - he hit my car. I was stationary. He got out, and said "Sorry about your car. You must have snuck up on me there." I didn't say a word. I was livid. I checked out my car, and it wasn't too bad, but the bra was cracked, as well as the front bumper and grill. He was driving an '84 GMC pickup - there wasn't even any paint transfer. I still hadn't said anything by the time we got in the house, and it only made me madder that he reeked of smoke and he was making the house smell bad. I said I'd get his insurance information after he'd done with the painting, and showed him all the spots around the house. After going out to his truck for his tools, he said I might as well take it down while he was working to save time. Of course, first thing I do when he's out of earshot is frantically call BF. I'm absolutely horrible at dealing with situations like this, and after nearly being screwed one too many times, I wanted to make sure I didn't get shafted because I was too nice. My car was the only one with any damage, and it wasn't even my fault, so I was the only one with something to lose. BF said to make sure I got his insurance info (duh - but sometimes my brain goes numb), to go file a police report as soon as he was gone, and to even go down to the builder's showhomes down the street just to make sure they knew about it. I got his insurance info, and called them as soon as he was gone. I called the police to find out which district I was in, but they don't like to have reports filed for less than $1000 damage. So I just talked to a constable about who would likely be found at fault. She was really nice to me, but gave me the truth - if he was reversing, he was at fault. But because there were no witnesses, it was his word against mine as far as insurance was concerned, and if he decided to lie and say he wasn't moving, it might end up being a 50-50 case. I got pictures of my car and couldn't do much else, seeing as it was the weekend. On Monday, my car was booked in for an oil change anyways, so I had them do an estimate at the same time. $922 worth of damage, and it's barely visible. But not quite $1000, so I didn't think I'd get a warm reception if I tried to file a police report, just so my version was down on paper. I called my insurance company just to make a record of it, and she gave me a more positive outlook - well, he's at fault because he was backing up at the time. So I felt a little better. Let it go a week without hearing anything before I started to get concerned and called his insurance rep back. She said that he hadn't given them a statement yet, but the version he gave to his broker suggested he didn't think he was at fault. That I could call my insurance company and have them deal with it, or wait until he gave them a statement. Then yesterday, I got home to find a message from this same lady. He claims it wasn't his fault, so there wasn't anything more she could do. Call my own insurance rep and have them deal with it. I called her back today, absolutely livid, to find out exactly what he was saying. He is now claiming that I ran into his car!! That I just pulled up in too much of a hurry and hit the back of his truck. I was dumbfounded. She said again that there was nothing more she could do, and to have my insurance company deal with it. Well, why should I have to file a claim and take a hit on my insurance just because he's a fuckin dumbass and a liar to boot? I don't think so. So I called his work. I wasn't really sure what I was going to say, but figured I'd at least get his phone number. I had to try really hard not to be bitchy, because I'd dealt with the receptionist/dispatcher before, and I knew this wasn't her problem nor did it involve her. I asked to have his number because I didn't get any contact information when the accident happened. She was apologetic, but said she'd been specifically instructed not to give out any information. I couldn't let it go at that. I let her know that I was extremely upset, because he was now lying about the accident and I wanted to be able to speak with him directly. I asked if I could speak to his boss instead, and now I'm just waiting for a phone call. Do I have an invisible sign on my car that says "Hit me, then take advantage of the situation"?? Cuz I'm sure starting to wonder. When it was the Dodge, I figured maybe it was just that particular car. But now I'm having the same luck with a brand new car, so I can only wonder if it's something to do with me. I want to beat up that fat, dumbass old man of a painter for being a liar and making my life difficult. I suppose it could be worse . . . someone could have smashed up my car while I wasn't around, and I wouldn't even have anyone to blame. But it still burns my noodle that there are such dishonest people out there. Don't mess with me, mean people, because I'm quickly learning from BF how to cause a stink when you've done me wrong.

Jumping on the Bandwagon 'Oh ho, the Wells Fargo wagon is a-comin' down the street Oh please let it be for me . . .' Don't ask. OK, ask. I was part of The Music Man in high school. There. But it has nothing to do with my post. "Bandwagon" just makes me think of that song. How can you tell it's a boring day? I've been catching up on reading blogs since coming back to the boring job, and I realized something - it's a new year. Sure, I went to the party and everything, but I never really thought about the implications. So - since I have nothing better to do for now, I figured I'd jump on the whole reflection/resolution bandwagon. Don't worry, I'll refrain from quoting The Music Man again . . . I was looking back on entries from December and January of last year, and I'm reminded of the drama I felt at the time. I was having endless crises involving my car, my living situation was in upheaval, and life in general felt like a big soap opera. It might seem like this year has started out in a similar fashion, but unlike last year - where the drama had no definite end in sight - this year I know it has an end, and that makes it much easier to handle. I know that, once the job transition is over, things will settle down once again. Last year, at this time, I was in awe of all the changes 2002 had brought for me. All the firsts, all the dramas, all the achievements, all the good and the bad. 2003 hasn't been much different. I've been nothing but tickled pink with the new car, officially moved in with the BF, soon after bought our first house together, adopted a dog only to give him up a few months later, changed jobs (only to realize the first job was a better fit), and had some close friends and family start families of their own. As much as these events have been mostly good, I really hope 2004 is a year of stability for me. I don't want my career situation to change for at least another couple of years. I don't want to move. I just want to make my house more homey, maybe add some more pets to our little unofficial family, and generally have life settle down. Not settle down settle down, in the common negative sense, just settle down as in a lack of upheaval. Cuz I'm a much better girlfriend, cat-mom, and friend when I'm not distracted by stress. I need to mention that I hate resolutions. I think they're retarded (for lack of motivation to find a more sophisticated word). And that seems to be a common thing among the people I talk to and those whose blogs I frequent. And I HATE those bloody New-Years'-Resolutioners at the gym. This year, my resolution just happens to coincide with the new year. But it's the same resolution I've had since the fall - I just got sidetracked due to having a second job and whatnot. Now I won't have two jobs, and I'll have plenty of time to go to the gym. But my initial efforts will likely be hampered by a crowded gym where my favorite machines are constantly in use by people who probably won't last past Valentine's Day. At the very least, I'll have my swimming program. I'm getting pretty excited about that. January 26 will see me half-drowning after dinner, but by mark my words - by Valentine's Day, I'll be a regular fish again. So, these are my hopes/goals (NOT resolutions!) for 2004: - a fitter, healthier, slimmer (and happier!) me - no changes in job - no new home - an improved current home - with a garage, a deck, a fenced yard with grass, and a more organized basement - more financial stability, in the form of no credit card debt And that's the end of my bandwagon-jumping for now.

Pep Talk To Myself I need to reassure myself that I've made the right decision. I've just come out of my exit interview, and I almost feel like crying. I need to remind myself of the reasons I made this decision in the first place, because now I'm doubting myself. I know it's just an emotional response, and logically I know I've given it a lot of thought so therefore I must have made the right decision. But when you get told outright that someone's very disappointed that you're leaving, because they've been happy with your work and found you to be bright . . . well, it's hard not to have an emotional response to that. I know I've made the right decision. It bothers me endlessly to come into work not knowing if people are going to have time to give me things to do, and it makes me feel guilty and useless to spend my days playing games and blogging and surfing the internet. But oh man, I'm sure with the drilling program underway that they would have found more things for me to do. No matter . . . a month later I would probably be in the same position of being bored again. The hours here aren't flexible, and I dislike feeling like a child because I have to get approval for everything. I don't like taking the train, and to boot, I've been sick far more often since working downtown. I get migraines fairly often, and I get stressed out - neither of which was really a problem at the old job. So why don't I feel any better yet? What if I get restless again? Will I be able to deal with it better than last time, when I quit and got this job? I'm tired of changing jobs all the time, and this one has been particularly stressful to me. Think of the summer . . . when the days get longer, and warmer, and instead of being stuck downtown from 7:30 to 5pm, you can be out. The work will likely ease up, and you can take courses, and likely work shorter hours. You'll have time to work out, which will definitely make you feel better. You'll have time to visit with the new little people in your life. You'll be less stressed out when you come home at night. OK, I think that's helped.

It was still great seeing my two aunts and uncles, along with my papa, mum and middle bro. New Years' Eve was fun, too. A little less eventful than last year, but good times nonetheless. Once or twice I heard "I miss Shari", but that's completely understandable. I hope our little tradition of gathering at the snewton household doesn't end with the beginning of families. I'm so excited about the next two babies to come. Well, not much else to tell. I'm addicted to playing Showdown Solitaire when I have someone to play with, Pogo games when I don't, and listening to my new Evanescence CD. So that's what I'm off to do.

More Random Thoughts The lingering effects of Valentine's Day. I love my boyfriend. But lately, I seem to get bitter from time to time. I don't know if it's justified, or if I just have unrealistic expectations. But I still get bitter. I hate Valentine's Day. Hate the commercialism, anyways. Don't care to make reservations to eat in an overcrowded restaurant just to say I had a date on Valentine's Day. Don't care to be made to feel like I have to buy a gift, or a cheesy card, or make some contrived gesture of affection. Those things are better left for spur-of-the-moment when a genuine emotion strikes. And I'd like to think I do that. Get up early one day to make breakfast before work. Take a few extra moments another day to make him lunch before work. Go out of my way after work to pick up some Pepsi, cuz I know how much he enjoys it and I also know that we've been out for a few days. Volunteer the idea of a hot tub party cuz he's had some shitty birthday parties in the past. You know, little things to show I'm thinking about him. That he's important to me, that I want him to be happy. Maybe I'm blind. Maybe he does things and I just don't see them for what they are. But every now and then, when I start to get bitter, I think pretty hard, look pretty closely. I don't see a lot. He'll plan for months to save up for a gun, a tattoo, a toy. Any trips or special occasions are planned and instigated by me. And see - I get bitter. I hate being bitter, because I like being happy. I like how people like being around me when I'm happy. Anyways. Babies. Babies, babies, babies. What more can I say? For 18 years, they were strange, foreign beings to me, and all of a sudden, even three aren't enough to keep me happy. I can't get enough of them. Two in particular are special to me, and I've been strictly informed that I am NEVER to have a favorite. No problemo. They're all my favorites. =) People ask me all the time, "So when are you going to have one, then?" Are you kidding? I have things perfectly right now: I get to be happy and excited to see them, maybe some day they'll think I'm cool (cuz I'm not Mom), and I get to go home by myself and still be excited to see them the next time. I can afford to buy all the cool toys and cute outfits for no reason. And - because, of course, I plan on having some ONE DAY - I get to learn! Even better than Mom's advice is to actually see a friend go through it, see what works and what doesn't, see the little things nobody thinks to tell you until after it happens. I'd like to pay off a few more debts, afford a bigger house with a real yard, and have the option to say, "Honey, I think I'd like to stay home after this year is up." And I'd like to be married first, and not worry that the father-to-be isn't as thrilled as I am. I'm too selfish right now, but give me a coupla years. You know, my mum was married shortly at 26, first child (me!) at 27. It startled me the other day to realize that I'm now almost 25 myself . . . and that, if things keep heading down this path, I may follow a similar timeline. But there's always the "who knows?" clause. And that's what keeps things interesting. I won't always be bitter. Just until BF catches on that something's wrong, coaxes me into talking, and asks what he can do to make it better. Cuz if things really were bad, you know I wouldn't still be here. Obviously something keeps me around, I just forget that sometimes. Friends. They're constantly shifting. I enjoy seeing more of people I didn't a year ago, and not simply because of the baby incentive (even tho they tease me to the contrary). People I swore I'd make regular time for have almost fallen off the charts. Not out of malice, not on purpose, things just change. Well, it's Friday night, and it's time for some much-needed socializing. Hope you all have a great weekend! All . . . two? . . . of you? I think I'm optimistic . . . =)

It's a Baby Bonanza, Folks!! I got a rather shocking (to me, at least - BF claims to have expected it) phone call last night. There's another baby in the world! The next little one - who wasn't due for another 4 to 5 weeks - made his appearance yesterday evening. Despite being early, it sounds like he's a fairly healthy 5lbs 3 oz, and most importantly, breathing on his own. I guess they decided that his mom's blood pressure was getting too high to risk it any longer. I don't know much at this point except mom is probably pretty rough, and the as-yet-nameless baby is doing OK. BF's happy that he has another boy to corrupt. As he put it, "I'm glad at least C has a boy. Girls aren't really my specialty." And with two boys, his secret ambition of eventually being known as "Uncle Pixie-Sticks" stands a better chance of coming true. I just have to sigh at that. I will have my hands full doing damage control for their poor parents. =) I'm just excited that there's yet another baby around. Boy or girl, they're all new and equally special to me. And no, it doesn't make me want them just yet. The more time goes by, the more sure I am that I want a family eventually , but just not quite yet. There's a few little things for now - being too selfish, not being financially stable enough, not being married, and not having BF on board quite yet. He still has a tendency to maintain that he doesn't want kids, but it slips more and more into casual conversations that he sees himself having them one day. And he's always been that way . . . he makes it seem like he's totally against something, especially when "everyone's doing it" (ie serious relationships, moving in together, getting married, etc), until all the fuss has died down and he decides he's good and ready. And I like that. I wouldn't feel right being with someone where I'd constantly be worrying whether they're doing things because they feel pressured to, and not because it's right for them. I've never had to worry about that with BF, and I like it. So - that should be it for babies for now. 3 little ones in just over a month . . . I'm not even participating and I'm exhausted! =)

I really can't think of a good title for this post, since it's just going to be ramblings, so onward we go . . . Friday was so unreal. Although I thought the new parents might want their space, I couldn't resist the urge to go and visit them in the hospital. Besides, I rationalized, New Daddy wouldn't have left me a message with their room number if he didn't really want visitors, right? We made it there barely a half-hour before visiting hours were over. Baby Shari was feeding when we got there, so Dad came out and gave us all the details and stories of the past day and a half. They certainly weren't afforded the much simpler-sounding experience that BF's sister-in-law went through. But all in all, Mom looked really good when I saw her (briefly), though it was apparent both she and her husband were seriously lacking in rest. So, I employed more willpower on Saturday, having been told that I'd get a phone call when they arrived home. Went to swimming in the morning, and that helped to keep me patient. But with BF on call and away working all day, by 6pm I was getting restless. So I ventured a call to their house. It turns out they'd been home a few hours, and our other friends were already over there. I did my best to gloss over the slightly hurt feelings, because it's perfectly understandable that they would have plenty more important things on their mind than making sure they called everyone. I asked if they'd eaten, and when the answer was no, I offered to pick up food on my way over, so at least I didn't feel completely useless. =) I was so excited - despite visiting them at the hospital the previous night, I still hadn't met Shari because she was under a blanket, feeding at the time. Dad looked a little haggard, but surprisingly enough, Mom looked pretty darn normal. She was just like her normal self, albeit probably still very tired. And Shari is so incredibly perfect. She's not even my baby, but I think she's perfect. The best part was, after we'd finished eating, Shari's daddy got up and placed her in my arms without a word. I've never had people trust me like that before. It's always been "Do you want to hold him/her?" because I'll never ask. I know that part of it was the fact that the other 5 people were heading out for a smoke, and being the only non-smoker, I'd be the only one staying inside. But still - he didn't say "Wanna take her while we go out?" or he could have even placed her in her crib or something . . . it just felt really good to be treated like that. And another thing I quite enjoyed (tho you'll all think I'm crazy for it). Every time I've had a baby in my arms (OK, the whole 3 or 4 times), as soon as they start crying in the slightest, someone (Mom, Grandma, a closer relative) will come rushing up and take the baby away. And this has only served to re-inforce my anxiety when a baby cries. But Shari started wailing on more than one occasion, and while Mom and Dad kept an eye on her, nobody seemed to think that it meant I shouldn't be holding her anymore, or that she needed to be snatched away. I'm so excited about this new little family. I hope we continue to be a regular part of their lives for years and years to come. My parents never really had close family friends that visited often . . . so it would be nice to be those close family friends this time. And who knows? Maybe by the time they're thinking about baby #2, I'll be ready to join them?

Clowns to the left of me, Jokers to the Right . . . Here I am, Stuck in the middle with you Well, it's not the most appropriate title, but the song comes to mind when I think of what I want to write. It really feels like BF and I are stuck in the middle - he may disagree, but that's how I feel. "Clowns to the left of me . . . " So they're really not clowns, but I have one group of friends that is predominantly single and/or still living at home (read: basically responsibility-free). I don't see much, if anything, of these friends anymore, as I'm sure I've eluded to several times before. I hear/read about all these exciting things they get up to, and I feel a little left out. But the bar scene doesn't hold much attraction for me anymore. And while I'd like to think I'm open to trying new things, our tastes in music/movies/food tends to differ greatly, and I'm a little cheap when it comes to spending money on things I'm not sure I'll like. If I was single, it might be different - there'd be some motivation in trying new things, mainly to meet new people and possibly make some connections. But since I have someone at home that I'd like to share fun times with once the weekend comes, there really isn't much motivation. Also not helping is that these are friends I had before BF, and while it's not that they don't get along, BF is a man's man and doesn't find much attraction in being the only guy in a gaggle of girls. "Jokers to the right . . . " Again, they're not jokers, but then there's my other distinct group of friends. And they've all got even more responsibility than me - a house to look after, as well as babies. I hang out with these friends the most. But again, I feel a little left out. The two women can (and probably do) talk for hours about their babies, the troubles their having, and little tricks they're finding out. Sure, I can ask questions and listen, but it's not really relevant to me yet. And of course they're not about to go out and party. "Here I am, stuck in the middle with you . . . " And that about sums it up. Going out just the two of us is only so much fun for so long. Eventually you need a few more people to make it more lively and interactive. Cuz we've heard each others' stories throughout the week. And the few couples we've met in the last little while have some little quirk or other that prevents us from becoming good friends, or hanging out more often. One of them makes us really uncomfortable, because they are just not a good couple. She bashes him, he just takes it, and it's really awful to watch. Another one does the long distance thing, so we only hang out once in a long while when she's in town (and not otherwise pre-occupied). Don't get me wrong - I wouldn't change my life right now for anything. It's just hard being stuck between two very different sets of friends and feeling a little left out with both. I think we should start saving up for that trip to Jamaica . . . =)

And you're giving us plenty to rally around, Iggy and Conroy and Commodore and Gelinas and Kipprusoff and all the rest that I'm ashamed to say that I can't name off the top of my head. I'm mentally bored and it's making me restless at work. Already. I was hoping I'd get a few more months along before it hit, but apparently not. A few weeks ago, I got two calls from a lady wanting to talk to me about a job that she thought really suited my skills and experience. She felt so strongly that she called again a week later (I never got the original message). It was so tempting, but in the end, I knew it would be best if I didn't even know what the job was. So I left her a message saying I already had a job. *sigh* So since changing jobs is just not an option, I'm really pushing for my employer to help me out with a course. Figure if I'm gonna be at this job for a while yet, I might as well start working toward SAIT's Bachelor of Applied Petroleum Engineering. Unfortunately, it's not a designated degree, but hey, it'll keep me occupied for a while. Then maybe once I've exhausted that option, BF will be exploring transfers or other diversions. But since the head honcho is outta town for a while, I gotta sit tight. And meanwhile, BF is going to school for his second semester of his apprenticeship. Making me veeeeerrrryyyy green with envy. I wish I was in school. Then again, I like my paycheques. I wish I'd gotten paid to go to school. He doesn't get much sympathy from me when he starts ranting about the government cutting back on their subsidy of the trades. The government didn't give me any help when I went to school, except to make sure I owed them plenty of money when I was done. And I didn't get to collect EI, either. I also wish I could distract myself with imaginings of how our backyard will look. Unfortunately, I'm giving up hope and am starting to think that it's not going to look any different come September. No mid-summer BBQs with friends, no lazy weekday nights on the deck with a beer, no backyard fires. It's BF's territory to get the garage going, and I'm sick of nagging. And until the garage is done, all our money is tied up with a lawyer. And as time ticks on, I draw closer to following in urlLink Leah's footsteps. In 10 days, I will have lived for a quarter of a century. A friend (and co-worker) keeps bugging me about being old. But it doesn't bother me. Sure, I feel old when I talk to my youngest brother - who's 18 - and reminisce about being that age again. But more than anything, it just makes me eager . . . hey, it's time to start living my life! No more of this, 'Yeah, that sounds cool, but . . . ' and more of 'OK, let's figure out how we can do this!' I've got a little practice under my belt - I never thought I'd have a house at this age, and I finally got back into swimming (and I'm sticking to it!). Now to keep the momentum going . . . Because I look around at my friends who have children now, and it hits home that if there are things I want to do, I have to do them now (if I plan on having a family one day) or be willing to wait until I'm almost retirement age. I know having kids doesn't mean your life ends, but many things become a lot more difficult, complicated and expensive to do. So, does all this rambling have a point? No, not really. Just letting you know I'm still alive somewhere out there. =)

I've Become One Of THOSE people!! Please, quick, someone kick my ass for me! Oh well, it was a voluntary decision. I always thought getting fit and losing weight went hand in hand. But my progress since starting swimming has been meager at best. So lately, I've been toying with the idea of dietary supplements to help things along. I've always been a big advocate of simple common sense - exercise and eat healthier foods, and you'll lose weight. It's that simple. But I've been swimming regularly for 5 months now, and I can tell I'm definitely more fit, but I'm having trouble shaking the bit of chub I'm always trying to get rid of. I've tried Xenadrine EFX (the Canada-friendly version) off and on, with the only effect being that it gives me the same energy boost I'd probably get from a few cups of coffee. I tried TrimLife (ephedrine-free, of course) for a few days (their 'free 7-day sample', which, if taken at the recommended dosage really only lasts 3 days), but it wasn't really any different than the Xenadrine. And I couldn't find it in any stores up here, and that made me nervous. So I paid a visit to a local urlLink GNC store. I figured if I was going to break my own rule, I'd better damn well do it right. And getting advice from a real live person seemed more reliable to me than written accolades on the internet. Turns out they have a reasonably new product that seems to be immensely popular. She said that they were having a hard time keeping it on the shelves. (I won't mention the name since I'm starting to feel like a walking advertisement for weight loss products.) I glossed over that part (can we say "so buy it now!"?), since she had something good things to say that had nothing to do with selling me a product. Comes with a 30-day guarantee, so if it reacts badly with me, or does nothing, I can get my money back. That makes me feel a little better. Plus, I know that a simple supplement isn't going to work wonders and 90% of the effort still has to come from me. Maybe since I just finished a 5-month course of urlLink Accutane , it doesn't seem like such a bad thing to take some different ones to help me lose a little weight. But I sure hope the trend doesn't continue. I definitely don't want to be one of those people who has tried 15 different types of supplements for weight loss - and is STILL fat. *L* Today marks Day #1 of my month-long effort . . .

The Weekend Away Just cuz I don't have much else to say these days . . . here's how the out-of-town wedding was . . . Friday Despite having the day off work, I was on the go from shortly after 7am. BF's ride didn't show up, so I drove him to SAIT, then ran around for a few last minute things before getting my hair cut. It's nice and short now, and I love it! Anyways, we finally made it out of the city around 2pm, only to come across construction just outside of the city. Friday at 2pm on the first nice weekend so far, and they weren't even doing any work - they just hadn't taken the cones down! It took us just over an hour for a distance that would have normally taken 10 minutes. Discovered a nail in one of the tires as we made a pit stop, had it repaired, and finally made it into Edmonton just after 6pm. Only silly me hadn't paid too much attention to the map when I made the reservations. I ended up taking us alllll the way past Edmonton into St. Albert before realizing where Kingsway was. Headed back into Edmonton and finally found the hotel. Kinda scuzzy, to be honest. But we were only paying $69/night, so we figured we'd deal. As we walked in, there was a cop trying to rouse a passed-out drunk in the lobby. Got stopped by a guy on the way in - we both swear we heard him say 'Can you take a picture of me and my wife?' - who then walked over to this other very-well-built man. After a second or so of contemplation, they lifted their shirts to display very ripped abs. Turns out there was a body-building competition that weekend, in addition to an arm-wrestling competition, and several rugby teams were also staying at the hotel. Dumped off our bags, and then headed back out again to visit West Ed. The plan had initially been to enjoy the Waterpark, but due to all the delays, there just wasn't enough time. So we just browsed - BF picked out his first shirt and tie in years - and had dinner at Hooters. By the time we were heading back, we'd decided that the badly-sagging bed just wouldn't do, and that we'd ask if we could upgrade the room. When we got back, it turned out there was only an executive suite - at $179/night - available. BF piped in that all we really wanted was a room with a bed that didn't sag so badly. After some more speedy typing, she said she could give us the executive suite for $89/night. Sounded like a helluva deal to me. It was in the nicer tower (as opposed to the mysteriously-odoured lowrise building), and huge. King size bed with big TV, separate room with couch and another big TV, and all the little extras like an ironing board (complete with non-functioning iron), extra toiletries, and a hair dryer. Like I said, it wasn't exactly a posh hotel, but this room was definitely better than the econojob we had before. Quite pleased with ourselves, we indulged in a nightcap before heading to bed. Tomorrow promised to be a long day. Saturday Buffet breakfast in the hotel was a tad disappointing. Amazingly enough, I was ready in record time - probably thanks to the short hair and a surprisingly relaxed attitude (I'm usually a basket-case while getting ready for special occasions). We left around 1pm to find the church, somewhere up near Ft. Saskatchewan. Although they didn't provide any maps with the invitations, they did put signs up on the road as we approached the church, which was pretty thoughtful. It was a quaint little countryside church, complete with that big tower bell. The weather was absolutely gorgeous - even hot - and my favorite part was when they rang the bell after the ceremony. The reception was surprisingly low-key, and by the time we left around 10:30pm or so, the place was already emptying out. The food was really good, the groom got pretty drunk early in the evening, the bride was stunning, and I had to endure an awkward moment with BF's father. My feet were killing me by the end of the evening (I have yet to find a pair of nice dress shoes/sandals that doesn't hurt after a full day of wear). Despite a rather pleasant day, it ended on a rather sour note. Since we were back so early, and only had his brother for company (his brother's wife stayed in her room with the baby), we were ready to sleep by midnight (geezers! *L*). BF kicked his brother out, and we were soon fast asleep. Only I got rudely woken up about an hour and a half later by this obnoxiously-loud knocking on the door. It was his brother again, claiming he knew we were in there and wanted us to let him in. The other younger brothers were with him. BF didn't wake up, and I was nice and warm under the covers. You'd think any normal person would give up after one or two knocks, especially at 1:30am. But no, not BF's brother. The knocking got louder, and he even took a couple of running starts at the door. I don't know if a neighbour called security, or if one of the younger boys finally convinced him to give it up, but it finally stopped after about 5 minutes. I was wide awake and very unimpressed, but BF was still fast asleep. But not long after the door-pounding stopped, the phone started to ring. Constantly. Around 8 rings, BF was starting to wake up, and by 10 he had crossed the room to pick it up. It was one of the younger boys asking if we could let them in so they could have some beer! BF gave him a piece of his mind. They even had the balls to call back after he hung up. BF said he picked up again, ready to let loose, and heard someone in the background say to just forget it, we were sleeping. I'd like to say I couldn't believe they did all that, but it really doesn't surprise me. BF's older brother is just that obnoxious. Sunday Despite the rude awakening the night before, Sunday turned out quite nice. Since the hotel restaurant was packed with Father's Day brunchers, we checked out and headed to the nearest Denny's. This was the best part - checking out. The girl behind the counter wasn't the one who'd given us the upgraded room. So she printed out our receipt, looked at the one printed out when we checked in, and said "Oh! This is supposed to be $69, not $89! I'll just change that for you . . . " It was so hard to keep from giggling, but I did until we were outside the hotel. We got an executive suite for 2 nights for less than most people would have paid for one night! Feeling VERY pleased with myself, it was a little easier to be patient when we got to Denny's and a 10-minute wait turned into 30 minutes. Over breakfast, we decided that we were both feeling too lazy to bother with the Waterpark and would just head home. And so we did. And we just missed the rain, so we got an entire weekend of lovely sunshine. And I was very glad to be back home, to our own bed, and our own comfy couch.
ARRGGHHHH!

Damn weather . . . damn banks, too . . . I'm not enjoying this weather anymore. I know rain is good for farmers and it makes everything green and it's been years since we've had decent rain in May & June . . . but I'm getting tired of it. Last weekend, we finally made the leap and got everything arranged for the fence. Got the materials delivered, friends invited to help, and the weather even seemed like it was going to cooperate. It took the majority of the day to get the posts cemented and crossbars screwed in. Around 4:30, it started raining, which was OK - a perfect time to pack it in before the game started. All that was left to do was slap in the vertical boards. Pretty easy work for me and BF to do on our own the next day. Slight snag - it poured ALL DAY Sunday. And I didn't mind at the time, since it seemed like a good day for a lazy rainy day. I figured we'd get it done during the week or, at the latest, the next weekend. Well, it rained all week. That, or I didn't really want to give up swimming when we could wait til the weekend. The weekend came and went, with more rain. We made an attempt on Sunday afternoon, though the ground was still muddy. Got a few sections up, but it was barely 1/4 done. And this week hasn't been much better. Yesterday we finally had a break from the rain in the evening, only to find that we couldn't do it anyways since the boards were wet and swollen. BF doesn't really understand my frustration . . . but I look ahead, and it seems like the next 2-3 weeks are completely spoken for. A wedding out of town this weekend, BF's exams next week, plans to visit a friend's farm next weekend, a likely-insane first week back at work for BF, and him being on-call the weekend after. And I wonder - if it takes us this long to get a measly fence up, how many months is it going to take for a garage? Which brings me to the next part of it - damn banks! They lent us extra money when we got a mortgage so we could build a garage, but it's being held in trust by the real estate lawyer. The condition being that the money would not be released until the building was complete and all permits issued. No big deal if you're having someone build it for you - just set up a payment agreement. Only problem is, we've since decided that the money we can save by doing it ourselves is well worth it. But we'd still have to pay someone to do the concrete pad. At one point, I swear I was told it wouldn't be a big deal to get the lawyer to pay a concrete company directly for that part of it. Which would have been great. But now they're saying that no-way-no-how are they letting us have a penny of OUR MONEY before everything's all done. Because it was written in as part of the approval. The kicker? We're still paying interest on this extra money, and I'm pretty darn sure the law firm is MAKING interest on it while it sits in their hot little hands. Fer cryin' out loud . . . they'll lend us over $160K for a house, but hang on FOR DEAR LIFE to another $11K to improve it - increase its value, even. The more time that goes by, the more determined I am to switch banks either when the mortgage term is up, or when we sell the house, whichever comes first. Damn laywers. Damn banks. I could get started on the government, but I'll restrain myself for today. I think I've ranted enough for one day. =)

If you don't see me for a while, it's probably 'cuz I've dropped dead of exhaustion . . . So I'm stepping up the swimming thing. I was swimming 3 days a week - Monday, Wednesday and Saturday - at 1.5 hours each time. But the Masters Club allows people to sign up for June/July/August, and my current program doesn't end until July 3. Which means that, until the end of June, I'll be swimming Monday thru Thursday, and Saturdays when I don't have other commitments (still all 1.5 hours each). I figure if I'm not fit by the end of the month, there's just no hope for me. Visual results from all this swimming have been slow in coming. After supplementing swimming with 2 gym workouts a week (just cardio - I had absolutely no desire to do weights), the scale began to give a little. Just a little, mind you. After more than 4 months of swimming, I have yet to reach a 10-lb loss. But my arms are starting to look nice and toned. =) So I decided a few weeks ago that I would track measurements as well as weight. This week was my first week of doubled-up swimming . . . Monday, I opted for the gym (so I could still watch the game!), Tuesday was Club practice, Wednesday was regular practice, and last night was another Club practice. I'm so tired and sore. And Saturday will be regular practice. I hope I can make all 4 next week. I can't believe that I used to swim as much as 9 times in 5 days - and then compete on the weekend! - back in my teens. Man, am I getting old! =) But it feels so good to be back in it. And in July 2005, I intend to kick some butt at the World Masters' Games in Edmonton . . .
