What's a person to do? I have never been terribly sure how to act around mentally handicapped people. I mean the obviously handicapped - Downs' syndrome is kinda different. I had a rather disturbing experience on my lunch break today. My friend and I were at the mall, and were taking a minute or two after eating to decide which direction we'd head in for some browsing. We were still sitting at the table when this man sat down right next to me (we were 2 sitting at a table for 4). Now, sometimes tables can be tough to find at lunchtime, but most people will politely ask before they sit down. So I turned and noticed that this guy was handicapped - seemingly enough so that I figured he must be with a group or at least a supervisor or something. Before I could say anything or get up to free the table, he turned to me, took my hand and began to pull my arm as if to pull me to him. He asked me how I was doing. Extremely uncomfortable and not sure how to react, I said with a nervous smile on my face "I'm fine, thanks" and quickly pulled away and got up. I felt kinda bad because I wasn't sure he knew what he was doing - I figured he must have thought I was his 'helper' or something - and didn't want to make a big scene. People nearby who witnessed it were giving me weird looks - in my confusion and awkwardness, I couldn't tell if they were sympathic or judgemental. I feel bad because had that been a child (probably the same mental capacity), I probably would have reacted very differently. I would have been gentle, amused, and looking around for a concerned Mom or Dad. Instead, I felt kinda violated and a little indignant that there didn't seem to be someone keeping an eye on him to prevent or relieve this awkward situation. When I got up, he did too, and seemed a little lost as my friend and I bee-lined for the washrooms. Am I a horrible person for this, or do most people tend to react like that?

'Talking It Over' can be highly over-rated . . . Today, I made the monumental mistake of forgetting the cardinal rule of communication - never 'talk it out' when one or both parties are still angry. I've had it, and I don't care of certain 'parties' read this anymore, I deal with things in my own way and this is one of them. Issues have come up at work, because I work with a friend. It was bound to happen eventually. Things have been slacking on her end lately, mostly due to recent surgery, and rather than say something, I figured she knew she wasn't doing the best job and would do something about it. Meanwhile, I'm getting stressed out because there have been a bunch of changes and I'm still trying to figure them out. And still get all the work done in a reasonable amount of time. And thus got silent at work. My thinking was - Don't bother saying anything. It's your problem that it makes you angry, she's not an idiot, she'll shape up soon enough. Only apparently my silence was making HER angry, and when she sent me an email at work instead of talking to me, it only made me angrier and blahblahblahblahblah whinewhinewhinewhine. Point being, we talked about it today. Good God! What kind of people think that telling someone you want to kill them is productive to solving a problem?! Or that you're so stressed out that going to work makes you want to kill yourself?! How helpful can it be, once you're finally talking to someone, to repeat five or six times that they're impossible to talk to? Attack me like that, and it's not talking things over, it's putting me on the defense. My brain will shut down and you won't get anything useful out of me. I tried really hard to stay logical and non-emotional, but in the end, I felt more hurt than anything. 'So tell her', you say? Yeah right, and have that happen all over again? Forget that idea. We talked about her quitting. She accused me of sending her mixed messages - hidden ones saying "I want you to quit" and direct ones saying "I never said I want you to quit." Don't freakin' look for hidden messages. Don't go to your mom or your sister to decipher an email I sent you - if you're not sure what I mean, ask me yourself fer cryin' out loud. "But you're impossible to talk to!" For the third time. Well, we're talking now, aren't we? I'm pretty sure she thinks things are all fine now, since we did talk about possible solutions for about 30 seconds. But they're not, at least not for me, and I hardly feel like bashing it out again, not after that. I'm left feeling like this was all my problem to begin with, that it's all my fault, and that because we work together, I made it her problem too. That I'm the reason she can't work, because she stresses out about work so much that she can't sleep. And on and on and on. So now I'm angry AND hurt. Because it's damn hard to separate the personal attacks from the constructive criticism. And there seemed to be plenty of the former, only a few of the latter. *sigh* 'Suck it up, princess', right? 'Be the bigger person and just forget about it.' Easier said than done.
Today's Lesson - Always Offer a Helping Hand . . .
The Picture of Innocence . . .

Happiness in the small things So I was pretty excited on Friday. Had to come down at some point. We finally decided a few things, BF and I. The biggest one that pretty much decided everything else - we'll start looking at selling the house next year. We're quickly running out of summer, and if we were to start a garage even in the next couple of weeks, it would mean a lot of sacrificed activites and a lot of hard work and probably a lot of worrying if the weather would cooperate long enough. So, with the promise of being able to look for a house with a garage already built, BF can live without one here. So we'll finish the yard, extend the fence to define a parking pad, and leave it at that. And that makes me feel a great deal better. I think it's going to be a nagging battle just to get the yard done, let alone a big project like a garage. There's just so many other things we'd hoped to be doing this summer. And I hate being a nag. But it needs to get done before it's too cold for sod to take, and sod will probably be the last thing we do. Meaning time is definitely not on our side. With that decision out of the way, a few others fell into place. I had figured that the money left over after the garage was built would be plenty for a second vehicle (or, more recently, a vacation). No garage = no extra chunk of money = creative thinking. I'll admit - I was pretty crushed when it sank in that a Hedonism vacation was unrealistic now. But this is one of the many things I love about BF - he wasn't fazed at all. When faced with new circumstances, he simply rolls with it. His brilliant suggestion was that we take a road trip - head out the door with some camping supplies and maybe a map, and not know exactly where we're going until we get there. This is another thing we talked about doing last summer. And you know what? That kind of a vacation makes me even more excited than some exotic beach destination. I love spontaneity, but it just isn't something that comes naturally to me. I'm still a little worried about getting the yard done before the summer's over, but perhaps with some creative thinking on my part I can avoid seeming like a nag. I'm slowly learning to find happiness in the small things - it certainly helps having BF around to remind me of everything we have when I get carried away worrying about what we don't.

*groan* That's the last time I ditch swimming for that long without a good excuse. My strokes felt (and probably were) sloppy and I'm sore today. That'll teach me to be lazy! On a much brighter note . . . for the last few months, I've casually mentioned a few times to BF that we should take a real vacation sometime this year, perhaps September or October since that might be the best work lull for the both of us. At first, I suggested that we just book a week off and cruise last-minute specials. So I mentioned it to BF again, but didn't get much of an enthusiastic response, so naturally figured it wasn't a top priority for him. But then, the other night, he came home and said, "So have you booked us a vacation yet?" I just about fell off the couch. I'd mentally dropped the idea of a vacation for the time being. But we're not getting any younger, still have that childless freedom, what better excuse could we have for such a vacation? Now I just have to see if BF agrees with my way of thinking . . . =)

Talk about timing! This past week has seen quite a few temptations and requests to add another feline to my current family. A frank discussion with BF a few weeks back revealed that, despite his 'maybe' answer when I'd ask about a kitten, two cats were more than enough as far as he was concerned. But earlier this week, a co-worker came back from lunch claiming he and another co-worker were going home with kittens that day - a waitress at the local lounge had a box full of kittens that were going back to BC with her mother if they weren't taken. I really really wanted to go and simply see these kittens, but I had a pretty strong feeling that if I went, the temptation would be too great. So I decided to test the waters again and called BF to see if his opinion still stood. It did. Le sigh. "A third cat is just going to make everything accumulate that much faster" (meaning clumps of fur and doodies). But then, not 2 days later, a co-worker approaches me about a former pet of hers. She'd given up a much-loved pet due to allergies, and the current owner could no longer keep it. But she also explained that it would probably need to be alone, and since I already have 2, that one didn't go very far. Later that day, I was told of another story - this one very sad. This lady's daughter's boyfriend had also previously given up a much-loved cat due to allergies. But this is where it got worse. It turns out the friend he gave it to just dumped the poor thing - declawed - and the Edmonton SPCA eventually picked it up and traced it back to the boyfriend through a microchip implant. Apparently the Edmonton SPCA doesn't put "older" cats up for adoption (this one's only 6 years old - how the hell is that old??), and it already had an appointment with the vet's table if nobody came to claim her. I called BF once again and told him the story. I guess I've asked too many times now, because his response was a sigh followed by 'If you want another cat that badly, it's up to you.' But I couldn't do nothing, knowing that I would most certainly find out if this cat got put down. My co-worker said she'd call her daughter and get her to find out if it was too late or not. This morning I got an update - the daughter tried to call for an hour last night but couldn't get through. As of yesterday, the cat only had a day to live. She called again this morning, and apparently caught the vet just after he gave the first injection (I guess they give a sedative first, then the lethal injection). What incrediblely fateful timing. I think my co-worker was so shaken up by the incident that she decided she was going to take the cat herself after all. (She'd previously decided her one cat was too old and cranky to introduce someone new.) So now I'm off the hook. Perhaps it's for the best - after talking to the vet, it turns out this cat will need a lot of work and attention because she's had such a rough life for the last little while. She's incredibly fearful and withdrawn. I doubt she would feel very secure with our two little playful monsters. But now I've kind of prepared myself mentally for another addition to the family . . . Part of me thinks I should take advantage of BF's resignation and adopt a kitten. And part of me thinks I should take this as a sign and keep things the way they are. Maybe wait until we have a bigger house with more space. What a close call for one very lucky kitty . . .

Stupid regulatory boards . . . As far as I'm concerned, the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board is full of retards. Remember? I got fired from there - I'm convinced because I was too smart. They're making everyone's lives a living hell in the oil & gas industry - they require that any and all testing be reported, and there are regulations about reporting the initial conditions when you drill a new well. This is nothing new. But it used to be all nice and simple - you could submit these tests electronically, and it was simple enough that a local company created nifty software that converts all the data into the proper format with all the required info, and will even prompt you if you're missing something. But now they have to go and completely change it. Nobody seems to fully understand what is required anymore, the updated software is FUBAR as far as I'm concerned, and nothing is working. It's making my working life a living hell. I'm so stressed out that apparently I'm waking BF up in the middle of the night to talk angry gibberish. But the government board is being so vague about the new formats and guidelines. And anytime I try and ask a question, I get a terse response that is rarely useful. GRRRRRRRRRRRRRR!!!!!!!!!!!!!

My Bad . . . Sheesh - I managed to make that whole post about me. I'd meant to briefly mention my friends' experience in comparison. It turns out the psychic described the physical looks of the men they were going to meet and end up with. I wish I'd known this before my session, as it would have been interesting to have been a little more coy and see if she'd describe my man. For them, she focussed a lot on career, telling Daisy she should be a hairdresser (she's a teacher! and loving it!), and Biskette that she should be a teacher ('been there, done that, wasn't for me' were her words, I believe). She didn't have much to say to me about work, except that I'd be happiest in anything with a humanitarian slant. I think that whole area is pretty gray anyways - people do what they do mainly to pay the bills. She said some things to Daisy that Biskette and I got downright indignant about. According to Daisy, the psychic basically told her she had to be thin to have a relationship. I argued that perhaps she simply picked up on Daisy's own insecurities, and that she meant she wouldn't feel confident and secure in a relationship until she was thin. But the more we discussed it, the more furious we got (Biskette especially). Apparently the psychic went so far as to discuss 'Curves' as a good gym to go to. She also told Biskette that her current man was no good for her. That he made her crazy and confused, and she needed to end it. She knows this, she's asked me and knows I agree, but it's hard to be logical about these things, especially when they involve you. Maybe meeting her gray-eyed, dark-haired man (at Stampede! - the psychic was very specific about this) will give her strength. =) Overall, it was a very interesting experience. I don't know if I'd spend the money to go again anytime soon . . . though immediately after, it seemed like an interesting idea to go see a different psychic and compare the readings. But at a roughly $80 experience ($60 for the session, $20 or so for noshies and coffee), I think I'll wait. Anybody else out there been to a psychic?

The Psychic Experience . . . Before my mind dumps it in favor of new info . . . Seeing a psychic has always been one of those things I've been sporadically curious about, but never enough to seek one out on my own. So when it became a good friend's birthday present, I jumped at the chance to join in. I was told it was at Conversations Tea Room at 3:30pm, and that was about it. We showed up, and none of us was sure what to expect. It seemed like a little coffee shop tailored to old ladies (elevator music, doilies everywhere, and a tad hoity-toity looking). Turns out the psychic just works out of the tea room - she takes a table at the back for the 'session'. The 'birthday' friend went first. Daisy and I ordered some hoity-toity tea-time noshies and settled in, attempting to gauge Biskette's reaction even though her back was to us. When she got back, she insisted that I go next, so I didn't get to hear any details until after my session. Daisy went last. She started out by having me write out my name, address and birthday. She appeared to be doing some math, and basically did a numerology reading (or so I'm guessing). Talked a lot about '5' people and their characteristics. This part of the reading didn't really impress on me. She just talked about general traits and such. Said that people live their lives in cycles of 9 years, and that I was in the 8th year of a cycle, meaning it would be a harvest year for me. A good year, an easy year. I liked the sounds of that, but she hadn't said anything spectacular yet. Next came the tarot cards. She had me shuffle and pick out 3 cards from 2 different decks. This part still remains a little fuzzy for me, as she seemed to be going rather quickly and it was all so vague, so I wasn't paying close attention. But I remember a '4 bowls' card, an 'Energy' card, 'Desire' and something about an arrow. She was talking on and on, almost losing me, until she suddenly leaned forward and said rather enthusiastically, "You're competitive!" This made me chuckle - it's very true. Any of my friends could tell you this, but this was a complete stranger whom I'd only met 10 minutes ago. But the suddenness of the statement was amusing. Now she had my attention, and it seemed that the longer she talked to/sat with me, the more accurate she got. From there, she went on to describe more of my personality - that I liked being a leader, that I hated being told what to do (this was a recurring theme), as well as being competitive (also a recurring theme). That a big thing I needed to watch out for was learning to cooperate with others, because nobody got to the top alone. That teamwork was a skill I needed to work on. And also that I live mostly in my head. This is also very true. I'm very analytical, very intelligent (her words, I'm not being a braggart), very logical. But that sometimes I let my head rule so much that I miss out on feeling and truly experiencing life. This struck a chord with me. That I need to work on 'getting out of my head and into my heart' a little more often, to actually feel things instead of thinking them. Again, all this coming from a complete stranger. Good advice, at the very least. After the cards, she moved on to palm reading. This part seemed a little textbook and generic to me, but interesting nonetheless. She stroked my palm and followed some of the lines, kinda muttered a little, said something about my love line meeting my life line, said I'd have a long life. Folded my hand over and played a little with that pointy bit of skin by my pinky (go ahead, make a fist - you'll see what I'm talking about), said something about 2 kids. I wasn't entirely sure if she said I had 2 kids, or would have . Then she moved on to my fingers, and this is where things got very amusing. She said I had very creative hands - but I've never considered myself terribly creative (if at all). She stroked them a little, and asked what I did. This stumped me - I said that I used to play piano, but nothing these days. She looked a little confused and kept playing with my fingers. She asked if I painted . . . no. Maybe drawing? Nope. Again, looking a little confused as if someone's telling her differently, and tries again. Pottery, maybe? No. At this point, I'm having trouble containing my amusement, just because she seems to be so confused and trying so hard. Again - flower arranging? Nope! Finally, she gives up, saying 'Well, you'd definitely be good at those things.' It gave me pause, just because she wouldn't give up on that tangent. Maybe I'm missing out on something? =) And finally, she moved on to the tea leaves. Unfortunately, she hadn't specifically told me to drink some of the tea sitting in front of me, so she handed me back the cup to take a few sips. It was good tea (cinnamon-flavoured), but quite strong. After a few sips, she took it back and went to strain it. I believe she had already broached the relationship subject at this point. But I don't recall if she knew I had a man in my life, or asked me. At any rate, she had been able to describe him (personality, not looks), saying that it was a good relationship with lots of love. But on to the leaves. She turned the teacup this way and that, looking very contemplative. She seemed to find what she was looking for, and showed it to me. Apparently it was the center theme of the tea leaves - it really did look like a little couple standing together with the man hugging the woman from behind. Quite cute, really. =) She said again that it was a close relationship and that there was a lot of love. Then she mentioned an older couple that was somewhat close to us. She asked about my parents . . . not likely. My parents haven't existed as a couple since long before I was 16 and they physically split. His parents? Doubtful. Once again, I seemed to have stumped her. She went on to describe the couple - they were older, and somewhat close to us. For all outward appearances, they were very close, doing everything together. But there was a gap between them (in the leaves), which meant there was a growing rift. I chuckled and said 'That could be his dad, but it's not his mom - he's on his third wife these days.' She laughed and said 'Well, maybe he'll be on his fourth before long.' Then she went on to describe another character - another male in my life, but related. Perhaps a sibling. I volunteered that I had 3 brothers. She said that could be it - that I was definitely closer to one than the rest. Which is somewhat true - I've been talking (messaging) pretty frequently with my youngest brother these days. She said he was protective of me, and when I seemed doubtful (he's younger, 18, and doesn't live with me - I didn't see him being protective), she went so far as to show me who he was in the tea leaves. 'See? He's right over top of you, watching over you!' That one baffled me. She went on to talk a little more, without the tea leaves. She had said back in the beginning that this would be a good year for sealing relationships. Now she went back to that, asking how long we'd been together (3 years) and if I had a ring yet. I said no. She said she saw me being married (or at least engaged) by my next birthday. This made me smile a little - hopeful, but also thinking that she didn't get a terribly good reading of my boyfriend. She asked if we'd talked about marriage, and I said only in that neither of us is in a big hurry. A little later, she said she sensed I was a little more ready than I let on. I laughed. When I related this to a different friend later, she said ' I could have told you that!' Yes, but again, this is someone who doesn't know me. She said she sensed that the man in my life had thought about marriage, but was a little intimidated by the responsibility and enormity of such a step. This could be true - I know it's not something he'd tell me. He's very proud, and wouldn't say anything until he was sure he was ready. She also said she sensed I was a little insecure about his feelings for me, but assured me that he wouldn't still be around if he didn't love me. This caught me off-guard - just the night before, I'd had a frank discussion with BF and discovered that he felt really pestered about certain things. This left me wondering what else bugged him about me, and how deep it went. Indeed, I was very insecure. She re-iterated that he put up with a lot from me (which elicited a bit of a guilty giggle), but he wouldn't have stuck around if he didn't care. She talked a little bit about motherhood . . . said she saw a baby for me sometime in my 27th year . . . that I would enjoy motherhood, but that I would always need a life of my own. This is something I've often thought about, and realized to be true about myself. She said that I'd always need something of my own, to keep improving myself, and that this wasn't a bad thing because children eventually grow up and leave us. I wondered if there was a hint of wistfulness in her voice at this point, or if it was just my imagination. While I don't think I'll ever stop being hopeful about those events - married with a baby within the next 2 years or so - I've been trying to take everything she said with a grain of salt. She was way off about some things, but she also had some good advice about my personality. Part of me hopes that, now the weddings should be over for a while (BF is the last in his family to get married now), maybe BF will allow himself to think about it. If there's one thing I've learned about him over the last 3 years, is that he refuses to be pushed into anything. If he even thinks he's being pushed or forced or manipulated into something, he will do his damndest to go the other way. But when he decides he wants something, he goes full steam ahead. It happened with moving in together - I vaguely mentioned it, simply asking if he'd thought about it. He quite honestly said no, and I dropped the subject. A few months later, he asked me out of the blue if I wanted to move in with him. Less than two months later, we were signing papers to buy a house together. To be honest, I kind of like the fact that I don't know for sure what my life holds for me. I can honestly say I love my life, and I don't mind waiting to see what happens.
